DOC.HEAD: Twin Storms: Floods Sweep Through Southeast; Hurricane Looms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `At 10:30 p.m. ...' to UPDATE with 11:30 p.m. location of Lili.
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor AUG1; LaserPhotos WX8, WX12; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Lili and the remains of Tropical Storm Marco locked pincers on the South on Friday with a combination of powerful winds, heavy surf and drenching rains. At least 10 people have died in the storms. Lili lurked off the shore of North Carolina, a weakling among hurricanes, spinning harmless 8-foot waves into the Outer Banks. Its winds were clocked at 75 mph - barely over the hurricane threshhold of 74 mph. But the convergence of Lili and Marco, plus the dying remnants of Tropical Storm Klaus, brought a third day of rain and dangerous flooding to parts of the coastal Southeast. ``We got so much rain, so fast. ... We've never had anything like this,'' said Pam Smith, director of the Richmond County Emergency Management Agency in Augusta, Ga., whose west side was swamped by floodwaters. In South Carolina, where floods Thursday carried caskets out of a graveyard, state climatologist John Purvis said some places had the most rainfall in a century. At the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla., forecasters said Lili appeared to be veering to the north sooner than expected, decreasing the threat of a direct hit on the mid-Atlantic coast. At 11 p.m. EDT, Lili's center was at latitude 32.8 north and 72.3 longitude west, about 240 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C. It was moving north-northwest at nearly 14 mph. ``It poses less threat to the East Coast now,'' said Herb White, of the National Weather Service in Raleigh, N.C. ``Now it's projected to parallel the coast a little farther out.'' Forecasters said gale-force winds could extend 75 miles inland along the route of the storm. Tourists in North Carolina packed ferries to flee the Outer Banks, although the most noticeable signs of the storm were waves big enough to thrill surfers. ``I'm a little bit nervous, for my parents' sake,'' said Tom Sherer, 18, of Coinjock, N.C., who was riding a skim board on the waves. ``They're sort of worried.'' ``Worried we're going to get hurt,'' added 16-year-old Mike Vernon of Currituck, N.C. The real danger for the time being lay farther south, in Georgia, where four people drowned in rising floodwaters that ravaged the Augusta area. The floods were blamed on the remnants of Tropical Storm Marco, which blew north out of the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday. The victims included an 80-year-old man who drowned as he and his wife struggled to leave their car at a flooded railroad track north of Augusta. Coroner Thomas King said the man was swept away in the floodwaters; his wife managed to escape. Three people drowned in Jefferson County, about 50 miles southwest of Augusta, sheriff's Deputy Mark Williamson said. On Thursday, three people drowned in South Carolina, while one person drowned and two died in storm-related traffic accidents in North Carolina. In Augusta and surrounding Richmond County, officials closed all roads and declared a state of emergency, Ms. Smith said. ``All of our roads are flooded,'' she said. ``People are trapped in their homes. People are hollering out for help through their windows. Some are on the rooftops. There are people in their cars floating down the road.'' Emergency officials began evacuating families in the Augusta area early Friday morning. Ms. Smith estimated that several hundred people had been moved from their flooded homes by boat or four-wheel-drive vehicles by afternoon. About 100 had been taken to a shelter, and the remainder stayed with friends or family, she said. An estimated 52,000 students missed classes as schools in three counties closed. Augusta College canceled morning classes, and most city and county government offices closed. At Appling, northwest of Augusta, 8.6 inches of rain was measured during a 24-hour period. In western North Carolina, a rural one-lane bridge collapsed and a mudslide squeezed traffic to one lane on a nearby highway north of Lenoir. Authorities said no one was on the bridge when it collapsed. Two emergency centers opened in Ashe County in northwestern North Carolina Friday night, as streams and rivers overflowed their banks, said Renee Hoffman of the state Division of Emergency Management.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Haunts Germans Even After Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By KEVIN COSTELLOE
DOC.TEXT: Like an old ghost in a new house, Erich Honecker is haunting the reunited Germans. Toppled from power a year ago, the 78-year-old former Communist chief is confined to a Soviet military hospital near Berlin, guarded by stone-faced soldiers. His health is the topic of nearly daily news reports, some saying the ousted East German leader, who is suffering from kidney cancer, is well enough to be imprisoned and others saying he is not. As Germans forge their new country, many are demanding punishment for despised members of the East Berlin regime that ran the country into the ground. Honecker tops the list. ``I think most Germans would like to see Honecker go before a court,'' said a spokeswoman for Berlin's justice department, Jutta Burghart. Prosecutors have had plenty of opportunity to bring Honecker to trial, having conducted investigations of deadly shootings at the Berlin Wall, economic crimes and the harboring of terrorists during his government. Berlin's chief justice, Jutta Limbach, hopes to decide ``within a few weeks'' whether there is enough evidence to arrest the small, slight man with steely eyes and a ramrod-straight posture. Even if the answer is yes, doctors will have to decide whether Honecker is well enough to stand the rigors of Germany's customary pre-trial detention. Any resulting indictment, trial and appeal could take years. All of this will keep Honecker's despised legacy alive almost indefinitely. On Thursday, prosecutors in formerly Communist East Berlin handed their western counterparts the files from the investigations of Honecker and his cohorts. The Honecker files alone take up about 400 thick spiral ring binders and a ``series of supplementary documents,'' officials said. Their work has been hampered by the disarray of the documents. While Berlin officials look into the notorious shoot-to-kill orders and economic crimes, a local prosecutor in the southwestern city of Karlsruhe is pursuing his own investigation. Gerhard Klass has accused Honecker of obstruction of justice for giving a safe haven to West Germany's most notorious terrorists. Germans are still furious that Honecker welcomed members of the leftist Red Army Faction, and reportedly provided homes to Middle East terrorists as well. There is a good chance the two criminal investigations will be merged. Doctors in the former East Germany say Honecker can't stand the rigors of prison. He spent one night in a crumbling, filthy jail last January. Officials in the now-extinct country said it would have been an ``injustice'' to put the aging ex-dictator on trial during East Germany's brief existence as a democracy. But those determinations will be reviewed by the new panels of legal and medical experts. Honecker's 82-year-old former secret police chief, Erich Mielke, is already in prison and targeted for the same Berlin investigation aimed at his boss. A full color photo spread in this week's Stern magazine documented the ailing Mielke's ambulance ride from an East Berlin jail to one in the west. Will Honecker ever stand before a judge, ready to defend his 18 hard-line years in power or his masterminding of the Berlin Wall construction in 1961? ``That will depend on the people who make the decision on his health condition,'' prosecutor Klass said. Germany's news media have been following every twist and turn in the case. Two days before the Oct. 3 unification, the mass-circulation Bild newspaper ran a front-page picture of Honecker walking jauntily and unaided near the Soviet hospital in Beelitz. Bild's blaring headline: ``Honecker - Really too Sick for the Clink?'' One open question is the ability of Germans to get their hands on Honecker anytime soon, since he is in a Soviet compound. Prosecutor Klass jokingly says the Soviets could complicate things by declaring Honecker an ``honorary colonel'' in the Red Army, in an attempt to put him beyond the reach of German law.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes To Require Parent Notification For Teenage Abortions
DOC.TEXT: Legislation approved by the Senate would bar teenage girls from obtaining abortions at most hospitals unless at least one of their parents was informed. The requirement, which still must go to the House, would cover teen-age girls under the age of 18 who seek abortions at any hospital that receives federal money. That covers virtually all hospitals, particularly public ones. But abortions without notice still might be available at privately run clinics that shun federal dollars. If enacted, the provision would be the first federal requirement that parents be involved in abortion decisions by young people. Many states have passed laws requiring notice or consent by a parent or parents but some of them have been invalidated by court decisions. The Senate approved the parental notice provision Friday as an amendment to a big appropriations billcovering the departments of Health and Human Services, Labor and Education. The notice requirement was sponsored by Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., a fierce abortion opponent. It passed on a voice vote, but only after opponents failed on a 48-48 tie vote to table, or kill, the measure. The bill was approved on a 76-15 vote. It goes back to the House, and probably will be sent to a conference committee to work out differences on the notification provision and other amendments. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, who led the fight against the provision, argued that it was probably unconstitutional. He said it lackdd a so-called ``judicial bypass'' that would allow an incest victim, or others unable to discuss the subject with parents, to seek a court's permission to obtain an abortion without notifying one of her parents. ``This is just too, too rigid,'' Harkin said. Armstrong's amendment was added to a provision banning Medicaid abortions for poor women, except when the life of the mother is threatened or in cases of rape or incest. President Bush vetoed a similar spending bill last year because he opposed allowing Medicaid abortions in any cases other than when the mother's life is in danger. That abortion language has been the object of yearly congressional battles. Abortion rights supporters won House passage of the broader exemption for the first time last year, then fell 51 votes short of overriding Bush's veto. The Senate's latest version, covering spending in fiscal 1991, would allow federal money for abortions in cases of rape and incest that were ``reported promptly to a law enforcement agency or public health service.'' Harkin's support for abortion rights is an issue in his re-election battle this year against anti-abortion Republican Rep. Tom Tauke. Armstrong, who is retiring from the Senate after this year, argued that abortion was an ``extremely cruel, barbaric practice'' and ``intolerable in a civilized society.'' He acknowledged that others disagree. ``I don't think young women should have an abortion without the permission of one parent,'' Armstrong said. He stressed that his provision requires notice - not consent - of one parent. Harkin said the effect would be to require notification for poor girls, who can't afford private clinics, while permitting the affluent to escape the restriction. ``What this amendment provides is a two-class system,'' Harkin said. ``... The end result of this amendment is very cold and very heartless.'' The bill provides $183 billion in spending in fiscal 1991 for HHS, as well as the departments of Labor and Education. It includes money to partially fund a bill approved earlier this year to increase spending to combat AIDS and authorizing direct assistance to cities hardest hit by the disease. The Senate tabled a pair of amendments sponsored by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that would have cut AIDS spending. A measure adopted earlier this year authorized $600 million a year in AIDS spending. But because of the budget problem, the spending bill trimmed that figure to $159 million in fiscal 1991 and earmarks $441 million for the following year.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Question High Level of Planned Military Spending
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers are voicing concern that the level of military spending approved by Congress in its budget resolution is too high for a nation facing an economic crisis. ``This isn't about a war with the Russians. This isn't about a war in the Middle East. This is about the economic survival of this country,'' said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., prior to House approval Friday of a $268 billion defense bill. By a vote of 322-97, the House adopted a military spending bill that cuts off production of the B-2 bomber at 15 planes and slashes President Bush's budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative. The House bill meets the level of defense spending worked out by the House and Senate last week in a budget resolution seeking to cut $500 billion from the federal deficit over the next five years. Final passage of the House measure didn't come, however, without a stiff challenge to the spending level for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Earlier this week, the House Appropriations Committee added a $5.3 billion package to the bill to meet the revised budget levels approved by Congress. Liberal Democrats and a handful of Republicans sought to eliminate the addition with a measure imposing a 2 percent across-the-board cut on defense spending. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said the levels set in the congressionally approved budget resolution were ceilings, not floors, on spending. ``We can achieve better savings,'' he said. Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee on defense, warned that the cut would affect American men and women who are stationed in the Persian Gulf region to stop Iraqi aggression. Although the bill does not specifically address the cost of Operation Desert Shield, expected to total $15 billion in fiscal 1991, sea lifts and projects such as the M-1 tank are key to the U.S. buildup in the gulf. ``Anybody who thinks this does not affect them is wrong,'' Murtha said. The amendment to impose a 2 percent cut failed on a 215-201 vote. Following House approval in September of a defense authorization bill that set spending ceilings, the legislation approved Friday cuts Bush's proposal for SDI to $2.3 billion. He had requested $4.7 billion. The appropriations bill provides no production money for the Pentagon's plan to place MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars. Instead, the bill creates provides $618 million for the MX and Midgetman land-based missiles. The spending plan calls for a cut of 77,000 U.S. troops worldwide. The Bush administration has proposed a cut of 38,000 from the active duty troop total of 2.1 million. The Senate is expected to take up its version of the appropriations bill next week. The package approved by the Senate Appropriations Committee late Thursday is markedly different from the House-approved legislation. The Senate committee bill trims about $1 billion from Bush's budget request for SDI, funds the president's request for the B-2 bomber and cuts U.S. troop strength by 100,000. White House officials have said Bush would veto the House-passed bill because of its wholesale cuts in his budget request for strategic weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Both Koreas Agree In Principle To Form Single Team For Olympics
DOC.TEXT: North and South Korea have agreed in principle to form a single team for the 1992 Olympics and other international sports events, news reports said Saturday. The national Yonhap News Agency said in a dispatch from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, that the agreement was reached between South Korean Sports Minister Chung Dong-sung and his North Korean counterpart, Kim Yu Sun, on Friday. Both officials agreed in principle to form a single Korean team for the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona and the 41st World Table-tennis Championships in Nagoya, Japan, in 1991, it said. Chung visited communist North Korea at the head of a South Korean soccer team which had an exhibition match in the north's capital of Pyongyang on Thursday. It marked the first sports exchange between the two rival Korean states. Chung and the South Korean soccer team returned home Saturday through the border village of Panmunjom, ending a five-day trip to the north. The two Koreas, bitter rivals since the division of their peninsula in 1945, have initiated talks on forming a single sports team several times in the past but failed to reach agreement over procedural and other matters. The friendly soccer match came several days before the prime ministers of both Koreas are to meet in Pyongyang in a second round of talks. The two ministers met in Seoul early last month in the highest talks ever between the rival nations. The Korean peninsula was divided into the communist north and the capitalist south at the end of World War II in 1945. They technically still remain at war since no peace treaty has been signed since the 1950-53 Korean War.

DOC.HEAD: Buildup of American Forces in Gulf Said to Exceed 200,000
DOC.TEXT: More than 200,000 U.S. troops now are arrayed against Iraq, an increase of at least 25,000 from the Bush administration's last official count, Pentagon sources said. The administration has refused to say exactly how many soldiers, sailors, airmen, and marines are in Saudi Arabia or afloat in the Red Sea, Persian Gulf and northern Arabian Sea. But sources said Friday that the total has jumped above 200,000 with the arrival this week of elements of two armored cavalry units. The sources spoke on condition they not be identified. Iraq has about 430,000 men in Kuwait and southern Iraq, according to the Pentagon. Also on Friday, sources said a Marine amphibious force is planning a practice assault on the Arabian coast soon as a trial run for a possible U.S. invasion of Kuwait. In its last official count of U.S. forces in the gulf area, the Defense Department said Thursday that ``more than 175,000'' are now deployed. The department is expected to announce soon that the total has risen by at least 25,000, sources said. In a sign that the gulf supply buildup is winding down, the Pentagon announced that it was releasing from active duty an Army Reserve unit that had been helping with port operations at Beaumont, Texas. It said the 82 members of the 1192nd Transportation Terminal Unit, stationed at New Orleans, will be released Oct. 19. ``Its services are no longer required to support Operation Desert Shield,'' the Pentagon said. The unit was called to active duty on Aug. 27. Of the 259 reserve units from all services called to active duty for Desert Shield, the 1192nd is the first to be released. Among the latest forces to arrive in Saudi Arabia are elements of the 1st Cavalry Division, which includes a brigade of the 2nd Armored Division, from Fort Hood, Texas, and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment from Fort Bliss, Texas. Also attached to the 1st Cavalry is the 13th Corps Support Command. Members of these units began arriving this week, meeting up with their roughly 300 M1-Abrams tanks and other equipment, which was shipped from their bases several weeks ago. Maj. Jesse Seigal, a spokesman at Fort Hood, said, ``We're in the latter stages'' of deploying elements of the 1st Cavalry, the 2nd Armored and their support command. In their usual configuration, that would include about 20,000 men. Seigal said he could not say exactly how many were being deployed to Saudi Arabia. The 3rd Armored from Fort Bliss includes about 4,500 men. In a related development, a Pentagon source said the Marine Corps was planning a training exercise to practice amphibious landings on an Arabian beach. The dummy run will be similar to an exercise Oct. 2 in which the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade stormed a beach on the friendly shores of Oman, but the new exercise will be held elsewhere on the Arabian Peninsula, the source said. About 45,000 Marines are depooyed in the gulf area.

DOC.HEAD: Reds 2, Pirates 1
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Reds beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 2-1 Friday in Game 6 of the National League Playoffs, setting up a World Series match with the Oakland Athletics starting Tuesday night. Winning pitcher Danny Jackson was just short of perfect for the Reds, giving up one run and one hit in six-plus innings. Relievers Norm Charlton and Randy Myers gave up no hits. Ron Oester, the remaining link to the Big Red Machine of the 1970s, led off the seventh inning with a single and advanced to third on Billy Hatcher's single. In a surprising move, Manager Lou Piniella then pinch-hit Luis Quinones for Paul O'Neill. Quinones delivered with a single to drive in Oester. The Reds' first pennant since 1976 comes only a little more than a year after former manager Pete Rose was banned from baseball for gambling.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Senate Committee Takes Up Own Tax Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Finance Committee approved a bipartisan budget package early Saturday that would double gasoline taxes and do nothing about tax rates on high incomes or capital gains. The plan was approved on a 15-5 vote shortly after it was endorsed by leaders of both parties. It is one of the more middle-of-the-road budget packages of the several circulating on Capitol Hill. ``I believe it is a fair compromise,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. The plan would raise the federal gasoline tax from 9 cents per gallon to 18.5 cents in three steps by 1992, raising $43 billion over five years. Nine Democrats and six Republicans voted for the plan, while two Democrats and three Republicans opposed it. The vote occurred shortly after midnight. House Democrats were lining up behind a soak-the-rich deficit-reduction plan that also would cut capital gains taxes for middle-income families; House Republicans were drafting a rival plan of their own. The House Democrats' plan put them at odds with President Bush, who has said he would accept such a trade only if taxes on the wealthiest Americans were raised less and capital-gains rates cut more than the Democrats are proposing. An administration official following developments, speaking on condition that his name not be used, said Bush could support the Senate committee plan. The Senate Finance Committee plan would reduce Medicare spending by $49 billion over the period. Of that, $17.6 billion would come from increasing costs to the elderly and disabled in the program. An example of one higher cost would be a doubling of the $75 annual deductible for physicians' fees to $150 next year. Information made available by the source who provided details did not include a total amount to be achieved for budget deficit reduction through higher taxes and spending cuts. Like other plans, the Senate Finance Committee Package would raise taxes on cigarettes by 8 cents to 24 cents a pack by 1993, on liquor by $1.20 to $13.70 per gallon, on a six-pack of beer by 16 cents to 32 cents, on table win by 3 cents per bottle to 21 cents. People earning more than $100,000 would be ableonly 95 percent of tax deductions they would otherwise get, and wages subject to the 1.45 percent tax for Medicare, levied in the Social Security payroll tax, would rise from $51,300 to $89,000. The package also include $29.4 billion worth of tax breaks, the bulk of them - $16.8 billion - for the poor through an increase in the earned income tax credit. Most of the rest appeared to be for business. The new plan by the House Democrats also would raise money by delaying taxpayers' protection against ``bracket creep'' for a year. However, unlike other plans under consideration, it would include no increase in the tax on gasoline. Meanwhile, Republican House members squabbled among themselves as they tried to come up with their own plan to find - before next Friday's deadline - $500 billion in spending cuts and tax increases to reduce the federal deficit over the next five years. Bush, seemingly unruffled as frustration grew on Capitol Hill, said he was confident a ``sound budget agreement'' could be found. ``Just stay calm - it will all work out,'' he said. Bush said Thursday he would accept an increase from 28 percent to 31 percent in the tax rate of the highest-income Americans in return for a deep cut in the rate on capital gains from sales of stock, real estate and other investments. But he also said he didn't think Congress would pass such a bill, and he declared he would not accept the 33 percent top rate the House Democrats propose. Republican members of the House were divided over whether to fight any kind of tax increase or support Bush's call for a deficit-cutting plan that includes some sort of higher taxes. There was no conclusion, but the anti-tax group seemed to carry the day. ``We're developing a House Republican position,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla. ``We're not stating the position of the president, nor are we stating what we think Democrats would vote for.'' GOP leaders were trying to piece a measure together, arguing that Republicans need to unite around a proposal. But many conservatives were insisting that unless the plan reflected bedrock Republican principles - such as no tax increases of any kind - it would be better to present nothing. ``If the alternative is going down in flames anyway, we ought to put out a Republican, pro-growth, anti-tax agenda, not something like Rostenkowski with a few less taxes,'' said Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas. The heart of a GOP plan under consideration would cut capital-gains taxes and raise tax rates on the wealthy but still produce a tax cut for the typical person with income above $200,000 a year. A surprise entry in the liberal proposal is a provision to forgo next year's inflation adjustment to tax brackets. This would affect taxpayers at all income levels, costing them $17.5 billion over the next five years. The adjustment is designed to offset bracket creep, under which inflation gradually pushes people into higher tax brackets when they get cost-of-living pay raises. The annual adjustment in the personal exemption also would be foregone but the standard deduction would be increased as usual. Delaying bracket-creep protection allowed backers of the liberal plan to eliminate a proposed 12-cent-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes. The liberal plan would raise taxes $160 billion over the next five years and reap $43 billion in savings from the Medicare program. Only $10 billion of that Medicare saving would come from beneficiaries. Well over half the tax increases in that proposal would come from higher-income individuals. The biggest shot: raising the maximum tax rate on the wealthiest people from 28 percent to 33 percent. The higher rate already is paid by some upper-middle-income people. People with incomes over $1 million a year would face a 10 percent surtax. Also, workers would have to pay the 1.45 percent Medicare tax on their first $100,000 of wages rather than $51,300 under current law. To encourage saving, the plan would allow a person 25 or older to escape taxation on half of $200,000 of certain capital gains in a lifetime. These gains could include profits from the sale of such investments as real estate, small businesses and timber - but not corporate stock. In addition, a person with income up to $150,000 could exclude another $1,000 of such gains each year. Other parts of the Democratic alternative include increased taxes on alcoholic beverages, such as doubling the 16-cent tax on a six-pack of beer; adding 8 cents to the cigarette tax; doubling the gas-guzzler tax on new cars, and requiring state and local government employees not covered by a public pension plan to join the Social Security system.

DOC.TEXT: Cher and Madonna have a few things in common - successful singing careers, movie stardom and Warren Beatty. ``That was before Sonny. Warren has probably been with everybody I know and unfortunately I was one of them,'' Cher said in the November issue of Vanity Fair magazine. ``But since I was only 16, maybe I can get out of it with that. I don't know if I was a bimbo then, but I had pretty low self-esteem,'' she said. Madonna and Beatty, who co-stared in the film ``Dick Tracy,'' had a highly publicized affair, now ended. Cher says she has five other tattoos in addition to the one she bared in her ``If I Could Turn Back Time'' video. ``I don't know why I like tattoos so much,'' she said. ``I can't defend them. I love getting them.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Model Marla Maples says she'd keep her name if she were to tie the knot with her alleged lover, Donald Trump. ``I always promised my daddy I'd keep my name, because I'm an only child and he never had a son,'' Ms. Maples, 26, said in the November issue of Vanity Fair magazine. ``I said, `Daddy, don't you worry.' So I don't know, maybe Marla Maples Trump,'' she said. --- ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) - Gov. Mario Cuomo is turning to acupuncture for treatment of a knee injury. Cuomo, 58, said Friday he got the idea at a campaign reception this week in New York City with Asian-American supporters. The governor says he injured his knee while playing basketball with an aide about a week ago. He says it frequently stiffens and makes it difficult to walk. Cuomo has a history of back problems but has never received acupuncture treatments before. --- IRVINE, Calif. (AP) - Mariya ``Masha'' Kalinina has been a busy Miss Moscow. ``What can I say? I am here because of Miss Moscow,'' the first crowned beauty queen in Soviet history said during a recent California visit. Since winning the title two years ago, she has appeared in an Italian movie, ``Pay Attention to Perestroika,'' and cut a record, ``Love Me,'' in France. And she wrote a book, ``Me, Miss Moscow: The Diary of a Beauty Queen.'' Ms. Kalinina, 19, said she was shocked to hear of reports she agreed to pose for Penthouse and Playboy magazines. She said she refused.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Seeks to Force Covert Cambodia Policy into the Open
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, in a sign of growing discontent with America's proxy wars around the world, has approved a $20 million program for Cambodia designed to supplant the Bush administration's covert aid to Cambodian rebels. ``It is ... healthy for us to provide this aid in this form,'' said Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman David Boren, D-Okla. ``This is a policy question that should not be discussed behind closed doors,'' Boren said as the Senate adopted the program as part of a 1991 foreign aid bill late Friday. ``It gives us an opportunity to involve the American people in an open public discussion of this matter.'' Boren's committee voted in June to kill the $13 million U.S. covert aid program that has provided military support for the non-communist resistance groups fighting the Vietnamese-backed communist government in Phnom Penh. The non-communist groups are fighting alongside the forces of the Khmer Rouge, the infamous faction that was responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians during its four-year rule in the late 1970s. While U.S. law bars the use of any aid to help the Khmer Rouge, opponents of administration policy have charged that American dollars are in fact doing just that, and Boren alluded to the problem in supporting a policy change. ``There is a strong likelihood that in the past some of the funds from the United States may have been used, directly or indirectly, to benefit the Khmer Rouge,'' he said. ``It's time we had restrictions that are enforceable.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, disclosed that the United States has provided some 200 tons of excess Pentagon supplies to the resistance since 1987, and noted that audits are unable to trace the supplies to their ultimate users. ``There is an urgent need to improve accountability for U.S. funds,'' Mitchell said. The House-passed version of the foreign aid bill includes only $7 million in humanitarian aid to the resistance. The amendment the Senate adopted Friday apparently combines that amount with the $13 million that had previously been provided secretly, and converts it into a broader program of aid and development. Instead of being intended primarily to supplement U.S. military aid, the new program would be designed to reinforce diplomatic efforts now being led by the United Nations, Mitchell said. ``This aid program will demonstrate the United States' commitment to a political process.'' Differences between the two versions still must be worked out after the Senate bill wins final passage, probably sometime next week. ``This is a step in the right direction,'' Boren said. ``It in no way turns our backs on the non-communist resistance.... It opens the doors to the possibility that we might provide support for a broader spectrum of Cambodian society in need.'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., reminded senators of the horrors many fear if the Khmer Rouge - now the strongest militarily of the rebel factions - ride U.S. aid back into power. ``This is the killing fields,'' Danforth said. ``The Khmer Rouge are still an active organization with Pol Pot (their ruthless leader) still in control. And their methods, if anything, have become more sophisticated in their evil.'' Defection from the administration's policy was yet another example of discomfort on Capitol Hill with U.S. support for covert wars waged by rebel groups in Cambodia, Afghanistan and Angola. At the same time it eliminated the covert money for Cambodian rebels, the Senate voted to cut about $100 million off the administration's $300 million request for the mujaheddin, the rebels fighting Afghanistan's Soviet-installed government. And an open debate is expected next week in the House about the $60 million covert aid program for UNITA, the guerilla movement fighting Angola's Marxist government. With relations with the Soviet Union improving, much of the Cold War rationale has disappeared for the conflicts, reducing them to the status of small regional wars and lessening their importance to members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher Says He's Solved Columbus Landfall Mystery
DOC.TEXT: A university professor says he has solved the ``wherewazit'' mystery of Christopher Columbus' first step in the New World. Now comes the hard part - convincing other historians. After four years of research, John Winslow says Columbus came ashore 498 years ago Friday at Lignum Vitae Cay, part of the Berry Islands in the northern Bahamas east of Miami. Historians agree Columbus landed somewhere in the Bahamas on Oct. 12, 1492, during his first voyage to the New World, but in the past 200 years, nine other islands have been proposed as the landing site. ``You know what a whodunit is? This has been a wherewazit,'' Winslow said. Winslow, who specializes in historical geography, says he grew interested in the explorer's landfall in 1986, when he was an assistant chairman of social sciences at the College of the Bahamas. He read theories on the two most accepted locations, San Salvador, formerly named Watlings Island, and Samana Cay, but said they did not adequately fit descriptions in Columbus' ``Diario'' of the voyage. Columbus' original diary has been lost. A 1530s transcription remains. Through the years, it has been translated various times and at points is contradictory and vague. Winslow said he developed his theory on details from the journal and other historical writings. He said freshly cut branches Columbus reported seeing shortly before the land sighting would have been caught in the Antilles current if they came from the Bahamas and disproves the two accepted landfall sites. ``It's impossible for Samana Cay and San Salvador. Because (of their location) the driftwood would have been on the other side of the current,'' he said. Winslow said his is the only theory that places Columbus' stop in Cuba at an area that matches the geographic descriptions reported in his diary. ``I'm convinced that (Winslow is) an outstanding scholar and thorough researcher,'' said George Daniels, chairman of the department of history at the University of South Alabama. ``If he believes he knows the correct route of Columbus, he has good reason to believe that.'' Winslow has to convince others who have spent years researching their own theories and governments who have millions of tourism dollars at stake. This week the landfall debate continues in Jamaica, where the Society for the History of Discoveries is holding its annual meeting. The society, which specializes in the history of geographic exploration, does not endorse any theory. ``I rather doubt that (the landfall issue) will be resolved to the satisfaction of everyone,'' said John Parker, a longtime society member and curator of the James Ford Bell Library at the University of Minnesota. ``It will be resolved to the satisfaction of some people, but the contention will continue.''

DOC.HEAD: Assassin's Bullet a Common Form of Protest in Egypt
With PM-Egypt-Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By WILLIAM C. MANN
DOC.TEXT: The assassin's bullet and other forms of political violence have been frequent methods of protest in Egypt this century. Mostly the mayhem has been in the cause of Egyptian and Arab nationalism or Islamic extremism. Moslem fanatics fired the bullets that killed President Anwar Sadat and seven people with him on a military reviewing stand in 1981. Since 1910, when a nationalist murdered Prime Minister Butros Pacha Ghali, violence motivated by politics has killed at least 30 government ministers, prominent Egyptians and Britons, and ordinary civilians. In 1985, a crazed Egyptian border police sergeant in the Sinai slayed four Israeli children and three adults because he said they spied for their government. Egyptian authorities said the latest slaying, the death Friday of the Parliament speaker on a Cairo street, could have been perpetrated either by nationalists or religious zealots. The Persian Gulf crisis also could have been the motivation, because Egypt led Arab opposition to Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. Authorities say Iraqi agents sent to cause turmoil could have killed Rifaat el-Mahgoub, speaker of the People's Assembly and second to President Hosni Mubarak in the official hierarchy, and four security men. ``One possibility is an outside operation, but the gangs for these operations are under control,'' said Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa. But when Moussa reported last week the arrest of more than 35 alleged terrorists sent by Iraq to assassinate and cause general unrest, he admitted that others remained on the loose. He said they would be caught, but no further arrests have been announced. The four assailants, who rode by on motorbikes when they killed el-Mahgoub, also could have been ``our brothers of the Gamaat,'' Moussa said. The word, Arabic for ``groups,'' denotes violence-prone Moslem activist organizations. It would be a great improvement in their effectiveness as terrorists compared with other outings in recent years. Moslem extremists were blamed for a bomb ambush last year that missed then-Interior Minister Zaki Badr. They shot at two former interior ministers and a government magazine editor in 1987. Only former Minister Abu Basha was hurt seriously. Moussa did not mention a third possibility: Egypt's Revolution. The government claims to have destroyed that Arab nationalist group. But the attack had some hallmarks of four of the group's actions in the mid-1980s that killed two Israelis and left six Israeli and American diplomats wounded. It also resembled in several ways an assault on an Israeli tour bus last February by men speaking Arabic with Palestinian accents. Nine people were killed. A roster of the century's assassination victims in Egypt shows a diverse group. -Sixteen Israelis: They included people on the tour bus and two staff members of Israel's Cairo embassy, the Jewish state's only one in an Arab country. -Two British diplomats: Sir Lee Stack, governor-general of Sudan, shot down by an Egyptian nationalist in 1924 with Egypt's army commander; and Lord Moyne of the wealthy Irish Guinness brewing clan, by Jewish terrorists in 1944. -Prime Minister Ghali and two other officials were shot for collaborating with Egypt's British occupiers in the first half of the century. -In 1948, Prime Minister Mustafa el-Nokrashy, who doubled as interior minister, fell to an assassin's bullet while waiting for an elevator in the Interior Ministry. The fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood, founded 20 years earlier in Egypt, was blamed. In 1954, Brotherhood member Mahmoud Abdel-Latif fired at Gamal Abdel Nasser, republican Egypt's first president, as he spoke from the same Alexandria balcony where two years later he would proclaim nationalization of the Suez Canal. The fusillade missed. Nasser, incensed, banned the organization, had six members executed and arrested thousands, many of whom were tortured.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle: It's Time to Limit Terms of Congressmen
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said public resentment of government may lead to limits on the terms of members of Congress. Oklahoma's vote last month to put 12-year limits on state legislative terms was just the beginning, Quayle said in a speech Friday to the Society of Professional Journalists. Similar ballot initiatives in Colorado and California are expected to pass next month, Quayle said. ``Clearly, term limitation is an idea whose time has come. It reflects a widespread condemnation of the current system. People rightfully feel that entrenched legislators are only interested in getting elected,'' the vice president said. ``I don't think that the movement to limit terms will stop at the state level. I wouldn't be surprised to see Americans calling to limit terms of the members of the U.S. House of Representatives and the United States Senate, and I hope they do,'' he said. Quayle spoke scathingly of Congress, where he spent 12 years representing Indiana in the House and Senate. The administration has been trying to portray Congress as the obstacle to a budget agreement and to deflect criticism heaped upon President Bush for indecisiveness on taxes. Quayle said a ``congressional elite'' has emerged, bearing out the founders' fears that ``life tenure would threaten our freedom by creating a new ruling class.'' Congress has exempted itself from its own laws on civil rights, equal employment, ethics, privacy, equal pay and freedom of information, Quayle said. ``In effect, Congress has created two classes of Americans: those who make the laws and those who must obey the laws,'' Quayle said. Bush, asked his view on the issue in a news conference on Tuesday, was less definitive. The president noted that term limits were part of the Republican Party platform in 1988, and said he was ``certainly not opposed to it, I haven't decided exactly.'' ``But whether I make that a prime mover in the political campaign that lies ahead in the nex few weeks, I don't know.'' ``But I think people want a change against the incumbents up there on the hill,'' he said referring to Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Quayles Ride Park Horses During Government Shutdown
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle and her daughter rode National Park Service horses in Manassas National Battlefield Park a week ago when the park was officially closed to the public in the government shutdown. The park superintendent and the vice president's press spokesman on Friday confirmed an account of the Oct. 6 visit that appeared in the Fairfax Journal. The visit occurred when the 22-member park staff was furloughed, as were many workers throughout the federal government. Three law enforcement rangers were the only staff on duty, and they accompanied Mrs. Quayle and her 11-year-old daughter, Corinne, said park superintendent Ken Apschnikat. Apschnikat said he closed the main gates, the visitors center and two parking lots, but otherwise made no attempt to keep people out of the park about 25 miles southwest of Washington. The park is the site of two famous Civil War battles. ``It would be very difficult to close the whole park, and I made no attempt to,'' Apschnikat said. The 4,345-acre park is crisscrossed by several major highways. Many visitors slipped under gates or climbed over fences. The Quayles arrived through a back entrance. The Quayle family frequently visits the park to ride the nine horses stabled there, which are normally reserved for the rangers. Dan Quayle's spokesman, David Beckwith, said he saw nothing inappropriate in the visit to the park. Beckwith said, ``The horses weren't on furlough.''

DOC.HEAD: Chances of Persian Gulf War 50-50, Former U.S. Officials Say
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The odds of the tense situation in the Persian Gulf erupting into a full-scale war are about even, say three former top government officials and the head of a major oil company. James R. Schlesinger, a former defense secretary and one-time CIA director, and Joseph J. Sisco, former undersecretary of state, both said Friday that they considered the likelihood of Middle East military action to be ``50-50.'' Sol Linowitz, a former ambassador who worked on Middle East peace negotiations and the Panama Canal treaty, suggested that he believed the chances of war were ``60-40, not because there's no alternative, but because we won't seriously have explored the alternative.'' ``I think we're finding now the sense - in Washington, certainly - that we're moving inexorably toward military action, that we are going to be faced with that ... '' Linowitz added. Mobile Corp. chairman Allen E. Murray said he was ``a little more optimistic than the others,'' and suggested there is less than a 50 percent chance of war. The four made their comments during a news conference after a closed-door discussion of the Persian Gulf crisis with members of the Business Council as the 100 leaders of the nation's top corporations held their semiannual meeting at this mountain retreat. Schlesinger, now senior adviser for Lehman Brothers, the New York investment banking firm, said any military action would not be short. ``A lot of people have used the metaphor the `six-day war,''' he said. ``But almost every war ... has started with a prediction the war would be short at the outset and those predictions have regularly been belied.'' Sisco, a partner in Sisco Associates in Washington, agreed, adding: ``If it comes to the use of force, then both air power as well as ground forces will be necessary so that any notion of a four- or six-day scenario just is unrealistic.'' Linowitz, now senior counsel for Coudert Brothers, urged fullest exploration of ``a negotiated path ... to be sure there is not some way we can get to where we want to be without going to war and without compromising basic principles that led us to take this action.'' Meanwhile, panel members said the sanctions would remain in place for several months while diplomatic efforts continue toward an Iraqi pullout of Kuwait. ``One has to say realistically, however, there's absolutely no indication on the part of (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein at this time that he's interested in getting out, let alone on conditions laid down'' by the Security Council, Sisco said. ``I myself see relatively little prospect that Saddam will withdraw on our terms which is our diplomatic stance,'' Schlesinger said. ``We're asking him to capitulate. That would be desirable but not likely.''

DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Corrects Poll Figures on Republicans and Rich
DOC.TEXT: A research organization says a national poll it took last month showed that 21 percent of the respondents, not 51 percent as reported, associated Republicans with ``rich, powerful, moneyed interests.'' A poll three years ago showed 18 percent making such an association and the big jump to 51 percent in the poll by the Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press was widely published and frequently cited by political commentators. Times Mirror blamed the incorrect figure on a computing error. It said it also overstated the percentage of people who spontaneously said they associated Republicanism with conservatism, being business oriented and not being for the people. Scott Sowry, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said the party was certain that the apparent jump was an error. ``That's what we've been saying all along,'' Sowry said.
DOC.HEAD: Proportion of Unwanted Births Increases
DOC.TEXT: A survey shows an increasing proportion of unwanted births among women who have been married. The National Center for Health Statistics on Friday released its National Survey of Family Growth, which showed that 10.3 percent of the 1.6 million births to these women that occurred between 1983 and 1988 were unwanted at the time of conception. The random sampling was weighted to represent the entire population. The proportion was 14.3 percent in a 1973 survey but had dropped to 7.7 percent in 1982. The increase was most pronounced among women living below the poverty line. From 1982-88, the proportion of births unwanted at the time of conception among this group rose 74 percent - from 11.9 percent to 20.7 percent. Among women who had never been married, a quarter of the 2.5 million births from 1983-88 were unwanted at the time of pregnancy.
DOC.HEAD: Consumer Commission Moves to Ban Baby Bean Bags
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission says it has taken the first step to ban infant ``bean bag'' cushions because of 30 reported cases of babies found dead on them. The decision was made public Friday, a day after the commission voted to publish a notice of proposed rule making in which it will seek public comments to help it develop an accurate definition of the product. The cushions are filled with plastic foam beads or other granular material that can conform to the body of an infant, especially to the face, when the infant is placed stomach-downward. They have been promoted as resting or sleeping places for infants or devices to prop them upright, but in at least 30 cases have led to death through suffocation. The commission announced earlier this year an agreement with all known manufacturers of the cushions to recall them and not produce any more. The recalls, covering about a million cushions, are still in effect. The commission said consumers who have not already returned their infant cushions should stop using them, return to the store or destroy them. Recall instructions can be obtained from a toll-free telephone number, 1-800-638-2772. Most manufacturers have offered refunds.
DOC.HEAD: Enema Kits Recalled
DOC.TEXT: The major maker of barium enema kits is recalling some products because they may be linked to severe reactions, including nine deaths, from the common medical procedure, federal officials said. E-Z-EM Inc. of Westbury, N.Y., sent recall notices to customers a week ago, saying evidence suggests water-soluble proteins in inflatable latex cuffs on the enema tips may be triggering the reactions. The FDA has received 150 reports of allergic reactions related to barium enema procedures in 1989 and 1990, FDA spokeswoman Susan Cruzan said Friday. In nine cases, the patient died, she said. The company makes 85 percent to 90 percent of the kits, which are used to diagnose disorders of the intestines. About 8 million to 10 million barium enemas are performed annually, Cruzan said. The reports have been related to the company's enema kits with inflatable latex cuffs. Company officials did not return a telephone call for comment. In light of the reports, the FDA asked radiologists and other health professionals to report any adverse reactions related to barium enema procedures that have occurred in the past 12 months. The procedure involves injecting a barium-containing fluid into the rectum and colon, which enables these organs to show up on an X-ray. In some cases, the reactions occurred after the enema tip had been inserted, but before the barium had been introduced, the FDA said. The FDA said the cause of the problem is still unclear.

DOC.HEAD: Terrier Heading For Reunion After Weeks as Hostage in Kuwait
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Biggles the terrier was headed for a reunion with his owner after two harrowing months as a hostage in Kuwait and a daring desert escape. He was scheduled to fly today from London to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, where he was headed on Aug. 2 when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The Iraqis had refused a British Airways request to allow the dog to leave, said an airline spokesman. If dogs could talk, the lively bundle of white fur would have quite a tale to tell his owner, identified by British Airways only as A.J. Higginson, a Briton who works for the Malaysian Petroleum Company. A British Airways spokesman on Friday did Biggles' talking for him, as the 5-month-old West Highland terrier yapped and played at the Heathrow Airport quarantine station. He was stranded in the cargo hold of British Airways Flight 149 which landed at Kuwait City airport on Aug. 2 and was unable to leave because of the Iraqi invasion. The 367 passengers and crew were taken away to nearby hotels but the terrier was left in the main cargo hold without food or water, said the airline spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity in line with official practice. A few days later, several British crew members were allowed to return to the aircraft to collect supplies and remembered that Biggles was still in the cargo hold. To their amazement, he was still alive, though badly dehydrated. ``We are not sure exactly how long he was in there before he was rescued but he was very lucky to survive,'' said the British Airways spokesman. The crew members took the terrier back to their hotel in Kuwait where he was named Biggles after the fictional 1930s pilot whose stories by W.E. Johns thrilled British school boys between the wars. The crew, moved to Baghdad, cared for Biggles until they heard of someone planning to flee from Iraq by land into Jordan, the spokesman said. Biggles' unnamed benefactor smuggled him across the border into Jordan on Monday and he was turned over to British Airways staff at Amman Airport who arranged to fly him to London, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Cameraman Smashed Window To Get To Duke of Kent's Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A television cameraman said he smashed through a glass window at a city gallery in the hope of chatting about art with a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. Simon Reynolds pleaded guilty Friday at London's Clerkenwell magistrate's court to damaging a window at the art gallery where Lady Helen Windsor works. She is the 26-year-old daughter of the Duke of Kent. ``I am not infatuated with her,'' Reynolds, a 35-year-old freelance cameraman, told the court. ``I just wanted to talk with her about conceptual art.'' He said he made six visits to the West End gallery and tried to phone Miss Windsor before his break-in on Oct. 5, when he scuffled with gallery personnel and finally broke a basement window to reach Miss Windsor. Once inside, he simply waite for police to arrive. He was released on bail until Nov. 4, when Magistrate Michael Johnstone will decide whether to send Reynolds to jail.

DOC.HEAD: New Question: Will Drug Question Resurface?
DOC.TEXT: A police association wants the candidates in the Texas governor's race to release detailed medical records. The Houston Police Officers Association's made the request Friday. Democrat Ann Richards blamed the request on Republican Clayton Williams. The Republican's campaign said he didn't instigate it. Richards campaign spokesman Glenn Smith said she released all the medical records necessary when questions about possible drug use came up during the Democratic primary election. Her refusal to say ``yes'' or ``no'' when asked if she had ever used illegal drugs dogged her in that race. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, said then that answering such a question might discourage others from seeking treatment. Williams, angry over Richards' bid to link his Midland bank to a Houston drug money laundering probe, told reporters at a campaign stop that he might resurrect the drug question.
DOC.HEAD: House Candidate Arrested While Campaigning Door-to-Door
DOC.TEXT: A candidate for the state House was charged with criminal trespassing after he campaigned door-to-door at a condominium complex with a ``no soliciting'' policy. Jonathan Spodnick, 27, was released on a written promise to appear in court for arraignment next Thursday. The Bridgeport lawyer is the Democratic candidate for the House seat held by House Minority Leader Robert G. Jaekle. Jaekle is vacating the seat to run for lieutenant governor with Republican gubernatorial candidate John G. Rowland. According to police reports, a resident told Spodnick of ``no soliciting'' signs posted at the complex, but the candidate continued going door-to-door while campaigning Wednesday evening. Police reports said when authorities asked Spodnick to leave the complex, he refused. Spodnick said in a prepared statement that he was unaware soliciting was not permitted in the complex. But he also said he didn't believe political campaigning constituted soliciting. ``I am amazed that (the complex) would prohibit candidates from going door-to-door, meeting those persons whom they will represent.''
DOC.HEAD: New Poll Shows Helms, Gantt in Virtual Tie
DOC.TEXT: The race is tied between Republican Sen. Jesse Helms and Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt, a new poll indicates. Helms has 47 percent of the voter support and Gantt has 46 percent, according to a survey by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research of Columbia, Md. Seven percent of the voters were undecided. The poll results came from a telephone survey of 816 likely voters Oct. 8 to Oct. 10. The survey has a 3.5 percentage point margin of error. While the poll showed voters evenly split between the two candidates, it also showed that a large majority believe Helms will go back to Washington for a fourth term. When asked who they think will win, regardless of who they favor, 57 percent said Helms, 22 percent said Gantt and 21 percent were undecided.
DOC.HEAD: Chiles, Martinez in Virtual Dead Heat in Latest Poll
DOC.TEXT: The Florida governor's race between Republican Gov. Bob Martinez and Democratic challenger Lawton Chiles remains a virtual tie less than a month before the election, a poll shows. The Florida Opinion Poll, conducted for the New York Times' Florida Newspaper Group, showed 42 percent preferring Chiles, 40 percent for Martinez and 18 percent not giving an opinion. The poll, which surveyed 558 people between Oct. 7-9, has a margin of error of 4 percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Quayle Commits Gaffe In Q&A With Journalists' Group
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle committed a gaffe when answering a question about Louisiana's U.S. Senate primary and former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke. ``Unfortunately, the people of Louisiana are not racist,'' the vice president said Friday when fielding a question about Duke. Duke, running as a Republican but repudiated by the national party, got 44 percent of the vote against incumbent Democratic Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. That was a vote of frustration, not racism, Quayle said. Nationally, a ``new wave of cynicism has been building up for a long time,'' Quayle said. ``The voters are channeling their discontent into real and lasting reforms.'' He made the comments in an appearance before the Society of Professional Journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Swedes Consider Ending Compulsory Military Service
DOC.TEXT: A parliamentary committee has proposed ending compulsory military service and allowing any conscript to do volunteer civilian work instead, the nation's largest daily newspaper reported. Spokesmen for the Defense Committee confirmed a proposal on military conscription would be made public Tuesday but refused to comment on it. All Swedish males over 18 years old are now required to serve seven to 15 months in the military. Those accepted as conscientious objectors may do volunteer work. The daily newspaper Dagens Nyheter said Friday that some legislators believe the current law is unfair because it accepts some people as conscientious objectors but jails others who refuse military service. About 50,000 youths are drafted each year. Of these, only 2,000 to 3,000 are allowed to engage in alternative service for moral or other reasons, Dagens Nyheter said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Committee Approves Middle-Of-Road Budget Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Finance Committee approved a middle-of-the-road budget-cutting plan early today that raises some taxes on the wealthy and boosts the levy on gasoline. The panel adopted the plan on a bipartisan 15-5 vote, leaving the Senate in sharp contrast with the more fractious House. In that chamber, Democrats have endorsed a liberal package containing sharper tax increases for the wealthy. Republicans are torn between a more conservative proposal bearing President Bush's plan to cut the capital gains tax, or perhaps offering nothing at all. ``I believe it is a fair compromise,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, just before the post-midnight Finance panel vote. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., called the plan ``right and necessary,'' and predicted its approval by the full Senate. A Bush administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the president could support the measure. The proposal is the latest congressional attempt to fashion $500 billion in tax boosts and spending slashes for the next five years. Bush has demanded that lawmakers send him a deficit-reduction package by next Friday. If they do not, he has threatened to allow the government to close down once again the next day, when its legal authority to spend money will expire. The president, whose wavering stance on the question of boosting taxes on the rich has sparked frustration and ridicule on Capitol Hill, expressed confidence that a plan will be hammered together. ``Just stay calm - it will all work out,'' he said. But there are so many different proposals in Congress that it is difficult to foretell what the package will look like. Each plan contains common elements such as higher taxes on alcohol, tobacco and luxury items such as expensive automobiles. They would pare the growth of defense spending by close to $200 billion over the next five years, and limit increases in Medicare by varying amounts. But from there, the plans differ. The Senate Finance proposal would limit income-tax deductions for people who earn more than $100,000 per year. It would apply the 1.45 percent Medicare tax to earnings of up to $89,000, rather than the current $51,300. It would boost the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax to 18.5 cents by 1992. And it would raise the $75 deductible Medicare beneficiaries pay for doctors' bills to $150. The new plan by the House Democrats would raise the income-tax rate the richest Americans pay from 28 percent to 33 percent, an increase Bush has promised to veto. It would also raise money by delaying for one year the usual adjustment of tax brackets forinflation. This provision would hurt taxpayers of all incomes. However, unlike other plans under consideration, it would include no increase in the tax on gasoline. House Republicans debated a plan that would raise the tax rate on the wealthiest Americans to 31 percent, while cutting the capital gains tax rate to 15 percent. The capital gains tax - applied to sales of property like real estate - is now treated like other income, with a top rate of 33 percent. House Democrats said their plan put a fair share of the deficit-reduction burden on the wealthy. ``You're seeing the difference between the Democratic Party and what they want to do, and the Republican Party and what they want to protect,'' said House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. But conservative Republicans insisted that they were concerned not with protecting the rich but with fostering economic growth. ``The Republican Party for 10 years has been united around the concept of growth,'' said Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn. The full House Ways and Means Committee endorsed a compromise plan earlier in the week that left tax rates on the wealthy alone and raised the gasoline tax by 9 cents per gallon. At this morning's Senate Finance Committee session, voting for the compromise package were Mitchell; Dole; committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas; Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y.; David Boren, D-Okla.; David Pryor, D-Ark.; Donald Riegle, D-Mich.; John D. Rockefeller, D-W.Va.; Tom Daschle, D-S.D.; John Breaux, D-La. Also, Sens. Bob Packwood, R-Ore.; John Danforth, R-Mo.; John Chafee, R-R.I.; John Heinz, R-Pa.; and David Durenberger, R-Minn. Opposing the plan were Sens. Max Baucus, D-Mont.; Bill Bradley, D-N.J.; William Roth, R-Del.; William Armstrong, R-Colo.; and Steve Symms, R-Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations: Cuban Withdrawal From Angola On Schedule
DOC.TEXT: Cuba is withdrawing its 50,000 troops from Angola on schedule and expects to complete the U.N.-monitored pullout by July 1991, the U.N. secretary-general said. In a report to the U.N. Security Council, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Friday that 38,643 Cuban troops had left Angola by Sept. 30. The pullout began in 1989. The Cubans are leaving under a regional peace accord brokered by the United States. Under the agreement, South Africa also gave up control of Namibia. The Cubans have backed the Marxist government of Angola in its battle with rebels of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

DOC.HEAD: Geena Davis Files For Divorce From Jeff Goldblum
DOC.TEXT: Citing irreconcilable differences, Oscar winner Geena Davis filed for divorce to end a nearly three-year marriage to actor Jeff Goldblum. The petition was filed in Superior Court. It said the two have been estranged since Sept. 1. Miss Davis, 33, won a supporting actress Academy Award for her role as Muriel, an offbeat dog trainer in the 1988 film ``The Accidental Tourist.'' Goldblum, 36, and Miss Davis co-starred in the remake of the horror classic ``The Fly.'' They also appeared together in the comedy ``Earth Girls Are Easy.'' The two were married Nov. 1, 1987, and have no children. Settlement of their property will be determined later, the divorce petition said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Aoun Orders His Troops to Surrender Under Heavy Artillery Attack
DOC.TEXT: Under heavy bombardment, rebel Gen. Michel Aoun fled the presidential palace to the French Embassy Saturday and ordered his troops to surrender, ending a nearly two-year rebellion. ``I ask my chiefs of staff to take their orders henceforth from Gen. Emile Lahoud,'' Aoun said in a brief address to his 15,000 mainly Christian troops broadcast by his radio station. Lahoud commands Hrawi's 20,000 mainly Moslem army, which teamed up with thousands of Syrians troops and hundreds of tanks in a three-pronged ground assault on Aoun's enclave in Lebanon's Cristian heartland. The attack was spearheaded by two hours of Syrian air and artillery bombardment of the presidential palace east of Beirut, where Aoun had his headquarters. Aoun fled to the French Embassy and first called for a cease-fire. The government of President Elias Hrawi, whose army is backed by an estimated 40,000 Syrian troops, demanded his surrender. The attack came hours after an assassination attempt against Aoun. Aoun had considered himself the legitimate authority in Lebanon since September 1988, when he was appointed a caretaker prime minister by outgoing President Amin Gemayel. Hrawi was elected president Nov. 24 to implement an Arab League-brokered peace plan endorsed by Parliament to end 15 years of civil war. He then sacked Aoun as army chief and interim prime minister. Aoun has rejected the peace accord because it does not contain guarantees for a complete Syrian military withdrawal. The Syrians have had troops in Lebanon since 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. The peace accord provides for sharing political power equally between Moslems and Christians, ending the traditional dominance of the Maronite Catholics, the main Christian sect. Aoun and Hrawi are both Maronites.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Born At Bridge During Tropical Storm Marco
With PM-Hurricane-Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A woman on the way to a birthing center had her baby in the car while her husband negotiated a three-mile bridge in pounding rain with a tractor-trailer rig on their tail. ``I kept saying, `He's coming out, I can feel it,' '' Brenda Urban said. ``It didn't register with my husband. ... He finally turned on the car light and looked and said, `He's coming out!' And I said, `Yeah I know.' '' It was 4 a.m. Thursday. Mrs. Urban and her husband, Rick, were traveling to a midwife birthing center 45 miles away in St. Petersbury. Urban said he couldn't stop on the three-mile Howard Frankland Bridge because the tractor-trailer rig was bearing down on their car. The baby's head appeared while they made their way across the bridge in a driving rain from Tropical Storm Marco, which later was downgraded. ``My husband just reached his arm down and held the baby's head till we got across,'' Mrs. Urban said. Her husband had to unwrap the cord from the baby's neck. Garrett Michael Urban, 6 pounds, 2 ounces, was in good health and went home with his parents later Thursday, just about the time the first rays of post-storm sunlight peeked through clouds. ``I kept saying, `I can't believe we had our baby in the car,'' Mrs. Urban said.

DOC.HEAD: Reds Win National League Baseball Pennant
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Reds won the National League baseball pennant with a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. ``A lot of people didn't think that we had that kind of a ballclub,'' second baseman Mariano Duncan said after Friday night's game. ``I'm going to the World Series now. We've proven ourselves to everybody.'' Pinch-hitter Luis Quinones broke a 1-1 tie with a run-scoring single in the seventh and reserve outfielder Glenn Braggs reached over the right-field wall in the ninth to rob Pittsburgh's Carmelo Martinez of a two-run homer. The Reds' bullpen set a National League playoff record with four saves in the six-game series. Reds relieving pitchers Randy Myers and Rob Dibble shared most valuable player honors. It was the Reds first pennant since 1976. They face the powerful Oakland Athletics in the World Series, which begins Tuesday night. The two played each other in the 1972 World Series. Oakland won four games to three.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I think we're finding now the sense - in Washington, certainly - that we're moving inexorably toward military action.'' - Sol Linowitz, former Middle East peace negotiator, predicting the chance of war in the Persian Gulf is about 50-50. --- ``This isn't about a war with the Russians. This isn't about a war in the Middle East. This is about the economic survival of this country.'' - Rep.
