DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia, Miss., Shaken By Child Sex Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Allegations that parents traded their children's sexual favors for as a little as a pack of cigarettes have shaken a town trying to live down three civil rights murders 26 years ago. At least four children, now ranging in age from 11 to 15, were sexually abused as long ago as 1985 by some of their parents, other relatives and family friends, authorities said. Twenty adults, including one or both parents of each child, are suspected and the case will go to a grand jury for consideration of rape charges, investigators said. Police are investigating whether more children were involved, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The investigation has spread from Neshoba County to two neighboring counties. The investigation is a difficult one in a town that was the site of one of the civil rights movement's most tragic events - the murders of activists James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner in 1964. The activists' bodies were found buried in an earthen dam near this rural farm town of about 8,000 in east-central Mississippi. Nine people, including a Neshoba County deputy sheriff, went to prison for violating the workers' civil rights. ``We've come a long way since that happened,'' said a resident who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``All we want now is to get on with our lives. We don't want other (people) to think we condone what was done to these children but we don't want any more bad news.'' ``There is a fear that with Philadelphia's past history people in other areas of the country will think that all the people down here are doing this and that's definitely not the case,'' said Stanley Dearman, editor of the weekly Neshoba Democrat. ``People here are disgusted and they hope that some kind of justice is brought to bear on those responsible,'' he aid. The investigation began in July when a telephone caller told police one of the victims, an 11-year-old girl, confided to a baby sitter that her stepfather sexually abused her, Bobby Anderson, the town's chief police investigator, said during preliminary court hearings. The girl later told authorities the abuse also included her mother and others. The girl's mother denied that she sexually abused her daughter, but said others had sexual intercourse with the child. ``Sometimes the parents would let them at the child for a few dollars or pack of cigarettes or some liquor,'' Anderson said, before a judge slapped a gag order on people involved in the case. The victims include two other girls, age 11 and 15, and an 11-year-old boy. ``Something like this turns your stomach,'' said Sheriff Glenn Waddell. ``It's hard to describe the feelings you have when you sit down with an 11-year-old girl in the physical shape she was in and get her to tell me all the things that she went through.'' Anderson said the case would be presented to a Neshoba County grand jury Nov. 5.

DOC.HEAD: President Bush to Meet Dying Boy
DOC.TEXT: A boy whose dying wish - to meet President Bush - was initially turned down by the White House will get his dream after all, his family said. Bush decided Friday to meet with 8-year-old Jimmy Kilanowski after he personally learned of the boy's wish to shake his hand. The White House called the Kilanowski family at their Long Island home in Lake Ronkonkoma to arrange the meeting, scheduled for Oct. 23 in Stamford, Conn., where Bush will be campaigning. ``That's wow,'' Jimmy said when his mother, Laurie, gave him the news. ``He is so happy,'' Mrs. Kilanowski said. ``We are all thrilled that the president came through.'' Jimmy, who was given 1{ years to live in April 1989 because of five brain tumors, made his wish known through Wish Is Granted, an organization that helps terminally ill children fulfill their dreams. The request was turned down by White House staff members who said the president was too busy. The boy has called Bush ``the most important man in the whole wide world.'' New York Sen. Alfonse D'Amato stepped in Thursday to see if he could help, and successfully broke through the red tape that apparently had kept Jimmy's wish from reaching Bush. Jimmy, his mother, father, Peter, and 5-year-old brother, Danny, also will be treated to a White House visit during the Christmas season. ``They said that way Jimmy can see the White House when it's decorated like a fantasy land,'' Mrs. Kilanowski said. It is White House policy to grant wish requests only through Make A Wish Foundation, a national organization not affiliated with Wish Is Granted. That apparently was the main reason Jimmy initially was turned down by the White House. ``When the president learned of this young boy's wish, he said he would do everything he could to try to make it a reality,'' D'Amato said. ``I think Jimmy is an inspiration - the fact that when he was initially turned down he said `well, I still love the president.' Jimmy never lost his spirit,'' the senator said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Turns Tough on Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf `This has...' to CORRECT exchange rate. Pickup 14th graf `The government's...'
DOC.TEXT: The government has suddenly switched to painful and politically risky capitalist reform, raising fears of winters as cold and dark as those imposed by executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It cut energy subsidies and credits to the country's chronically inefficient government-owned industries and said the same treatment was in store for private consumers. On Friday it said the country's second-largest automaker will be allowed to go bankrupt if it can't pay its debts. Officials also have put Romanians on notice that state-controlled prices will go up, and that the country can afford no more across-the-board wage increases. Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu warned that could cause civil unrest. ``The country has lived for 40 years in an equal system of wages,'' he told reporters. ``These are crazy people because they don't know anything else. ... We have to teach them that wages, like profits, are not assured, and they must strive to earn them.'' The National Salvation Front, which dominated the interim government after the December revolution that toppled and executed Ceausescu, was at first mostly concerned with winning May elections. It took the politically popular steps of shortening the workweek and raising salaries, stopping food exports and lifting Ceausescu's heat and energy rationing. It handily won the vote. The grim results of the government's largesse were presented to Parliament Oct. 10 by Prime Minister Petre Roman and Anton Vatasescu, the minister of commerce and industry. Productivity has fallen about 20 percent compared to last year. The decline has been felt especially in energy production, which has become even more crucial since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August. Exports are down and imports are up. The trade imbalance has grown to a projected annual $3.6 billion. Declining production and higher wages has led to a near-total depletion of the meager stocks in Romanian stores. Maintenance of the centrally controlled, heavily subsidized pricing system has bred massive corruption. Many stores sell off most goods to speculators at prices above the official ones. Speculators resell the goods for even more, often for hard currency only. This has driven the black market rate of 100 leu to the dollar, five times the official rate. The government's solution, Roman announced, was ``inevitably liberalization of prices,'' which officials said was to be enacted within one month. But the elimination of subsidies and price controls will have the unpopular effect of shifting high black market prices into state stores. Along with the devaluation of the leu, which officials say is imminent, this is almost certain to generate more demands for higher wages and possibly strikes, further damaging production. Roman warned Parliament that ``we cannot permit further pay raises.'' The government has attempted to head off public discontent by assuring private consumers they will have enough heat and light this winter. But many might not be able to meet the higher cost. To shift energy from industry, which consumes more than 80 percent of it, the government cut industrial energy subsidies and imposed special taxes on energy use by industry. This more than quadrupled the cost to industry of some forms of energy. The government said Friday that the huge automotive joint venture Oltcit would be allowed to go bankrupt if it cannot make good on debts of more than a billion dollars. Oltcit, a Romanian-French joint venture, would be the first company to be allowed to bankrupt, signaling the government's tough new stand as it makes initial steps toward a market economy. The manufacturer produced tens of thousands of cars that were replicas of an early 1980s model Citroen. It is Romania's second-largest car manufacturer after the Dacia company, which produces replicas of a 1970s model Renalt. The government also is looking to foreign investment to rescue Romanian industry by injecting know-how and money into its antiquated infrastructure in exchange for what Dijmarescu called ``a capable and cheap work force.'' Foreign investment has been stifled by Romania's poor international image, the result of political and ethnic unrest since the revolution. In March, six people were killed in rioting between ethnic Romanians and Transylvanians. In June, another six were killed when police suppressed a 53-day anti-government protest, and pro-government miners terrorized the capital for several days. The government now hopes the negative effects on foreign investment will be reversed by Romania's support for the West in the gulf crisis and new laws encouraging privatization and foreign ownership of local firms. Diplomatic and economic sources say there has been a dramatic increase in the number of foreign companies sending delegations to investigate business opportunities in Romania.

DOC.HEAD: North, South Korea Agree to Unify Sports Team
DOC.TEXT: North and South Korea announced today they have agreed to field a single team for the 1992 Olympic Games and other sports events, possibly signaling a new era of cooperation between the rival nations. North Korea, in a statement by its news agency, said the accord had ``contributed to the cause of national unification.'' Waving a bouquet of flowers triumphantly, South Korean Sports Minister Chung Dong-sung announced the agreement in principle on crossing the border at the truce village of Panmunjom. He had returned home with this country's men's and women's soccer teams from the first scheduled inter-Korea sports exchange since the division of the peninsula in 1945. The minister read a statement saying he had reached the agreement with his North Korean counterpart, Kim Yu Sun. He said they agreed to form a single Korean team for the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona; the 41st World Table Tennis Championships in Nagoya, Japan, in 1991; the Winter Asian Games in Samjiyon; and other major international sports events. The North Korean news agency, monitored in Tokyo, said the agreement was made public before the South Korean soccer teams left Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. Communist North and capitalist South Korea have been archenemies since the division of the peninsula at the end of World War II. The border between them is tightly sealed with more than 1.5 million troops on either side. The agreement to form joint teams is viewed as a sign that a new period of harmony between the two nations may be at hand. They have also been holding talks in an effort to ease military and political tension. The five-day trip to North Korea by 76-members of South Korea's soccer teams was only the second inter-Korean civilian exchange since partition. A small family exhange was held in 1985. The North Korean soccer teams are to visit South Korea Oct. 21-25 for a second exhibition soccer match. On Sunday, a 17-member delegation of South Korean musicians will cross the border at Panmunjom to spend 10 days in North Korea participating in a series of joint concerts. Officials said the two Koreas will discuss the proposed formation of a single inter-Korean team when they meet again in Seoul in two weeks. The two Koreas, which both pride themselves on their sports prowess, have initiated talks on forming a single sports team several times in the past but failed to reach agreement over procedural and other matters. North Korea boycotted the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Planeload of Middle East Refugees Arrives
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. chartered jet carrying 257 refugees from Iraq and Kuwait was the first such exodus in nearly three weeks. The Pan Am Boeing 747 touched down at Raleigh-Durham International Airport on Friday, ending a long and tiring odyssey for 123 American citizens, seven Canadians and 127 passengers of unknown nationality. About 103 on board were children, many of them infants. ``When the plane touched down in North Carolina, I hollered so loud `Thank God I'm in freedom city,'' said Mohammed Issa, a native of Jordan and a U.S. citizen. The first group off the plane were women in Middle Eastern garb, such as flowing robes and veils, carrying sleeping children and some personal belongings as they came down the ramp. North Carolina National Guardsmen escorted other children off the plane. Three people on board were in wheelchairs. One was diabetic, one was suffering from a blood disease and one was heavily sedated, said Joe Dean, secretary of the North Carolina Department of Crime Control and Public Safety and a member of a welcoming party allowed onto the plane. ``The moment I reached U.S.A., I started crying and I cried not because of the crisis, because it is hard when you see a friend treat you better than a brother,'' said a Palestinian mother of four who did not want to give her name or have her photograph taken. Issa returned to the United States with his wife and parents. He said the trip from Kuwait to Baghdad was the ``most miserable trip we've ever taken.'' ``There was no food. A trip that was supposed to take 1{ hours, maybe two, took 14 hours,'' said Issa, a former U.S. Marine who was once stationed at Camp Lejeune, N.C. He said a caravan of buses stopped in the desert for five hours, but there appeared to be no mechanical breakdowns or other reason for the delay. ``They were trying to break us down mentally, to make us suffer some,'' Issa said. ``They were trying to put some pressure on us to see if maybe somebody wouldn't do something.'' When the caravan finally got to Basra, the last stop before Baghdad, Issa was charged the equivalent of $72 for eight candy bars and four cartons of juice for his family. Issa said he would return to Bridgeport, Conn., where he taught before going to Kuwait as a special education teacher. The flight arrived in London on Thursday night, where passengers spent the night before completing the final leg of their journey away from the crisis in the Middle East, begun when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Calls Time Out Before Third Game
DOC.TEXT: The World Chess Championship will resume Monday after challenger Anatoly Karpov used one of his three time-outs to postpone the third game against Garry Kasparov. Karpov sent word of his decision Friday, seven minutes before the deadline for a time-out. Karpov and Kasparov, the champion, battled to a draw in Monday night's opening game. Kasparov drew first blood with a victory on Wednesday. The third game of the best-of-24-game, $3 million match had been set for Friday but was put off until Monday because of the time-out. Each player has the right to take three time-outs during the match. Generally, the time-outs are taken on a Monday or Friday to give a player a long weekend. They can also be used for illness.

DOC.BYLINE: Persian Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Kuwaiti exiles representing all walks of life gathered in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, for a three-day Kuwaiti People's Conference beginning today. The first session was expected to deal with ways to intensify opposition to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invasion on Aug. 2 and annexation of their country after a dispute over oil, land and money. --- A U.S. Marine amphibious force is planning a practice assault on the Arabian coast that could be a trial run for an invasion of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, Pentagon sources said Friday. The French magazine L'Express, meanwhile, reported that U.S. officials have devised plans for a four-day war with Iraq next month to liberate Kuwait and destroy Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's armed forces. But the assault could cost as many as 20,000 American lives, the magazine said. U.S. officials wouldn't comment. --- In what was widely interpreted as part of an effort to hold together the Arab alliance opposing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the United States joined the rest of the U.N. Security Council in denouncing Israel for the killing of 19 Palestinians during rioting in Jerusalem this week. --- Pentagon sources say the United States now has more than 200,000 troops in the Persian Gulf region. The administration has refused to say exactly how many U.S. soldiers, sailors, airmen, and marines are in Saudi Arabia or afloat in the Red Sea, Persian Gulf and northern Arabian Sea. There are believed to be about 430,000 Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait and southern Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Hanford Operator: Radioactive Waste, Water Added to Leaky Tank
DOC.TEXT: The operator of the Hanford nuclear reservation says workers in the 1960s pumped almost 1 million gallons of radioactive waste and water into a tank that had leaked in the past. Westinghouse Hanford said Friday the tank leaked about 2,400 gallons of liquid in 1962. Despite that leak, about 780,000 gallons of radioactive waste and 150,000 gallons of cooling water were added to the tank between 1963 and 1967, said Richard Raymond, a Westinghouse manager. ``The presumption is that some amount of cooling water leaked out of the tank and took some waste material with it,'' he said. ``How much - we don't know.'' Another damaged waste tank at Hanford may have leaked 800,000 gallons of radioactive cooling water into the soil, the Energy Department said Thursday. The department reported a year ago that tank had leaked 5,000 gallons of liquid since it ruptured in a 1965 explosion. The two underground, single-shell tanks are about five miles apart on the 560-square-mile nuclear reservation in south-central Washington. The 1965 explosion caused tank 105-A to leak and the radioactive wastes inside to overheat. The new estimate shows 832,000 gallons of cooling water were pumped into the tank between 1965 and 1978, when the work stopped. The Energy Department estimates 40,000 to 200,000 gallons may have evaporated through vents, leaving 632,000 to 792,000 gallons still in the soil. Provost said the state needs precise leak data so it knows how much work is required under a 30-year federal plan for cleaning up the entire Hanford site, which Westinghouse Hanford began operating for the Energy Department in 1987. Hanford waste engineer Johnnie Newsom said officials are still combing old records to determine how much waste was leaked. The Energy Department has agreed to turn over any additional records to the state. The tank filled with nearly 1 million gallons of waste and water was pumped dry in 1980 and is no longer in service. It cannot be determined how much of its contents may have evaporated or leaked, but a Westinghouse investigation continues, Raymond said. Recent monitoring of the soil beneath the tank indicates that no radioactive cooling water reached ground water or traveled away from the vicinity, Westinghouse Hanford said. Hanford has 177 underground waste storage tanks. They were used to store radioactive waste generated in four decades of producing plutonium for nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Lili Lurks Off Coast; Storms Leave At Least 11 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Lili downgraded to tropical storm, latest position, quotes; pick up 6th graf pvs, `Georgia and . . .'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Lili weakened off the Carolinas early today and was downgraded to a tropical storm. It posed little threat to South Atlantic states battered by a week of high wind and heavy rain from two other tropical storms. At least 11 people in Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina have died in storms since Wednesday. Residents boarded up their windows along North Carolina's Outer Banks, shelters were readied and some tourists fled, but the state was likely to be spared Lili's full brunt, forecasters said. Lili, whose winds dropped nearly 10 mph below the hurricane threshold of 74 mph, was expected to turn to the north and move away from the Carolina coastline. ``This motion should keep the storm and its effect away from the mid-Atlantic Coast,'' said forecaster Martin Nelson of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gable, Fla. At 6 a.m. EDT, Lili's winds were 65 mph, down from 75 mph earlier in the morning. The storm was centered at latitude 34.0 north and longitude 73.0 west, about 175 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C. It moved north-northwest at 12 mph. The hurricane was not expected to hit land today, Nelson said. The storm was headed toward the Northeast, but odds of landfall were lessening, he said. Georgia and the Carolinas kept an eye on floodwaters from heavy rain from the remnants of tropical storms Marco and Klaus. In South Carolina, thousands were told to evacuate their homes. High water receded in some areas, but others remained threatened by flooding. South Carolina's climatologist, John Purvis, said some areas of the state had the most rainfall in a century. Sumter County received more than 15 inches of rain within 24 hours Thursday. A 2-year-old boy died Friday in South Carolina after he wandered away from home. Two others drowned in the state and a fourth remained missing. Rising waters in Georgia killed four people, incduding an 80-year-old man as he and his wife struggled to leave a flooded railroad track. One person drowned and two died in storm-related traffic accidents in North Carolina. Two emergency centers opened in Ashe County in northwestern North Carolina as streams and rivers overflowed their banks, said Renee Hoffman of the state Division of Emergency Management. More than 5,000 South Carolinians were told Friday night to evacuate their homes as rivers and creeks swelled around the state and threatened to flood low-lying areas. ``Even if it stops raining, the dams could develop problems two or three days from now,'' said George Ballenger, South Carolina's chief of dams and reservoir safety. At Cape Hatteras on North Carolina's Outer Banks, surfers and wind surfers scurried for surging surf and swift winds Lili sent their way. ``I would only leave if they told us to leave,'' said Gus Linssen of Boston, one of many tourists at Canadian Hole, a favored wind surfing spot near Buxton.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Party, Ruled Off Ballot, Vows Retribution Against Democrats
DOC.TEXT: A Illinois Supreme Court ruling knocked a third party slate of candidates off the November ballot, and the party's rejected candidates vowed retribution against the Democratic Party on Election Day. ``The Democrats continue to dig a very deep hole for themselves in the November election,'' David Reed, chairman of the Harold Washington Party, said Friday. ``We know who the adversary is.'' The state high court voted 4-3 along party lines Friday to reject nominating petitions filed by the predominantly black party. The four Democratic members of the high court ruled that the party had failed to collect enough signatures for its candidates and had illegally used the Harold Washington Party label. The three Republican justices said the majority was needlessly strict in interpreting the election code. The party, named after the city's first black mayor, had sought to put 19 candidates on the Nov. 6 ballot for offices in Cook County, which comprises Chicago. The Washington Party contended that the Democratic Party was behind the ballot challenge. Democrats, who feared they might lose large numbers of straight party voters to the party, contended that Republicans were behind the third party effort. They tried to disassociate themselves from the ballot challenge, fearing a backlash from black voters. The high court upheld a ruling Sept. 20 that removed all the party's candidates from the ballot. Circuit Judge Eugene L. Wachowski ruled that although the party had gathered sufficient nominating petition signatures from Chicago, it fell short of the legally required minimum for each of its suburban candidates. The party is appealing Wachowski's ruling in U.S. District Court.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Double Agent Says KGB Backed Gorbachev To Succeed Chernenko
DOC.TEXT: Former double agent Oleg Gordievsky says the KGB backed Mikhail Gorbachev's rise to power in the early 1980s, believing he could save the Soviet economy, according to extracts published today from the ex-spy's book. The book also tells of unsuccessful KGB efforts through political contacts and the news media to hamper the reelection of former President Ronald Reagan. Gordievsky, 52, who fled to Britain in 1985, makes the claim in a book, ``KGB: The Inside Story of its Foreign Operations from Lenin to Gorbachev.'' He wrote the work with Christopher Andrew, a Cambridge University intelligence historian. Serialization of extracts from the book began today in The Times of London and will continue next week. The book will be published in Britain and the United States on Oct. 19. The book, as serialized, said that in the closing months of 1984, Gordievsky was the deputy KGB chief in London and the agency's local head of political intelligence. He had been working for Britain's MI6 espionage agency for more than 10 years. Gordievsky's book stated: ``It was clear to the London residency (KGB branch) that the KGB was backing Gorbachev for the succession to the increasingly moribund (Communist Party General Secretary) Konstantin Chernenko. ... ``Without a change in the Soviet leadership, the KGB saw no end to the problems of the Soviet economy and no end, either, to Western attempts to exploit them. ``In the months before Chernenko's long-expected death in March 1985, the KGB put great care into briefing Gorbachev in a way that would allow him to impress the rest of the Politburo with his grasp of Soviet and world affairs. The former spy said, however, that KGB support was only one reason that Gorbachev won election as Communist general secretary in March 1985. He said the KGB ``saw the election, nonetheless, as a major victory.'' In describing the purported anti-Reagan effort, the book says that the KGB told its agents in the United States ``to begin planning to thwart Reagan's bid for re-election in November 1984.'' ``Although arms control negotiations were still going on in Geneva, KGB leaders felt there was no chance of agreement. Any other American president, Democrat or Republican, would therefore be preferable to Reagan. The former spy said KGB agents in the United States ``were instructed to acquire contacts on the staff of all possible candidates and inside both parties.'' It did not explain how they planned to try to manipulate these contacts but added: ``Simultaneously, residencies throughout NATO were told to popularize the slogan `Reagan means war.' The book says the KGB branches around the world ``found it easy to claim credit, frequently undeserved, for many of the anti-Reagan articles which flooded the world's press.'' On Friday, Gordievsky said in an interview that the KGB helped ignite last year's East European revolutions to put pro-Gorbachev reform Communists in power. But he said the KGB and its Soviet Communist Party bosses never expected the outpouring of anti-Communist fervor which they were later helpless to stop. He did not say where he learned about the alleged KGB involvement in Eastern Europe. But he regularly goes to the United States for meetings with U.S. officials and international analysts, and he consults for the journal ``Intelligence and National Security.'' Gordievsky began working for the British while posted in Copenhagen, Denmark, in the early 1970s. He has said the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia pushed him to act on his growing disillusionment. The KGB sent him to London, but he was recalled to Moscow and questioned about his activities. He eluded his KGB tail and escaped to the West. His 1985 defection sparked a tit-for-tat expulsion of 31 Soviet and 31 British diplomats, trade representatives and journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Library of Congress May Wind Up With Magic Collection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT musicians to magicians.
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators may give the Library of Congress a collection of memorabilia from the world of magic that was seized from the head of a failed thrift. Thousands of posters, handbills, 16th-century books and private letters from Harry Houdini and other noted magicians were taken from Carl M. Rheuban after the savings and loan he ran was closed last month. Regulators say Rheuban, who ran First Network Savings in Century City, allegedly spent at least $1.5 million of the thrift's money on the magic collection, which was named after the late John Mulholland, an early 20th century magician. Library of Congress officials say they don't have the money to buy the collection, which was seized by the federal Resolution Trust Corp., the bailout agency for ailing savings and loans. ``These aren't just card tricks we are talking about,'' Larry Sullivan, chief of the rare books collections at the federal library, said of the magic collection. Kevin Shields, spokesman for Resolution Trust, said his agency usually sells all seized assets at auction, but the rarity of the magic collection has him considering whether to hand it over to the Library of Congress. ``It is an unusual asset, to say the least, for a savings and loan to have. If this were an apartment building, it would be an easy decision,'' said John F. Penrose, who is overseeing the thrift's closing for Resolution Trust.

DOC.HEAD: Clash At Massive Protest; Hunger-striking Opposition Leader Weakens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with violent clash, police block march by 20,000 protesters. Pickup 11th graf `Aides said...'; EDITS thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired tear gas today to block a street march by thousands of angry protesters leaving an anti-government rally attended by more than 100,000 dissidents and opposition supporters. Meanwhile, the health of opposition leader Kim Dae-jung deteriorated on the sixth day of his hunger strike against the government. About 20,000 people protesting government surveillance waved banners and shouted ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo.'' They were blocked from marching toward downtown Seoul by riot police about 2 miles from the park where the mass protest was held. Police fired volleys of tear gas to disperse radicals and dissidents hurling firebombs and chunks of cement pavement torn from the sidewalks. Injury figures were not immediately available. ``Disband Defense Security Command,'' protesters shouted as thousands of other marchers clicked flashlights and cigarette lighters on and off in the dark in a show of protest and unity. The protesters were demanding the dissolution of the Defense Security Command military intelligence which has conducted illegal and widespread spying on more than 1,300 civilians. Violence also erupted inside the park as the rally ended when some protesters hurled rocks and bottles toward the podium. Another group of protesters attacked a truck carrying about 20 members of the splinter Democratic Party. One party member was seen bleeding from his head. The reason for the violence was unclear, but it appeared to be disagreement between two factions of opposition parties attending the rally. Kim Dae-jung, head of leading opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, had been expected to speak at the rally, but doctors said the 66-year-old leader's health had deteriorated after six days of no food and he was not strong enough to appear. ``The barbarious surveillance of civilians by the security command clearly shows the Roh regime as a disguised military dictatorship,'' said National Assemblyman Choi Yong-keun, who said he was speaking for Kim. Aides said Kim, a two-time presidential candidate, had lost about 13 pounds since his fast began and he suffered stomach cramps. Kim was undergoing routine tests for admittance to a hospital, they said. Kim launched his hunger strike last Monday to demand reforms from the government and call attention to a scandal involving the military intelligence Defense Security Command, which allegedly spied on more than 1,300 civilians. The turmoil comes in the second month of a boycott by the 78 opposition members of the 299-member National Assembly. The opposition members resigned en masse in August, charging the government with railroading bills and curtailing democratic reforms. Roh fired the defense minister and head of military intelligence earlier this week. The new minister said military reforms would be made and an investigation was under way into the surveillance scandal. Opposition leader Kim said he would continue his fast until the government met four demands - disolution of military intelligence, implementation of local self-rule, economic reform and the ruling party's agreement to drop efforts to change from a presidential to parliamentary-cabinet system of government. U.S. Rep. Edward F. Feighan of Ohio sent a news release to Kim saying he supported him. ``But the recent exposure of the government's extensive domestic spying network makes one wonder whether it intends to shed completely its past of military rule,'' the congressman said in the release.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa-dated 4th item in rdp to correct style on company in 2nd graf, add location of Lyric Opera.
DOC.TEXT: J.W. Fisher, retired chairman of Fisher Controls and a nationally known patron of the arts, died Thursday at age 76. Fisher served as a director of New York's Metropolitan Opera Company for 35 years and as a lifetime member of the board of the Lyric Opera Company of Chicago. He received the National Medal of Arts award from President Reagan in 1987 for his support of the arts, including the Gramma Fisher Foundation. The foundation, named for Fisher's mother, donates money to dance, theater and opera productions around the country.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalists Or Iraqi Agents Blamed For Slaying Of Parliament Speaker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with funeral, sixth person dies. Pickup 10th pvs, `Saddam has...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egypt honored its slain parliament speaker and four security men today with a state funeral led by a grim-looking President Hosni Mubarak. The government said Iraqi agents or Egyptian Moslem fundamentalists were to blame for the assassination Friday of its second-highest official, Rifaat el-Mahgoub. He was the first Egyptian politician assassinated since Islamic extremists shot President Anwar Sadat at a military parade nine years ago. Four assassins riding two motorbikes killed el-Mahgoub in a car driving by a luxury hotel by the Nile. The death toll from the attack rose to six today with the death of the speaker's chauffeur. Doctors in a Cairo hospital said the driver suffered bullet wounds in the stomach, back and arm. Hassan Abu-Basha, a former police minister, told the Cairo newspaper Al-Ahram he believed el-Mahgoub's slaying was the work of Iraqi agents. He said the perpetrators possibly belonged to the Palestinian extremist faction led by Abu Nidal. The funeral was at Nasr City, the same suburban neighborhood where Sadat's funeral took place. Hundreds of red-bereted military police and white-uniformed policemen sealed off all streets leading to the mosque where the religious service was held. They also lined the funeral procession route, as did hundreds of plainclothes security men. Mubarak, wearing a black suit and sunglasses, and British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, on a two-day official visit, were in the front row of about 1,000 mourners. They included relatives of the dead, government officials and foreign diplomats. Symbolic units from the military services spearheaded the procession, followed by a military band and two dozen wreath-bearers. Behind them were four military jeeps carrying coffins of the four security men, draped in the red, white and black Egyptian flag. A caisson bearing el-Mahgoub's coffin followed, also wrapped in the flag. It was drawn by three pairs of black horses. Military officers rode the three horses on the right. Immediately behind came two officers carrying el-Mahgoub's decorations laid on black-velvet cushions. The procession began from the mosque and stopped about 1,500 feet away. Relatives of the dead then lined up to accept condolences from Mubarak and other mourners. Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa had warned days earlier of such an attack. He said authorities arrested alleged saboteurs who were entering the country with orders from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to assassinate Egyptian officials. Saddam has called Egypt a traitor to the Arab cause for sending its troops to back the U.S. military buildup in the gulf in response to the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The state-owned newspaper Al-Ahram, quoting police sources, reported Monday that local Moslem extremists were collaborating with Palestinian terrorists sent to the country by Iraq on sabotage missions. It said the extremists had provided weapons and explosives to five Palestinians from Abu Nidal's faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Recent reports said Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council recently moved its headquarters from Libya to Iraq. Police ordered a state of alert at airports to keep the assailants from fleeing and set up security checkpoints along Cairo bridges. El-Mahgoub's authority extended solely over the 458-seat Parliament, which he had headed since 1984. He was not active in the gulf crisis, Al-Ahram noted in a front-page editorial today. ``In fact he was assassinated because he was a prominent Egyptian politician. The assasins wanted to tell their terrorist bosses that they pierced the stability of Egypt,'' the newspaper said. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``We are shocked by the assassination of the Egyptian speaker. ``We certainly deplore these kinds of terrorist activities and assassination is the most vile kind of terrorism. We don't have any indication at this time who was responsible or what their purposes were,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Denounces Israeli Shootings of Arabs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with PLO, Israeli criticism of resolution. Pickup 22nd pvs, `The investigating...'
DOC.TEXT: Making common cause with its new Arab allies, the United States has joined the rest of the Security Council in denouncing Israeli authorities for killing 19 Palestinians during rioting in Jerusalem. In its unanimous vote late Friday, the council asked for a U.N. investigation of the deaths. But Israel said today it must consider whether it would allow such a mission on its territory. The U.S. vote for the resolution represented a rare departure from the usual American practice of defending Israel, its longtime ally, from censure in the council. The last U.S. vote against Israel in the United Nations was in 1988 over the Israeli practice of expelling suspected leaders of the Arab uprising, known as the intefadeh. Diplomats said the United States wanted to avoid a veto on the issue because it feared alienating its Arab allies in the international effort against Iraq. ``Beginning from now, Israel's protective umbrella will begin to be steadily removed,'' Malaysia's ambassador, Rasali Ismail, predicted early today. The Palestine Liberation Organization today accused the United States of preventing the Security Council from developing a stronger response. Yasser Abd Rabou, a member of the PLO's executive committee, said in Tunisia today that the resolution was ``insufficient'' even though it condemned the actions of Israeli police. The PLO initially sought a three-member Security Council mission that would have made recommendations on how to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories. That was seen as part of a PLO tactic of trying to get the council directly involved in supervising the territories. The resolution instead envisages an inquiry organized by Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said the killings ``never should have happened.'' ``The Security Council tonight grieves for those lost and injured (and) condemns the acts of violence - both provocative and reactive,'' he said. Monday's rioting in Jerusalem broke out after Arabs threw rocks at praying Jews. The Arabs were killed when police moved in, first with tear gas and rubber bullets, but later with live ammunition. In addition to the 19 dead, about 140 Arabs were wounded. About 30 Jews were injured. The U.N. resolution ``condemns especially the acts of violence committed by the Israeli security forces resulting in injuries and loss of human life.'' It also refers to the injury of ``innocent worshipers'' in an implied criticism of the Palestinian rock-throwers. The PLO had fought to have that phrase removed. The resolution was sponsored by Britain, Canada, the Soviet Union, Zaire, Finland, Ivory Coast, and France. Israel expressed regret over the resolution this morning. However, Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein, in a statement from his Foreign Ministry, complained that the resolution ``fails to condemn the cause of the tragic events in Jerusalem, an unprovoked Arab attack on Jewish worshipers. ... ``It is also regrettable that the Security Council fell into the trap laid by (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein and his PLO supporters, who inspired the riots in order to divert attention from Iraq's aggression in the gulf.'' A spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel today said the Cabinet would have to decide whether it would accept a U.N. investigating team. The statement by spokesman Avi Pazner said the U.N. action was ``without any reason or justification'' since the police opened fire after a stoning attack by Palestinians that injured more than 30 Jewish worshipers and police. One Western ambassador said the United Nations would send an American of such stature that the Israeli government would find it impossible to refuse the visit. The ambassador spoke on condition of anonymity and did not elaborate. The investigating team would be charged not only with looking into how Monday's riots were handled but at ``other similar developments in the occupied territories.'' It would recommend ways of ensuring the safety of Palestinians. Israel captured the Arab sector of Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war and later annexed it. The U.N. resolution followed five days of arduous bargaining among the United States and non-aligned nations on the 15-member council. The only Arab on the Security Council, Ambassador Abdalla Saleh al-Ashtal of Yemen, said the non-aligned countries supported the compromise because it is ``a clear condemnation of Israeli actions, something the council didn't do for a very long time.'' He said the investigating mission will report back to the Security Council by Oct. 24. The last U.S. condemnation of Israel was in 1988, when American officials objected to its expulsions of suspected ringleaders of the Palestinian uprising from the occupied lands. The United States cast a dramatic U.N. vote denouncing Israel in 1982, when Israeli forces invaded Lebanon to oust the PLO. It did so again in 1981, when the Israelis bombed a nuclear power plant in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Le Duc Tho, Vietnam's Celebrated Negotiator, Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with report he died from throat cancer. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Tho shared...' Name pronounced Lay Duhk Toh.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TOK2,NY15
DOC.TEXT: Le Duc Tho, a hard-line Communist revolutionary named as a winner of the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating a settlement in the Vietnam War, died today in Hanoi. Official accounts say he was 79. The Foreign Ministry in the Vietnamese capital said by telephone that Tho died early in the day but gave no details. Japan's Kyodo's news agency, reporting from Hanoi, said he died of throat cancer. He had been hospitalized at an army hospital since returning in April from treatment in Paris, the report said. Tho shared the Nobel prize with then-Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. Together, they negotiated the Paris Peace Accords of 1973. But Tho turned down the prize, saying Vietnam remained at war. The guns fell silent two years later, when Communist forces defeated the U.S.-backed Saigon government and unified the country. Tho, one of the organizers and theoreticians of Communist revolution in Vietnam, remained in the ruling Politburo after 1975. He was believed to have played a key role in Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia in late 1978. But in 1986, he was removed from the Politburo as aging veterans gave way to more liberal leaders seeking economic reform. Western diplomats have speculated that in recent years, Tho's power had ebbed but that he remained an important figure in the party's conservative ranks. His official position was adviser to the party's Central Committee. Until the end, Tho kept parts of his life from the public domain as did many revolutionary leaders of his generation. There are several different versions of his birthdate and accounts of his early life. By some accounts, he was born of poor parents in a village about 60 miles south of Hanoi. But some Western biographical sources say his father was a civil service official of middle rank in the French colonial administration. Still in his teens, Tho became involved in left-wing labor and political movements and helped organize several protests in the Hanoi area. He was among the founding members of the Indochinese Communist Party in 1930 and was later imprisoned by the French. In jail, he reportedly organized some fellow inmates, who nicknamed him ``Tho the Phonograph'' for his ceaseless recitations of Marxist literature, which he had learned by heart. His activities during World War II are still a matter of speculation among Western historians. Some sources say Tho escaped to China and helped Vietnam's founding father, Ho Chi Minh, form the Viet Minh guerrillas and lead them against the Japanese. Others say Tho spent some of the war years in a French prison in Vietnam. After the founding of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam and during the war against the French colonialists, Tho became a key Communist Party organizer in South Vietnam and a prime purger of the middle and upper classes in North Vietnam. He became a member of the party's Politburo in the 1950s and an expert on party organization and ideology. Periodically, he criticized ``revisionists, defeatists, traitors, pessimists and individualists'' within party ranks. Although a party watchdog through much of his career, he often called for patience and moderation in healing internal rifts. Unlike parties in China and the Soviet Union, Communists in Vietnam carried out no bloody purges. During the Vietnamese war in 1960s and 1970s, Tho apparently did not have a direct say in military matters. Until 1968, his diplomatic experience had been limited to trips to various Communist nations, usually as head of Hanoi's delegation to party gatherings. In 1968, with the Vietnam War stalemated, the United States and North Vietnam opened talks on a cease-fire. Tho was officially described as special adviser to his delegation, but it became apparent that the real powers to negotiate lay with him. In Kissinger, Tho faced an adversary acknowledged as one of the most skilled and stubborn negotiators of recent times. The silver-haired Tho also proved a man of considerable social polish and personal charm, although he rarely sought the limelight during his years in Paris. The negotiations dragged on year after year, the two sides trying to overcome what Kissinger called ``mountains and ravines'' of complexities. The accord was finally signed Jan. 27, 1973. It resulted in the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Vietnam, the exchange of prisoners and the splintering of South Vietnam into Communist- and Saigon- controlled zones. But true peace failed to materialize, each side accusing the other of sabotaging the agreements. The Nobel Peace Prize Award of 1973 was perhaps the most controversial ever. Leftists protested the selection of Kissinger, and other critics bristled at the naming of a Communist revolutionary.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0489 to fix writethru designator
Rebel Lebanese General Surrenders Under Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with report Syrian troops first controlled Aoun strongholds. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Aoun had...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI1,2
DOC.TEXT: Syrian forces using land and air power today blasted the stronghold of Gen. Michel Aoun, who ended his 11-month mutiny by fleeing to the French Embassy and ordering his forces to surrender. Aoun told his troops to pledge allegiance to the government of President Elias Hrawi, trying to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war among Christian and Moslem factions. Hrawi's army entered Aoun's presidential palace headquarters in suburban Baabda at 12:45 p.m. (5:45 a.m. EDT), Beirut radio stations reported. The official Syrian news agency SANA said that almost two hours earlier, Syrian troops had taken control of the palace headquarters and the Defense Ministry complex in the suburb of Yarze, which had also been under Aoun's control. Aoun had opposed the government's peace plan, which gives the Moslem majority an equal share of power, but has no timetable for withdrawing the 40,000 Syrian troops, in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. The developments contributed to the growing instability in the Middle East, where the United States is struggling to hold together its alliance of Arab states opposed to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Syria, the main power-broker in Lebanon and Iraq's arch-rival, is an important part of that effort. Several of Aoun's battalions surrendered after Aoun's order and fighting was tapering off at the major entry points to the Christian enclave, witnesses and police said. Civil aviation authorities ordered Beirut airport closed. In Paris, the Foreign Ministry said France had granted Aoun political asylum and was prepared to help him leave Beirut. Beirut radio stations said Hrawi asked for a pledge from France to ban Aoun from political activity. Aoun's departure removes a major obstacle toward implementing the Arab League-brokered peace plan. But many enmnities still exist not only between Christians and Moslems, but among the various sects on both sides. ``This is a historical moment, heralding the reunification of the Lebanese army and the return of peace to Lebanon,'' said Hrawi's prime minister, Salim Hoss. He called for the Lebanese to close ranks behind his government. At least 15 civilians were killed and 110 wounded in fighting early today along Beirut's Moselm-Christian dividing line and Lebanon's central mountains, police and hosptials said. Military casualties were not immediately available. Aoun, 55, escaped assassination Friday by a Moslem Shiite gunman who aimed a pistol at him as he addressed cheering supporters. The crowd roughed up the gunman, and bullets went astray, wounding an Aoun aide. ``I ask my chiefs of staff to take their orders henceforth from Gen. Emile Lahoud,'' Aoun said in a brief address to his 15,000 mainly Christian troops broadcast by his Lebanese Radio station. Aoun, who had served as caretaker prime minister, had refused to step down in November, when Hrawi was elected president. Hrawi's 20,000 mainly Moslem army, commanded by Lahoud, today joined thousands of Syrians troops and hundreds of tanks in a three-pronged ground assault on Aoun's enclave in Lebanon's Christian zone. The attack began with two hours of Syrian air and artillery bombardment of Aoun's palace headquarters east of Beirut. Lahoud's bulldozers knocked down mounds of earth and removed wire barricades leading to the Aoun-held district of Ein Rummaneh in east Beirut. Thousands of Aoun's supporters had formed a human shield around the palace to help the general deter a Syrian assault. Aoun's radio station said they left after the general told them to go home at midnight Friday. ``Let us all rise above our hatreds and band together in a national unity that will definitely lead Lebanon to peace, security and stability,'' Hrawi said in a radio address to the nation after Aoun's surrender. Moslem west Beirut, where Hrawi's government is based, erupted in jubilant gunfire over Aoun's defeat. Lebanese and Syrian soldiers in the Moslem sector shot sustained volleys of machine-gun fire into the air. Defense Minister Albert Mansour ordered crossings between Beirut's Moslem and Christian sectors reopened ``to reunify the capital.'' Hrawi, Aoun, and Lahoud are all Maronite Catholics, the largest Christian sect and the dominant power in Lebanon since it gained independence from France in 1943. Aoun has tried to establish himself as the legitimate authority in Lebanon since September 1988, when he was appointed caretaker prime minister by outgoing President Amin Gemayel. Hrawi was elected president Nov. 24, 1989, with a mandate to enforce the peace plan brokered by the Arab League. The agreement stipulated an equal distribution of power between Moslems and Christians. After his election, Hrawi promptly dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister, but the general denounced Hrawi as a ``Syrian puppet'' and refused to leave the presidential palace. In an effort to bolster his own administration, Aoun waged an unsuccessful war to oust Syrian troops from Lebanon. He also battled forces of rival Christian militia leader Samir Geagea, a supporter of the new government. Aoun's battles with the Syrian army from March to September 1989 claimed 929 lives and wounded 2,744 people. His fight with Geagea this year from January until Sept. 26 killed 1,046 people and wounded 3,222.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Report Warns of Gridlock in the Skies in Next Century
DOC.TEXT: Air traffic likely will double early in the next century and billions of dollars in airport expansion and thousand-seat planes may be needed to prevent gridlock in the skies, said a report released Saturday. ``Delays in air travel have been mounting and could reach staggering proportions in the coming years,'' the National Research Council conclude in its report on a one-year study conducted for the Federal Aviation Administration. In 1987, each of 21 major airports experienced more than 20,000 hours of flight delays. But by 1997, the report said, 39 airports could reach that level. Delays could reach 100,000 hours a year at such major hubs as Chicago, Atlanta and Denver. The nation's air transport system is expected to carry about 1.3 million domestic and international passengers a day in 1990. But shortly after the year 2000, the number is expected to reach 2.5 million a day or nearly 1 billion passengers a year, the report said. ``If this growth continues, the system could be carrying 4 million to 5 million passengers daily by 2040, more than triple the present volume of traffic,'' the report said. If plans are not made now to handle such vastly increased levels of air travel, ``congestion and delay ... will be a constraint on growth that will profoundly affect the society in the 21st century.'' The study calls for a blend of new construction, changes in approach and greatly expanded research and development. Specific recommendations include: -The FAA should establish a strategic planning process through the year 2040 with shorter-range goals in each 10-year period. -Increase capacity at up to 50 existing airports at a cost of $40 million to $65 million each, with runway changes and improvements in air-traffic control. -Develop new secondary hubs for connecting flights at some or all of 28 under-used airports at a cost of $250 million to $500 million each. -Study ways to improve airport design, manage resources, reduce airport noise, and integrate air and land transportation. -Create an expanded, centrally organized airport system by giving the federal government authority to oversee improvements in airport capacity, possibly including construction of 10 new major airports. This could involve federal costs of $50 billion to $90 billion over the next 40 years. -Seek market-based solutions to capacity problems. This strategy also involves the construction of 10 new airports but would give state and local authorities responsibility for increasing airport capacity. Estimated federal financing: $38 billion to $75 billion. -Develop larger subsonic jets of up to 1,000 seats for heavily traveled routes, supersonic commercial transports for international routes, and short-haul aircraft and miniports at suburban locations for transfer purposes. Develop new surface transport systems to absorb some of the 200-to-500 mile intercity traffic now handled by aircraft. The estimated price tag in federal, local and private funding: between $50 billion and $100 billion by 2020 and perhaps $125 billion to $165 billion more by 2040. The report stressed that no matter what is done, congestion and delay cannot be eliminated simply or permanently, especially when weather and airspace congestion are taken into account. ``The best that can be achieved is a higher degree of efficiency that reduces (congestion and delay) to an acceptable level at an affordable cost,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Hits Central Philippines; No Casualties
DOC.TEXT: A moderately strong earthquake shook the central Philippines Saturday, officials said. There were no reports of casualties or major damage. Seismologists said the earthquake, which measured 5.7 on the Richter scale, was centered below the Sulu Sea, about 78 miles southwest of Dumaguete City on Negros island. The earthquake's epicenter was about 410 miles south of Manila. Raymundo Punongbayan, director of the Philippines Institute of Volcanology and Seismology, said the earthquake lasted only a few seconds and was hardly felt in nearby islands. In July, an earthquake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale hit the northern Philippines, leaving more than 1,600 people dead and wide areas devastated. The open-ended Richter scale measures energy released by an earthquake as measured on a seismograph. A quake measuring 5.7 can cause severe damage if it occurs in or near a town center.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Lay Plans For Homeland; U.S. Buildup Tops 200,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with conference beginning, statement by Iraqi foreign minister; Edits to trim; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Kuwaitis gathered in Saudi Arabia today to discuss the future of their occupied homeland. In Washington, officials said the U.S. buildup facing Iraqi invading forces had surpassed 200,000 troops. At the United Nations, U.S. officials joined the rest of the Security Council in condemning Israel's security forces for killing 19 Palestinians in rioting in Jerusalem earlier this week. Diplomats said the United States had not exercised its veto power over the resolution for fear of alienating Arab nations whose support it needs against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. There were new indications that the United States might launch an attack on Iraqi forces. Pentagon sources in Washington said Friday a Marine amphibious force was planning a practice assault on the Arabian coast as a trial run for a possible U.S. invasion of Kuwait. And a French magazine said U.S. military officials have drawn up an offensive plan against Iraq. More than 1,000 Kuwaiti exiles from all walks of life gathered in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia for the three-day Kuwaiti People's Conference, which began today. Hundreds of young men and women demonstrated outside Jiddah's Conference Palace, raising banners of support for the emir and shouting slogans calling for the liberation of Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug 2. ``This conference is the most eloquent response to your enemy who usurped your homeland,'' said the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, in his opening speech. The crown prince and prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, also addressed the opening session and promised democracy would increase in Kuwait after liberation from occupation by troops loyal to Iraq's Saddam Hussein. More than 200,000 U.S. troops have been deployed against Iraq, the Pentagon said. It has refused to say, however, exactly how many U.S. soldiers, sailors, airmen, and marines are in Saudi Arabia or on warships in the region. There are an estimated 430,000 Iraqi troops in Kuwait and southern Iraq. The U.N. resolution approved in New York ``condemns ... the acts of violence committed by the Israeli security forces resulting in injuries and loss of human life.'' The Palestine Liberation Organization had supported a harsher version of the resolution. The U.S. vote in favor of the resolution was a rare departure from its usual practice of defending Israel, from censure in the Council. The United States, however, did not want to allienate its Arab allies, including Egypt and Syria, joining the multinational effort against iraq. There were indications the United States might be growing impatient with the U.N.-ordered economic embargo on Iraq. Pentagon sources announced a practice assault on the Arabian coast. And the French news magazine, L'Express, reported that U.S. military officials have drawn up plans to free Kuwait and defeat Iraq in a four-day attack in November that would destroy Saddam's armed forces. L'Express said U.S. planners estimated the offensive might cost 20,000 American lives, but gave no estimate for dead of other nations. The magazine said it obtained an outline of the plan from an unidentified aide to U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney. U.S. officials refused comment on the reports. James R. Schlesinger, a former defense secretary and one-time CIA director, and Joseph J. Sisco, former undersecretary of state, both said Friday they consider the likelihood of Middle East military action to be ``50-50.'' They spoke at a news conference in Hot Springs, Va., after a discussion of the Persian Gulf crisis with members of the Business Council, a group of top American corporate leaders. In Jordan, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said today the crisis had entered a new phase of ``reconsideration'' of stands in another indication of a shift in Baghdad's hard-line attitude toward Kuwait. Iraq, meanwhile, said it might stop Soviet detainees from returning home if they have knowledge of Iraqi weapons systems. The evacuation began a week ago and Iraq had promised to let at least 2,000 Soviets leave. Defense sources said Cheney planned to ask Soviet officials next week for intelligence on the Iraqi military, armed largely by the Soviet Union and France. The Soviets have condemned their former ally over the invasion. A Pan Am jetliner with 257 evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait - the first U.S.-chartered flight in nearly three weeks - landed Friday at Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina. The passengers - mostly women and children - included 123 Americans, six Canadians and others of unknown nationality.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Killed In Continuing Violence
DOC.TEXT: Five villagers were killed in a gunbattle between government troops and a band of guerrillas trying to free their arrested comrades, military officials said Saturday. Five Tamil rebel captives also were killed escaping from the patrol, which was ambushed at Attapallam village in the eastern Ampara district on Friday, the officials said. The patrol was taking the seven captives to locate a rebel hideout, the officials said on condition of anonymity. Two rebels fled during the shootout. Troops combing the village afterward discovered the dead civilians. In a separate incident, a soldier was shot dead in an ambush by rebels in the eastern Batticaloa district, the officials added. At least 14,000 people have been killed since rebels from the minority Tamil community started a separatist campaign in 1983, claiming they were victims of discrimination by the majority Sinhalese.

DOC.HEAD: President Pardons Men Jailed for Anti-Government Tracts
DOC.TEXT: President Gnassingbe Eyadema has pardoned two men whose jail sentences for distributing anti-government tracts triggered rioting in which four people were killed, state radio said Saturday. Doglo Agbelenko and Logo Dossouvi were sentenced Oct. 5 to five years' jail after a court found them guilty of distributing ``false and defamatory tracts aimed at inciting the army to revolt.'' Hundreds of their supporters went on a rampage, attacking police stations in the capital and setting government vehicles on fire. Security forces opened fire. A government statement said three people were killed by bullets and a fourth was beaten to death. Protesters had demanded a multiparty democracy, following a pattern that has swept much of Africa this year. Eyadema decided Friday to free the jailed men, national radio said. It gave no reason for the decision by the president, who seized power in a 1967 coup and instituted a one-party state.

DOC.HEAD: Prowling the Hallways With Lobbyists: Must Be Budget Time
DOC.TEXT: It's party time, sort of, in the dimly lighted marble hallway outside the House Ways and Means Committee hearing room. But nobody's having much fun. They're clutching notebooks and documents, not drinks and munchies. And most of their causes are lost ones, whether they're trying to prevent luxury tax increases, protect Medicare or cut the tax rate on capital gains. ``I don't think anybody in this hallway is doing very well. With a $500 billion deficit-reduction package, everybody is going to get hit,'' said a young man with glasses. Ah, if that were the only problem facing the lobbyists who have been camping outside committee rooms for hours on end, monitoring each incremental step of this year's tumultuous budget process; hoping against hope for one last moment with some key lawmaker or aide. They're bored. They're lonely. They're stretched thin. They've got image trouble. ``We're sick of each other,'' said a hospital lobbyist gesturing to two colleagues. ``I haven't seen my fiance in days,'' another woman said. ``Midterms start Monday,'' adds a young man studying for his master's degree in international management. ``We've been tarred as fat cats,'' laments Ed Hatcher, senior manager of tax policy for the American Electronics Association. His group wants - guess what - a capital gains tax cut. But only a teeny one that wouldn't hurt the deficit much and would help strung-out entrepreneurs trying to create ``the Apple computers of tomorrow.'' ``I personally think they should go easy on Medicare beneficiaries,'' Hatcher said. Gucci Gulch, named for the soft designer leather worn by the tax lobbyists who often congregate there, is a wide swath of hallway across the front of the Longworth House Office Building. Committee Democrats were talking about capital gains taxes and Medicare on Friday, and dozens of lobbyists had decided they had to be on hand. They leaned against the marble walls, sat in stairwells, even perched in wall niches just big enough for two. They filled the air with esoteric references to asset reversions, corporate interest disallowances, ESOPs and R&D extenders. ``It really is sort of a social event,'' said Hatcher. ``The trouble is, it's not terribly productive. I come up when they're very close to reaching a decision. Otherwise, you're better off in your office.'' Many of the old hands at Gucci Gulch agree. ``I promise you a lot of the people are sitting out here in the hall billing hours,'' said bank and real estate lobbyist Jim Skinner, a 14-year veteran of the process. He added hastily: ``I'm waiting for a phone.'' At this late stage, particularly with the political stakes so high for Democrats, Republicans and the White House, most of those haunting the hallways admit that it's too late to work their will on anyone. Now they'll settle for information - even rumors and hearsay in a pinch. ``Staying ahead of the information curve is basically my job,'' said Dan Harrington, an assistant at a law firm. ``It gets exciting. You get caught up in the paper chase, the fun of getting something before it's released.'' Budget-watching is just about the only thing the hall-dwellers have done for the past two weeks. ``It's seasonal work, like farmworkers,'' said Tom Nickels, director of the Washington office of the American College of Emergency Physicians. The group helped win a 3.5 percent Medicare fee increase and he's trying to make sure it survives each transmutation of each budget bill. Venture capitalists and homebuilders and Hatcher, meanwhile, watch the capital gains tax cut fall in and out of favor on a daily and sometimes hourly basis. ``There just comes a point where you have to look at the process with a sense of humor,'' said Hatcher. ``If you don't, you really will drive yourself crazy.''

DOC.HEAD: Two More Suspected Spies Arrested
DOC.TEXT: The interrogation of a former top East German agent has led to the arrest of two more people suspected of spying for the former Communist secret service, authorities said Saturday. Two high-ranking officials in the counterespionage agency working in the Lower Saxony state were arrested late Friday, state authorities said. The latest arrests brought to 14 the number of suspected former East German spies apprehended in one week. The series of arrests began after Klaus Kuron, a top official in the former West German counterespionage service, turned himself in over the weekend and began cooperation with investigators. Kuron has admitted that he ha also worked as an agent for the now defunct East German intelligence for eight years. The latest two officials to be arrested knew the names of all double agents and could have caused serious damage by their revelations to the East German secret service, according to a statement by the Lower Saxony state Interior Ministry. East Germany had a broad spy network in West Germany, but the agents were left without a country when the two states merged on Oct. 3. The Bonn government has appealed to former East German spies to turn themselves in. Officials say up to 8,000 former spies may be on the loose.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0488 to fix writethru designator
Leading German Minister Wounded by Gunman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th pvs, `The West...' to DELETE incorrect reference to December elections. Pickup 15th pvs, `Schaeuble, 48...'
DOC.TEXT: A lone assailant has shot and seriously wounded Germany's top law enforcement official, but officials say the attacker had a history of mental problems and that terrorists were not involved. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, considered a possible future candidate for chancellor, was in stable condition today after doctors removed a bullet from his spine, officials said. He was shot late Friday at a campaign meeting at a restaurant in Oppenau, about 120 miles south of Frankfurt. Television repors said a security guard was also seriously wounded when he threw himself in front of Schaeuble. After Friday's attack, Schaeuble was hospitalized in Freiburg and underwent five hours of surgery. A medical bulletin described Schaeuble's condition today as ``satisfactory and stable.'' Interior Ministry spokesman Roland Bachmeier said earlier that Schaeuble was ``seriously wounded'' but that his life was not in danger. A ministry statement said Schaeuble was hit by two bullets. Witnesses reported that three shots were fired. There were widely varying accounts of where Schaeuble had been struck, but most reports said it was in the area of the head and neck. A doctor who helped treat Schaeuble told ARD television that he had been hit in the jaw and chest. ARD quoted a Munich-based journalist at the scene as saying Schaeuble had bled heavily but could speak before he was rushed to the hospital. The journalist said the suspect had seemed ``disturbed.'' Prosecutor Werner Botz identified the gunman as Dieter Kaufmann. Botz said the 37-year-old gunman is mentally disturbed. The man told investigators he had felt threatened by the ``terror of the state'' and had decided six months ago to take revenge by shooting Schaeuble, according to Botz. In Bonn, Interior Ministry spokeman Willi Hausmann said there was no evidence of terrorist background. Direct violent attacks aimed at top politicians were rare in postwar German history, though top businessmen were prime terrorist targets. Friday's attack was the second time in six months a top German leader has been wounded during a public appearance. In April, a disturbed woman drove a knife into the neck of Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democratic candidate for chancellor, at an April campaign rally. The West German candidate was badly hurt but soon resumed his campaign for Dec. 2 national elections. Schaeuble, 48, was named interior minister in April 1989. Overseeing police and security nationwide, he is said to be one of Germany's most heavily protected politicians. In recent months, he guided the difficult, whirlwind talks that led to the historic German unification on Oct. 3. The interior minister has been mentioned recently as a possible successor to Kohl when the Christian Democratic leader decides to retire. Many Germans recall Schaeuble's emotional announcement to Parliament on Nov. 30 that Alfred Herrhausen, the nation's top banker as chief of the powerful Deutsche Bank, had been killed in a terrorist bomb blast.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for Release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
Study: Defense Contractors Adapt to Drop in Business
With BC-Star Wars Chief, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Faced with the inevitable decline in military spending, defense contractors are adapting to a sharp drop in business by using existing programs to help laid-off workers, a study released Saturday said. The report by the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency found that the impact of a scaled-back defense budget will affect individual companies and some communities, but nationwide the impact will be minimal. ``We estimate that even if defense spending were reduced at an annual rate of 2 percent for as long as five years, job loss would be roughly 68,000 defense-related workers per year,'' according to the study by the government agency. The agency found that programs in place through the Job Training Partnership Act, the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, as well as assistance provided by the Defense Department's Office of Economic Adjustment, are enough to help defense workers who lose their jobs. Some members of Congress have pushed for additional programs to assist employees and communities affected by lower defense spending. The House-passed defense bills include $200 million for existing programs and provides funds to affected communities. ``The economic effects of future reductions are unlikely to require legislation to convert the defense industry to non-defense activities, and that conversion directed by government mandate would not be helpful,'' the study said. It did recommend, however, that Congress ease the pain for workers by reducing the budget deficit, which would lead to lower interest rates; improve conditions for investment by adjustments in the tax system and encourage the use of commercial products in defense buying. The report found that states heavily dependent on defense contracts - California, Texas, New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Virginia - will feel the brunt of significant cuts in defense spending. However, some states will be able to use the adjustment assistance ``while others with large, varied and vibrant economies such as California and New York would probably not require it,'' the report said. The purpose of the report, which was provided to Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., was to determine the effect of U.S.-Soviet arms control agreements and the resulting cutbacks in defense spending. The study found that savings resulting from such agreements will probably be limited during the years immediately after the signing of arms control treaties.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Towns Skirt Repeal of Apartheid Law
DOC.TEXT: For 37 years, blacks have been legally banned from the sparkling blue waters of South Africa's public swimming pools. That's supposed to change Monday with the end of the Separate Amenities Act, a major apartheid law that segregated bathrooms, swimming pools, libraries and other public facilities. But if Sasolburg officials have their way, few if any blacks will join white residents in the town's municipal pools. A new local law takes effect Monday that allows only town residents, most of them white, to use the public pools. The tens of thousands of blacks forced by apartheid laws to live in townships outside the city will still be barred. Similar measures aimed at restricting use of facilities to whites have been reported in other towns controlled by the pro-apartheid Conservative Party. The legal maneuvering by right-wing whites illustrates the depth of South Africa's internal divisions. President F.W. de Klerk has pledged to end apartheid, but many whites are unprepared to share their daily life with blacks. ``Scrapping apartheid laws is one thing; ending race prejudice and eradicating apartheid's deep roots will take a little longer,'' said The Star, an anti-apartheid newspaper in Johannesburg. Little will actually change with Monday's formal repeal of the Separate Amenities Act. All major cities have wiped out the so-called petty apartheid. Last Christmas, de Klerk opened the few remaining segregated beaches to all races. Symbolically, though, the governing National Party is lifting one of the last barriers protecting white privilege. De Klerk has promised to abolish all discriminatory legislation, including laws prohibiting blacks from residing on or owning property in much of the country. Those measures, along with the ones that segregate public schools and the political system, are the major remaining apartheid laws. The Separate Amenities Act became law in 1953 and was repealed by Parliament in June. Local communities were given until Oct. 15 to comply. In places like Sasolburg, a conservative town about 50 miles south of Johannesburg in the country's heartland, many white residents oppose the government's actions. ``I think if they open everything up, the standard of living is going to drop,'' said Trevor Engelbrecht, 43, a taxi driver. Under the new Sasolburg law, the small number of black employees living in white households or worker hostels inside the city of 27,000 can use the pools. But not blacks living in the adjacent township of Zamdela, which like most black areas has few recreational facilities. ``You must take some sort of a measure to prevent overcrowding,'' said Kim LeRoux, head of the town's community and development services. He conceded that the end of whites-only regulations Monday prompted the new law. Several blacks interviewed on the town's streets were unaware the Separate Amenities Act would end Monday.
