Immediately after harvest, market prices are lowest, making that gap wider than later in the year.

DOC.HEAD: Compromise Resolution Condemned By Both Sides
DOC.TEXT: Israel said Saturday that a U.N. resolution condemning it for the deaths of 19 Palestinians was unfair, and the Palestine Liberation Organization said it didn't go far enough. The predictable reactions came a day after a rare unanimous vote against Israel by the 15-member Security Council. The United States, long a defender of Israel in the council, departed from its usual stance to join in the censure. ``This is an incident which never should have happened,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering said Saturday of last week's killings on the Temple Mount. Malaysia's ambassador, Rasali Ismail, predicted that ``Beginning from now, Israel's protective umbrella will begin to be steadily removed.'' In the resolution, which was passed just before midnight Friday, the Council also asked Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send a team of envoys to Israel to investigate the slayings last week on the Temple Mount. The compromise resolution was worked out after five days of marathon negotiations that pitted the United States against the non-aligned members of the council, who supported the PLO. The PLO urged its allies to support a resolution that would have sent a Council team to investigate the killings, as a first step toward giving the Council a direct role in protecting Palestinians in the occupied territories. But the United States let it be known it would veto that resolution. A U.S. veto would have shattered America's fragile coalition with moderate Arab states that support the U.N. economic embargo on Iraq and have joined the multinational military effort to counter new aggression by Baghdad. Moderate Arabs told the council in speeches last week that Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which it seized in the 1967 Middle East war, is as illegal as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Some Western diplomats said privately that they believed the PLO aimed to force a veto from the United States and thus split the anti-Saddam alliance. ``The Security Council tonight grieves for those lost and injured, condemns the acts of violence - both provocative and reactive - and reaffirms the obligations and responsibilities,'' that Israel has to protect the safety and rights of Palestinians, Pickering said Saturday. Last Monday's rioting in Jerusalem began when Arabs on the Temple Mount threw rocks down onto Jews praying below at the Western wall, Judaism's holiest site. Police moved in to disperse the Arabs, at first using tear gas and rubber bullets, then live ammunition. In addition to the 19 Palestinians confirmed dead, 140 Arabs were wounded and 30 Jews were injured. The U.N. resolution ``condemns especially the acts of violence committed by the Israeli security forces resulting in injuries and loss of human life.'' It also refers to the injury of ``innocent worshipers'' in an implied criticism of the Palestinian rock-throwers. The PLO had fought to have that phrase removed. In Tunisia, a member of the PLO's executive committee, Yasser Abd Rabou, said Saturday the resolution was ``insufficient'' even though it condemned the actions of Israeli police. ``Unfortunately, we are expecting Israel to continue oppressing the Palestinian people,'' said the PLO's U.N. observer, M. Nasser al-Kidwa. A spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israel's Cabinet would have to decide whether to accept a U.N. investigating team, which is to report back to the Security Council by Oct. 24. The spokesman, Avi Pazner, said the U.N. action was ``without any reason or justification'' since the police opened fire only after the stoning. Israel's ambassador to the United Nations, Johanan Bein, said the resolution ``fails to condemn the cause of the tragic events in Jerusalem - an unprovoked Arab attack on Jewish worshipers.'' ``It is also regrettable that the Security Council fell into the trap laid by Saddam Hussein and his PLO supporters, who inspired the riots in order to divert attention from Iraq's aggression in the (Persian) Gulf,'' he said. Israeli politicians on both right and left have said security forces had advance warning of the riot, which they said was planned, and failed to prepare adequately. France co-sponsored the U.N. resolution with Canada, Britain, the Soviet Union, Zaire, Ivory Coast and Finland.

DOC.HEAD: That Was No Cab, That Was My Car!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT name of cab company to Crescent sted Century.
DOC.TEXT: A man was waiting for a bus when he saw a familiar car roll by. It was his 1980 Chevrolet Caprice, the one stolen 11 days earlier. Not even a customizing job that put a taxi light on the roof and painted ``Crescent Cab Co.'' on the side could fool Bogdan Szetela. ``I think that was my car going by,'' a disbelieving Szetela told a woman at the bus stop last weekend. ``And she said, `What are you going to do about it?''' he recalled Friday. ``That kind of ignited my brain cells to work.'' Szetela, 27, hailed another cab and gave chase. Several blocks away, he jumped out of the cab and ``nonchalantly'' got into the back of his own car, his heart pounding. ``I had to control myself,'' he said. ``I started chatting with the guy, asked him where he's from and so forth - he's from Mount Airy - nice weather we're having, isn't it? ``All the while, I'm checking out my car. There's a different stereo and stuff, a meter, a radar detector, the works. Oh, and he had a new steering wheel, a Monte Carlo. I'm saying to myself, `You so-and-so, how could you do this to my car?''' Szetela said. His plan: find a police officer. He directed the cabbie to South Street, where police frequently patrol, and spied one. ``I lunged from the back seat, put the car in park and grabbed the keys,'' he said. ``I hopped out of car and told the cop, `That's my car!''' Police weren't convinced - the identification number was switched - until Szetela told them he left blue towels and a chess set in the trunk. ``They popped the trunk, and sure enough,'' he said. Checkmate. It took another four days after the Oct. 6 incident to get the car back. Crescent Cab says its drivers operate their own cars; police are investigating but haven't arrested the driver. ``This is a first down here,'' said Detective Paul McKelvie. ``Sometimes God works in strange ways,'' said Szetela.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Foreign Minister Due in Washington for Talks Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: The first Vietnamese leader to visit here since the Vietnam War will hold talks in Washington this week, officials said Saturday. Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach will meet Wednesday at the Pentagon with Gen. John Vessey, former head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and now the president's special negotiator on U.S. servicemen missing in action from the Vietnam War. Also attending the meeting will be State and Defense department representatives, and Anne Mills Griffiths, who heads a coalition of MIA families, said officials who asked not to be named. Thach's visit is another in a series of steps taken this past year by the administration toward normalizing relations between the two countries. Two weeks ago, Secretary of State James Baker met with Thach at the United Nations in New York, the highest-level talks between the sides since the war ended in April 1975. The administration insists the only agenda for Thach's visit is to move along the accounting for an estimated 1,700 American servicemen whose fate is unknown. The administration says restoration of relations would depend on Vietnam's cooperation in the MIA issue and in resolving the civil war in Cambodia. Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia in 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge, has withdrawn most of its 140,000 troops but must still sign a peace treaty being worked out for signature in Paris. Vietnam's communist leadership hopes the Washington visit will enhance the prospects for U.S. aid to the impoverished nation and help end its international isolation. The government still rejects democracy and represses opposition, but it has moved the economy away from the failed communist model to a free-market system, which has dismantled collective farming and improved urban living standards. Thach will also meet with members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee at their invitation. Baker agreed to lift the usual travel restrictions on Vietnamese diplomats, which limit them to a 25-mile radius of New York City, so Thach could travel here.

DOC.HEAD: Menotti Quits as Director of Spoleto U.S.A., for Now
DOC.TEXT: Composer Gian Carlo Menotti has quit as artistic director of Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in a dispute over control of the event he created, but his decision may not be final. The 80-year-old founder of the annual festival said Saturday he will stay on if there are changes in the board of directors. And the board, which didn't accept his resignation when it was submitted Friday, is hoping differences can be smoothed over. ``I no longer feel it is my festival, and this has been my life for 15 years,'' Menotti said from his Manhattan hotel room. ``I feel a bit lonely among them (the board members) ... I'm treated like the clerk.'' Menotti is best known in this country for his opera of the Christmas story, ``Amahl and the Night Visitors.'' In 1977 he founded the international arts festival in Charleston, S.C., two decades after founding The Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, in an effort to bring together European and U.S. culture. ``I'm not going to go on in an organization where people stand against me on artistic matters. I must feel my leadership is accepted,'' Menotti said. Board Chairman Ross Markwardt said: ``Frankly, I'm going to let the whole thing cool for a few days. Then I'll speak with his agent, and try to open a dialogue that can result in some kind of agreement.'' Menotti acknowledged he could change his mind, though he sounded resolute in his decision. ``They did not accept my resignation, but as far as I am concerned I'm still resigned,'' Menotti said. One issue between Menotti and the board involves an $800,000 conceptual art exhibit planned for the 1991 festival. Menotti opposes it. Menotti is in the second year of a three-year contract as artistic director. Markwardt said it was unlikely Menotti would be compelled to finish the term. ``I can't imagine that this board would have the stomach to do anything to harm an 80-year-old patriarch who founded this festival,'' Markwardt said. Menotti said he was meeting privately Saturday with festival general manager Nigel Redden, who declined to comment about the flap. Markwardt said he hoped this kind of private approach would help ease tensions. ``It is much more appropriate that this not be turned into a business arrangement, given the long personal relationships that exist,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Defeated, But Hrawi Still Faces Big Problems
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In crushing rebel Gen. Michel Aoun, President Elias Hrawi may have eliminated a main obstacle to a peace plan for Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. But his troubles are far from over. Hrawi can claim that his authority now extends over much of his ravaged country. But he depends on Syrian muscle, and goodwill, to maintain his authority. That was underlined by the Syrian firepower needed to hammer Aoun into submission. The Syrians, for their part, have a history of getting rid of allies who don't do as they're told. Hrawi faces a tough time ahead in consolidating his control and implementing the 1989 peace agreement, which is still viewed with misgivings by many Moslems. Hrawi declared in a radio address Saturday that ``a new dawn for the republic was born'' after Aoun fled the presidential palace in Baabda, where he had his headquarters in an underground bunker. That could well be. But the Syrians still control 70 percent of Lebanon. They have said they will withdraw from Beirut and other cities to the Bekaa Valley in east Lebanon in the coming months. But they may never leave Lebanon altogether unless there is an Arab-Israeli peace settlement. The Syrians see Lebanon, which was part of Syria under French rule until 1943, as vital to their defensive strategy against Israel. The Israelis occupy a border strip in south Lebanon, and they won't withdraw while there are Palestinians and other Moslem guerrillas operating in the southern panhandle. There are also several thousand Iranian Revolutionary Guards, and various Palestinian factions, based in Syrian-policed east Beirut. Getting rid of them will not be easy. The Arab League-brokered peace accord agreed on in Taif, Saudi Arabia, provides for the traditionally dominant Christians sharing power equally with the Moslem majority. Hrawi last month formally signed political reforms into law. But the Druse and Shiite Moslems still do not think they are being treated fairly and many Maronites, the dominant Christian sect, are loath to see their traditional privileges stripped away. The Shiites are also deeply divided between among themselves. The Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, has been feuding for the last three years with the more secular, Syrian-armed Amal militia. More than 1,000 people have been killed in the power struggle for control of the Shiite community. Iran and Syria, its main Arab ally, recently brokered a new cease-fire, but there are still scores to settle and an new flare-up is more likely than not. The 200,000-strong Druse, whose stronghold is in the Chouf Mountains overlooking Beirut, fear they will be squeezed out by the biggest sects. The Palestine Liberation Organization, which carved out a stronghold in south Lebanon after it was driven out of Beirut bastions by Amal two years ago, also is not likely to pay much heed to Hrawi. Under the peace plan, the militias are supposed to be disarmed and disbanded. But for much of the civil war, they have basically done what they wanted and carved out their own cantons. Disarming them will not be easy. Only Syrian firepower keeps the lid on. Without it, Hrawi's poorly armed forces would find it difficult to take on the veteran street fighters. And even if political stability can be restored, Hrawi faces the awesome task of rebuilding the shattered economy. Much of the infrastructure has been destroyed or damaged, particularly in fighting triggered by Aoun's actions. Under the peace plan, the Saudis were slated to bankroll much of the reconstruction. But Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has meant the Saudis are too involved confronting Saddam Hussein and underwriting a multinational force to bother about the Lebanese. Economists estimate Hrawi will need $21 billion for reconstruction. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Ed Blanche is Middle East News Editor for The Associated Press, based in Nicosia. He has covered the region since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Gov't Commander
DOC.TEXT: Rebel gunmen killed a government militia commander and seven of his men in a raid on a mosque in Afghanistan's western state of Herat, state-run radio said Saturday. Kabul Radio, in its English-language broadcast, said at least 22 people were injured, including a member of the Iranian Consulate in Herat. Gunmen belonging to the Moslem resistance fighting the Soviet-backed government in Kabul stormed the Blue Mosque Friday and killed militia commander Zahim Ahmad and his men as they were praying, the radio said. ``Extremists launched an inhuman and criminal attack on the mosque and martyred eight people, including commander Zahim Ahmad, and wounded 22 people,'' said the radio, monitored in Islamabad. Midia, the Pakistan-based news agency of the guerrillas' government-in-exile, confirmed rebel fighters had killed Ahmad and other ``notorious Communists'' but denied the attack occurred in the mosque. ``The mosque was not damaged. The ambush took place on a road north of the mosque,'' the agency said. The U.S.-backed guerrillas, known as mujahedeen or Islamic holy warriors, have been fighting for 12 years to unseat the Communist-style government in Kabul. Ahmad, the leader of a militia force of about 5,000, was a guerrilla fighter before he signed a non-aggression pact and switched to the government's side three years ago. Ahmad wielded considerable influence with the provincial government in Herat, which borders Iran and the Soviet Union. He had been critical of the mujahedeen leaders based in Pakistan. Diplomatic and guerrilla sources in Pakistan say Ahmad's murder could be linked to inter-militia rivalries or to avenge the murder of another militia commander who was killed in a similar incident in Herat in August. No one claimed responsibility for that attack.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Angered by U.N. Resolution
With AM-UN-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel was angered by the Security Council's condemnation of the killing of 19 Palestinians but has not decided whether to reject a U.N. investigating mission, a government spokesman said Saturday. The council resolution Friday night condemned the ``violence committed by the Israeli security forces'' in Monday's riot at the Temple Mount. U.S. approval of the resolution appeared to mark a shift in its policy toward Israel. Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yizhak Shamir, said the resolution was ``without any reason or justification'' since police opened fire after a stoning attack by Palestinians that injured more than 30 Jewish worshipers and police. He said that he did not know if the government would accept the resolution's call for emissaries of the U.N. secretary-general to investigate the deaths. ``I can't say if we will accept this mission. The Cabinet will have to decide,'' Pazner said. The resolution would be discussed at a Cabinet meeting Sunday, he said. Shamir said earlier that a U.N. investigation of the rioting on the Temple Mount would infringe on Israel's sovereignty over Jerusalem. The Mount, holy to both Moslems and Jews, is in Arab east Jerusalem, which Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East War and then annexed. ``Jerusalem is the pupil in the eye of the Jewish people. I think it would be a real crime ... to allow anyone to damage the sovereignty of a Hebrew Jerusalem,'' Shamir said in a radio interview broadcast Saturday but taped before the Security Council decision. The council's resolution did not specifically mention a U.N. mission to Jerusalem, but referred only to a visit to ``the region.'' Nafez Essala, head of the Palestinian Center of Nonviolent Studies in Jerusalem, praised the council's resolution but had reservations about its real worth. ``If Israel says they won't accept the U.N. delegation, will the U.N. impose an embargo or send troops to force Israel to accept it? I don't think so,'' Essala said. Pazner said that the U.N. condemnation of Israel for the Palestinian deaths - 19, 20 or even more than 20 according to some versions - played into the hands of another of Israel's strongest enemies, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The Foreign Ministry issued a reaction to the Security Council vote that warned the resolution could further inflame the Middle East. ``One can only hope that the Arab extremists who formented these riots will not view this resolution as an internationally sanctioned license to further violence,'' the statement said. Questions have been raised in Jerusalem about whether the rioting was planned by Palestinians or a spontaneous reaction to rumors that a group of Jewish zealots was planning a march on the Temple Mount. Israel officials first said Palestinians planned in advance to hurl a barrage of rocks at Jewish worshipers below the Mount at the Wailing Wall, Judaism's holiest site. But Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner later said he believed the riot was spontaneous. The rioting was the bloodiest single incident in Jerusalem since Israel captured the city's Arab sector from Jordan in 1967, as well as in the 34-month Palestinian uprising. At least 760 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the revolt against occupation. An additional 278 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-eight Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Wins $10 Million McDonald's Prize, Then Gets Disqualified
LaserPhoto DT2
DOC.TEXT: A woman named as the winner of a $10 million prize in a McDonald's-NBC contest feels she got burned - she was disqualified hours later because her daughter is a McDonald's cashier. Instead of heading for a vacation in Puerto Rico, Thelma and Charles Bellows are visiting an attorney. A McDonald's spokesman said Saturday the couple apparently misunderstood the rules. ``It's been two day of no sleep,'' Bellows said in a telephone interview from his home in Kawkawlin, 120 miles northwest of Detroit. ``We were honest about it. For $10 million, we could have given the ticket to someone to claim it. But we were honest.'' Mrs. Bellows, 49, was named on national TV Friday morning as the winner in the ``McMillions on NBC.'' She received the winning ticket, which was drawn Thursday, when she bought a meal at a McDonald's restaurant in Auburn, Mich., where one of her six children, Charlene Saunders, works. The couple spent Friday in Detroit with representatives from McDonald's, taping a commercial that was to air Friday night. They planned to buy a new house and furniture, and take a trip to the Caribbean. ``I just can't believe it,'' Mrs. Bellows said in a statement Friday. ``It's still a dream and it doesn't seem real yet.'' At about 6 p.m., the dream fizzled. McDonald's told her she was ineligible. Bellows said they told the contest auditors about their daughter earlier in the day, but were told it didn't matter because she does not live with them. However, Charles Rubner, vice president at the McDonald's Corp. headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., said the auditors were unaware Mrs. Bellows had a relative working at McDonald's when they verified the winning ticket. ``It is clear that Mrs. Bellows did not understand the rules that an employee's family is ineligible,'' Rubner said in an interview. ``When she was asked if she had any immediate family employed by McDonald's, she apparently misunderstood and said no. When we learned otherwise, we told her. ``We're terribly sorry that the misunderstanding occurred,'' he said. Rubner said the McDonald's rule about employees' families is not a federal or state requirement, but a standard regulation in company contests. In New York, NBC spokesman Curt Block said the network backed McDonald's decision. Mrs. Bellows was too upset to talk to reporters Saturday. ``We still feel that we should get the winnings,'' said Bellows, co-owner of RCL Construction Co., in Sanford. ``Our chances of winning were the same as anybody else's.'' The couple said they have contacted an attorney, but did not elaborate. The jackpot rolled over to $11 million for Friday night's contest. The game card with the winning number is announced each night on an NBC prime-time program. The promotion began Sept. 24 and ends Oct. 22. The Bellows were offered a consolation of dinner and accommodation at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Dearborn Friday night, but they turned it down. ``We figured it would be better to just come home,'' Bellows said.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcast Pioneer Douglas Edwards Dead at 73
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: Pioneering journalist Douglas Edwards, a World War II radio correspondent who became the nation's first network television anchorman with CBS, died Saturday morning at his Florida home. He was 73. Edwards, who spent all but 10 of his 56-year broadcasting career with CBS News, died of cancer in Sarasota, Fla., CBS News announced. He retired from the network in April 1988. Forty years earlier, then-CBS President Frank Stanton tapped Edwards to anchor its nationwide TV news broadcast, titled ``Douglas Edwards with the News.'' He held the job for 14 years before surrendering the seat to Walter Cronkite. The program won a Peabody Award for best television news in 1956, and the show - which began airing coast to coast five years earlier - became the world's largest single news medium with 34 millions viewers. ``Because he was a pioneer and achieved so much as a professional, Douglas Edwards is in the pantheon of news broadcasters,'' said CBS News anchorman Dan Rather. Don Hewitt, executive producer of ``60 Minutes,'' was an associate director on Edward's nightly newscast. ``Along with Dave Garroway and Ed Sullivan and Jack Webb and other pioneers, Doug ushered in the television era. ... Whatever is good and right about TV news today, Doug Edwards can claim a lion's share of the credit,'' Hewitt said. Edwards already had a decade of experience when he joined CBS News in 1942. He became part of Edward R. Murrow's legendary London radio staff as World War II drew to an end, and also served as Paris bureau chief. In 1948, he joined Murrow and Quincy Howe in CBS' acclaimed radio coverage of the presidential conventions. ``We did very well, the three of us, on those conventions,'' he recalled later. ``Afterward, CBS asked me to go into television, and I did it with some fear and trepidation, not because I was nervous about being on television, I had done quite a bit of it, but radio was the power, and I was pretty young at the time.'' He made the transition smoothly, retired colleague Eric Sevareid recalled Saturday in Washington. ``He was one of the very few who set the standards of objectivity and cool-headedness for the anchor position. ... He never tried to bend the news. When TV came along, with all its emphasis on personalities, he was never one of those who tried to act the news,'' said Sevareid. When he gave his last TV broadcast in April 1988, Edwards said: ``A deep bow of gratitude, love and respect to the men and women of CBS News and to the company for which they stand. To you out there, thank you for honoring me with your presence in my audience.'' Edwards was born July 14, 1917, in Ada, Okla. He began his broadcasting career at the age of 15 on a radio station in Troy, Ala. He attended the University of Alabama, Emory University and the University of Georgia, combining his studies with work at various radio stations. Later, he worked for radio station WXYZ in Detroit, along with another up-and-coming broadcaster, Mike Wallace, now of ``60 Minutes.'' In addition to his Peabody, Edwards received the Lowell Thomas Award from Marist College in 1986 and the Paul White Award from the Radio and Television News Directors Association in 1988. He is survived by his wife, May; three children from a previous marriage, two stepsons, and four grandchildren. Funeral services will be Wednesday at the Church of the Palms in Sarasota.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Visits School Where Children Died in War
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Iraqi children burned effigies of President Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher outside their embassies in Baghdad on Saturday, the Iraqi News Agency said. The children also burned British and American flags and delivered letters to both missions protesting ``the economic siege imposed by the United States and its allies against the Iraqi children.'' The protests occurred on Iraq's National Children's Day, which commemorates an Oct. 13, 1987 Iranian missile attack on a Baghdad primary school that killed 39 children during the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Saturday visited the school, located in Baghdad's Dora district, according to the new agency, monitored in Nicosia. The protest letters said that depriving children of food, medicine and vaccinations under the U.N. economic embargo on Iraq violated international human rights agreements and declarations on the rights of children. The U.N. imposed the trade embargo to force Baghdad out of Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2 and then annexed. ``We call upon you to retreat from this uncivilized course, and end the blockade imposed for the purpose of subjecting Iraqi children to hunger and endangering their health and lives,'' the letters said. ``We also urge you to withdraw your forces and fleets from our lands and Arab waters.'' Iraqi authorities have been claiming there is a milk shortage, but Western journalists who traveled to Baghdad recently saw stores stocked with milk. In his visit to the school, Saddam met with teachers and students ``and wished the pupils success in service of the great objectives of Iraq,'' the news agency said. ``Teachers, pupils and their relatives gathered in front of school to express pleasure over his excellency's visit,'' it said. In a nationally broadcast address marking Children's Day, Saddam on Friday urged the children to understand the candy and milk shortages caused by the trade embargo. ``I know that you like sweets despite the harm they cause to your beautiful teeth, and that the younger among you live on imported milk,'' Saddam said in the speech, read by an announcer on government television and radio.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Peace Price Changes With The Times
DOC.TEXT: As the world changes, so des the Nobel Peace Prize. Once the domain of Western statesmen, recipients in recent years have come from a range of backgrounds and regions, such as Tibet's exiled Dalai Lama last year and Mother Teresa in 1979. Gidske Anderson, Norwegian Nobel Committee leader, said members ``no longer look just to the Western world, but to the whole world.'' ``What is new is the peace prize encouraging human rights,'' said Nobel Institute director Geir Lundestad, noting the awards that have gone to the Dalai Lama and to Lech Walesa, leader of Poland's Solidarity movement, among others. The prize could be awarded for the 71st time on Monday. Since the first peace prize in 1901, it has been withheld 19 times, most recently in 1972. The 1990 winner's name, if there is one, remains a closely guarded secret until Ms. Anderson makes the announcement at the Nobel Institute in Oslo. Ms. Anderson said she often finds speculation beforehand ``a little amusing.'' Norway's news media has suggested Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela or Chinese pro-democracy activist Chai Ling. Others mentioned as possible candidates include former President Reagan, Pope John Paul II and German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Nominations for 74 individuals and 26 organizations were received by the Feb. 1 deadline. Ms. Anderson would not say if the 1990 award would be surprising. ``But there is always someone who will criticize the choice. It's perfectly natural. There are a lot of opinions in the world,'' she said. Before 1960, the only winner from outside North America or Western Europe was Argentine negotiator Carlos de Saavedra Lamas, who helped settle a conflict between Paraguay and Bolivia. But six of the past 10 winners were from other parts of the world, including Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez in 1987, South African Bishop Desmond Tutu in 1984, and Mexican disarmament champion Alfonso Garcia Robles, who shared the prize in 1982. The Office of U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees was awarded the prize in 1981. The prize was founded by Alfred Nobel, a Swede who invented dynamite and hoped the power of his find would force the world to disarm. The prize is always awarded in Oslo on the Dec. 10 anniversary of his death in 1896. No one is certain why Nobel picked Norway for the peace prize. The awards for science and literature are given in Sweden. Nobel's will said the peace prize should recognize those who had arranged peace conferences, negotiated disarmament or ``encouraged brotherhood between nations.'' ``The committee has a great deal of latitude,'' said Lundestad. But three basic categories emerged quickly: humanitarians, peace activists and world statesmen. The prize carries a prize of 4 million Swedish kroner, about $700,000 at the present exchange rate. ``I don't think the money is that important. For someone like Tutu or Walesa, its prestige gives them a whole new dimension. They can no longer be ignored by their governments,'' said Anderson. Yet choices can provoke anger. China threatened sanctions against Norway after the Dalai Lama was named. The award was seen as a slap at China for the June 4, 1989, massacre of pro-democracy students in Beijing and its 30-year occupation of Tibet. Adolf Hilter was so enraged by anti-Nazi journalist Carl Von Ossietzky winning the prize in 1935 that he decreed no German could ever accept one. The Nobel Foundation sometimes awards a prize retroactively, and Ossietzky received it in 1936. The five-member Nobel committee, appointed by Norway's Parliament for overlapping six-year terms, does not answer to the government. ``One tradition that has become stronger in the last decade is that any kind of campaign for a candidate has the opposite effect,'' Ms. Anderson said. ``It makes us suspicious.'' Nor is timeliness of events, such as the 1989 pro-democracy reforms in Eastern Europe, a key consideration. ``If a nomination can't last a year, then it wasn't worthy,'' Ms. Anderson said. ``No organization can always be on the mark, but I think the Nobel committee has a pretty good overall record of finding worthy winners,'' Lundestad said.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Deployment: A Family Affair in the 646th
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It will be a family affair Sunday when the 646th Quartermaster Company rolls out of town for the Middle East. ``We've got a brother-sister team, a mother, father and son, a father and son, two brothers and a couple of sets of cousins,'' said Lt. Larry Sheetz, commanding officer of the 124-member Army Reserve unit. ``When we say there's a family feeling within this unit, we're not kidding,'' Sheetz said. ``Sometimes you have to watch what you say because someone's relative might hear.'' The Kingwood-based unit, part of the 99th Army Reserve Command in Oakdale, Pa., is headed for Fort Lee, Va., and several weeks of training before deployment in the Persian Gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield, Sheetz said. The 646th helps distribute fuel for front-line troops. ``We're like a floating gas station,'' said Sheetz. ``We can set up a pipeline and distribution system anywhere in the world we're told to go.'' Staff Sgts. Walter and Rotha Hall, and Spec. 4 Jerry Hall, the couple's son, will be among those boarding trucks and buses for the trip to Virginia. Jack Gordon, a spokesman for the 99th, said the Halls are unique among reservists nationally. ``I've never heard of another father, mother and son serving together in the same unit,'' Gordon said. Walter Hall, 39, an assistant platoon sergeant, and Rotha Hall, a tank farm supervisor, joined the reserve unit together 14 years ago. Mrs. Hall wouldn't give her age. ``I had just gotten out of the Army and decided to join when we tried to buy a house,'' Walter Hall said. ``We were in a pinch and didn't have any money, so I said, `I'm going to join the reserves.' ``My wife said, `If you're going I'm going with you,' and here we are,''' he said. As staff sergeants, the Halls each are paid $200 a month for attending monthly meetings and a two-week training camp. Jerry Hall, 20, receives about $150 a month. ``It's been great,'' Walter Hall said. ``A lot of people get lonely when they have to leave their families to go to summer camp. We don't have that problem.'' ``We don't have the long distance telephone bills that some people run up either,'' his wife added. ``It's worked out really well. We've used our Reserve pay to buy clothes for the kids and to buy a car.'' Jerry Hall said good-natured ribbing from his cohorts and an inability to conceal his cigarette habit from his parents are the only problems he's had since joining the reserve unit three years ago. ``It's really pretty cool,'' Jerry Hall said. ``They take care of me. I kind of envy them, especially now. They have each other. But all I'm thinking about is leaving my girlfriend behind.'' The Halls learned they could be called up in August while the unit was on a training mission in Okinawa shortly after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. ``We've made out our wills and told our other children what to do if something happens,'' Rotha Hall said. ``They told us we could be away six months or a year. If war breaks out, they said we could be there for the duration.'' That possibility doesn't sit well with the Halls' two daughters and two other sons. ``I hate this,'' said Lea Pyles, one of the Halls' daughters. ``I've never really been away from my parents for any length of time. We grew up with them going to summer camp, but this is different. ``We kind of figured they'd never leave the states,'' Pyles said. ``This has been scary. One day, we're all right, the next we're all crying. You try to be strong but it isn't easy. It's like I'm 10 years old again.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Agents Seize $3 Million From Iraqi's Account
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents seized $3 million deposited in a bank account by an Iraqi broker who the government claims broke federal law by shipping aircraft parts from the United States to Libya. The late Ihsan Barbouti wired the $3 million to Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. in New York to finance the illegal export of the aircraft parts, according to a federal complaint filed in New York. Barbouti was a London-based architect who designed a chemical weapons plant in Rabta, Libya. He died in London in July of heart and lung complications. The Dallas Morning News reported Friday that last year Barbouti ordered parts identified in documents as replacement equipment for CH-47 Chinook helicopters, C-130 cargo planes and French-made Mirage jet fighters. They were shipped from Miami to Brazil, where a Barbouti associate then shipped the equipment to Libya, according to the complaint. The seizure of assets last week stems from an ongoing U.S. Customs investigation. Federal investigators have been trying to unravel the intricate domestic holdings of the international middleman who described himself as a procurement broker for Col. Moammar Gadhafi's government in Libya. Don de Gabrielle, a federal prosecutor in Houston, confirmed the Oct. 4 seizure of the $3 million, but declined to say whether Barbouti's role in the parts transactions has been presented to a grand jury. The News reported last month that the arms deal was part of a pattern of purchases and investments by Barbouti, apparently designed to divert American technology to Libya and Iraq. Barbouti held interests in high-tech companies based in Houston, Dallas, Oklahoma, and Boca Raton, Fla., the newspaper reported. The News also reported that interest among federal law enforcement agencies in those investments and purchases was heightened by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. At least three American businessman with whom Barbouti did business told the newspaper that Barbouti intended to export technology from their companies to Libya. Among Barbouti's American investments was Product Ingredient Technology Inc., a manufacturer of cherry flavoring in Boca Raton, Fla. Last month, the newspaper reported that a waste byproduct in the making of cherry flavoing was hydrogen cyanide, a lethal compound easily converted for use as a chemical weapon. Peter Kawaja, a high-tech security consultant and former employee of Barbouti's, said some of the deadly compound was taken out of the United States to a destination he declined to identify. As in the case of the aircraft parts, the export of such technology would violate a 4-year-old presidential order that bars the export of any goods, technology or services from the United States to Libya. According to a Customs document, Barbouti's plan involved the purchase of what he claimed was automobile parts from Brazil. The Customs claim says Barbouti admitted in litigation in Florida and New York that the $3 million really for the purchase of aircraft parts for shipment from Brazil to Libya.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Wants More Information About Leaky Hanford Tanks
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators have joined state officials in seeking more precise data on two leaky radioactive-waste storage tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation. The Energy Department said Thursday that a damaged waste tank at Hanford may have leaked 800,000 gallons of radioactive cooling water into the soil since being ruptured in a 1965 explosion. On Friday, operator Westinghouse Hanford said almost 1 million gallons of radioactive waste and water were pumped between 1963 and 1967 into another underground tank that had leaked about 2,400 gallons of liquid in 1962. The two single-shell tanks are about 5 miles apart on the 560-square-mile nuclear reservation in south-central Washington. ``We don't have the full story yet,'' said Don Provost, waste-management director for the state Department of Ecology. Provost said the state needs extra leak data so it knows how much work is required under a 30-year federal plan for cleaning up the entire Hanford site, which Westinghouse Hanford began operating for the Energy Department in 1987. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, also wants to know ``what they (the operators) knew and when they knew it,'' said Vic Rezendes, the agency's chief of energy issues. The 1965 explosion caused tank 105-A to leak and the radioactive wastes inside to overheat. The department reported a year ago that the tank had leaked 5,000 gallons of liquid since it ruptured. The new estimate shows 832,000 gallons of cooling water were pumped into the tank between 1965 and 1978, when the work stopped. The Energy Department estimates 40,000 to 200,000 gallons may have evaporated through vents, leaving 632,000 to 792,000 gallons still in the soil. Hanford waste engineer Johnnie Newsom said officials were still going through old records to determine how much waste was leaked. The Energy Department has agreed to turn over any additional records to the state. Energy Department spokesman Ken Morgan said there ``was an honest attempt to provide all the information on the tanks,'' though he said the data may prove incomplete. The other tank, 108-SX, was pumped dry in 1980 and is no longer in service. It cannot yet be determined how much of its contents may have evaporated or leaked but a Westinghouse investigation continues, said Richard Raymond, Westinghouse manager of single-shell tanks. Hanford has 177 underground waste storage tanks. They were used to store radioactive waste generated in four decades of producing plutonium for nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Urges Syrian Troops to Leave Christian Enclave in Lebanon
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials said Saturday they regretted the Syrian invasion of the Christian enclave in Lebanon but did not consider it cause for an Israeli move against Syria or Lebanese forces. Past reports have said Syrian use of air power in Lebanon could lead to an Israeli attack. But Uri Lubrani, Israel's coordinator in Lebanon, said the attack that forced rebel Gen. Michel Aoun to surrender was not enough to force Israel's hand. ``The Syrians know very well Israel's red lines. It is true that they used planes but ... this is the use of force in order to do something inside Lebanon,'' Lubrani said on Israel television. ``We are sticking to the position that anything that doesn't threaten our security ... doesn't obligate us to make any move that would be seen as interference in Lebanon's internal affairs.'' He added: ``We are sorry that it came to the use of violence and the entrance of Syrian forces into the Christian enclave. We hope that these forces will leave as quickly as possible.'' Israel carved out a 2- to 10-mile wide strip in southern Lebanon in 1985 to act as a buffer against guerrilla attacks when it withdrew the bulk of its forces from Lebanon following its 1982 invasion. A 3,000-man South Lebanon Army led by General Antoine Lahad patrols the zone, backed by about 1,000 Israeli troops. Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, a parliamentary leader, said Aoun's surrender would have little affect on the security of Israel's northern border, despite the Christian South Lebanon Army's close relations with Aoun. ``Don't forget that Lahad is supported, that his back leans totally on Israel,'' Ben-Eliezer said. Israel radio said residents of southern Lebanon had turned to the Israeli army officers to protect Christians in Beirut from reprisals in the wake of Aoun's defeat. Israeli military sources said such appeals could not be granted.

DOC.HEAD: Video Fools Customers into Calling Police
DOC.TEXT: Customers looking at a television monitor in a check-cashing store saw a gunman sneaking around and thought they were witnessing a crime. But it was daytime drama of a different sort. The women dashed down the street to call police, who quickly swarmed the store. The women didn't realize the monitor was just a TV set tuned to the soap opera ``General Hospital,'' and the man with gun was an actor. As police positioned themselves outside the Check-X-Change on Wednesday, a dispatcher called the store's teller, 20-year-old Chris Wiltse. ``They asked if everything was OK and I said, `Yes,''' Wiltse said. ``And they said, `Are you sure?''' The police dispatcher asked Wiltse to come outside to talk to the officers. ``There were police everywhere,'' Wiltse said. ``I was like `Wow.' They searched the building real quick to make sure nobody was there.'' In the convincing make-believe, actor Scott Thompson Baker, playing Colton on the soap opera, was creeping gun-in-hand toward the hospital roof to rescue some hostages. He eventually freed them, of course. Baker, in an interview from Los Angeles, said he was flattered that his performance was so effecting. Police Lt. Robert VanLeuven said the women, whose names weren't released, did the right thing. ``We would rather receive a call of that nature and have people be involved than have someone ignore it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Actress in Student Film Accidentally Wounded DuringCemetery Scene
DOC.TEXT: An actor using a loaded gun in a film being made by college students in a cemetery accidentally shot another member of the cast, police said. The victim, a 28-year-old actress, was shot in the chest with a large-caliber handgun at Valhalla Memorial Park late Friday afternoon, Burbank police Lt. Gordon Bowers said Saturday. She was flown by helicopter to a hospital and was listed in stable condition, Bowers said. Her name was not released. The woman was shot on camera, Sgt. Ed Skarvana said. ``Incredible as it may seem ... they used a loaded gun,'' he said. ``They didn't know it was loaded or they had forgotten.'' The actor was questioned, but the shooting appeared to be accidental and there were no arrests, Bowers said. Valhalla Memorial Park is in the city's North Hollywood section on the edge of Burbank.

DOC.HEAD: Group of Westerners Plan to Leave Iraq After Appeals
DOC.TEXT: At least 19 Westerners were told they could leave Iraq after appeals by a Spanish lawmaker and by Youssef Islam, the former pop singer known as Cat Stevens. The 15 Spaniards and four Britons were to leave Sunday on regular Iraqi Airlines flights to Amman, according to Spanish Parliament member Cristina Almeida and Youssef Islam, the name the singer adopted after converting to the Moslem faith. Ms. Almeida and Youssef Islam said they had met with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to urge the foreigners be released. On Saturday, the Baghdad station manager of the Dutch carrier KLM was allowed to depart Iraq, the Dutch Foreign Ministry said in Amsterdam. The employee, Jan van Houten, arrived in Amman on Saturday. Dutch Television reported Saturday that all Western airline employees would be allowed to leave Iraq and occupied Kuwait, but gave no further details or source for the information. Youssef Islam said he has been in Iraq for about a month atttempting to obtain freedom for foreigners. The four Britons scheduled for release are Moslems who were making pilgrimages to Islamic shrines in Iraq when they were stranded by the Aug. 2 invasion and Saddam's order detaining all Westerners. British diplomats in Baghdad speculated that more Britons might be permitted to leave after former British Prime Minister Edward Heath's scheduled meeting with Saddam on Oct. 21. Ms. Almeida, a noted human rights activist in Spain, arrived in Iraq on Oct. 4 to appeal for the release of her countrymen. The 15 are reportedly the only non-diplomat Spaniards left in Iraq. Thousands of Westerners are being detained by Iraq or are in hiding in occupied Kuwait. An estimated 700 U.S., British, French and German citizens and other Westerners are being held as human shields around strategic targets to deter attack by U.S.-led forces in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: Lubbock Lake Preserves Record of Early Human Life
DOC.TEXT: When the natural springs that had fed this West Texas region for millennia dried up in the 1930s, Lake Lubbock vanished with them. But the lake has not been forgotten. Its legacy was in helping to preserve a treasure store of artifacts of human and animal life dating back more than 11,000 years, archaeologists say. The arid, windswept plains of West Texas were once rich with grasslands inhabited by huge hairy mammoths, 3-foot-tall armadillos and bears three times the size of a grizzly. Lake Lubbock has provided the proof. A 300-acre site northwest of Lubbock, centered on where the lake once existed, has been turned into a state park that has been designated as a federal historic site. The Lake Lubbock Landmark opens Sunday. Some archaeologists regard it as the premier site of its kind in North America. Over the last 50 years, researchers have unearthed evidence that the area has been continuously inhabited for more than 11,000 years. ``The site basically is little packages of time, stacked one on top of the other,'' said Eileen Johnson, the park's director. ``You can study man's entire existence in the New World in one spot instead of having to go to 100 different sites.'' Researchers have been able to identify soils, vegetation, pollen records, wildlife and human culture from fossils excavated at the site. Among the bigger finds have been an ancient short-faced bear, a giant armadillo and mammoths. ``The giant armadillo was truly Texas-size,'' Ms. Johnson said. ``It was 3-feet-tall and 6-feet-long.'' Researchers have also identified the remains of prehistoric plants, fish, amphibians, reptiles and birds, she said. While researchers have found evidence of human life - projectile points, bone tools, manufacturing debris, processing areas, slaughter sites and an oven - ``the most fantastic thing is that no human remains have ever been found,'' said Robert A. Nash, a longtime supporter and namesake of the landmark's interpretive center. ``That would be the find of the century if they found a skull of the so-called Clovis or Folsom man,'' he said. Amid the sprawling acres are a museum documenting the site and a research lab occupied by archaeological students from Texas Tech University. After visitors pass through the museum, filled with murals of ancient life, photographs and fossils, they are encouraged to walk through the excavation sites. Picnic tables and grills are set up for barbecues. The park is a collaborative effort by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, Texas Tech and the city of Lubbock. The state agency leases the property from the city and Texas Tech provides the research. ``We know only 5 percent of what is out there,'' Ms. Johnson said. ``It's awe-inspiring and exciting to think we will be uncovering and learning here for years and years to come.'' Scholars from around the world were expected to attend the park's formal opening. John Albanese, a Wyoming-based geologist and independent consultant for archaeological sites, said the park ``is the premier site in terms of the quality and quantity of the old material that has been found there.'' ``It's one of the better preserved records of early man in North America,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Gulf War Foes Reported To Open Embassies in Tehran and Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: Iran and Iraq were to open embassies in each other's capitals Sunday, marking another step in the rapprochement of the two nations after a decade of hostility, the Tehran Times reported. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is seeking Iranian help in puncturing the comprehensive economic embargo slapped on him by the United Nations to force his pullback from Kuwait. Quoting an informed source, the English-language newspaper's Sunday edition said the two nations agreed to establish missions during the current Tehran visit by Iraqi Deputy Foreign Minister Wisam al-Zahawi. The source said the level of representation would be at the charge d'affaires level for the time being. Iranian political circles believe Tehran's first envoy will be Javad Turkabadi, Iran's former charge d'affaires in Kuwait. Turkabadi currently heads the Iranian Foreign Ministry's Persian Gulf Affairs desk. There was no word on who the first Iraqi envoy would be. Iran and Iraq agreed to re-establish diplomatic ties during a September visit to Tehran by Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. It was the first visit by an Iraqi official since before the 1979 Islamic revolution that overthrew Iranian Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi. A year later, war broke out between the two nations. A U.N.-brokered peace was made in 1988. Iraq has been seeking the help of neighboring states to circumvent the U.N. sanctions, since its coastline is effectively blocked by the U.S.-led multinational fleet in the Gulf. Iraq and Iran share a 700-mile border, and although Tehran has condemned Saddam's invasion of Kuwait, there have been reports Iran was allowing food shipments across the border. Iran could be of even greater help if it helps Iraq ship its oil, which accounted for more than 95 percent of Iraqi foreign exchange earnings before the embargo. The embargo and blockade have shut down Iraqi exports, but Iran could use the pipeline to its Kharg Island terminal in the gulf to carry Iraqi oil from across the nearby border.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Release Greenpeace Ship
DOC.TEXT: A Greenpeace ship seized by the Soviets after it approached an Arctic nuclear test site was released Saturday and headed for Norway, a member of the environmental group said. None of the 42 activists detained were charged following more than five days at a naval base near the port of Murmansk, about 900 miles north of Moscow, Canadian activist Steve Shallhorn said by radiotelephone from the ship. The ship was expected to reach the Norwegian port of Kirkenes by early Sunday. Last Monday, the Soviet Coast Guard fired warning shots from deck-mounted machine guns before boarding the MV Greenpeace. Four environmentalists in a rubber raft had earlier managed to reach one of the Novaya Zemlya islands in the Barents Sea and collect radioactive soil and other samples, Shallhorn said. The ship was towed to the naval base, where it was held for violating Soviet territorial waters. Shallhorn said the four activists spent 10 hours on the island before being captured. Novaya Zemlya was a primary nuclear test site from 1958 to 1963. Environmental groups claim it was last used in 1988. ``They tried to hide samples in their packs, their pockets, even their socks, but the (Soviets) went through everything with a Geiger counter and found everything,'' Shallhorn said. He said the 35 Western and seven Soviet activists had been generally treated well during the detention, and were guarded by at least 13 armed men under KGB command. The Greenpeace was ordered to leave Soviet territorial waters following an investigation by the KGB security police and the Soviet Prosecutor's Office, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. The vessel was on a two-week anti-nuclear protest voyage along the Arctic coastline. On Wednesday, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said the Soviet Union agreed with the Greenpeace goal of ending nuclear weapons testing. But, he said, ``no matter what the mission or how noble the objectives may be, the laws of our country cannot be violated with impunity.'' According to Greenpeace officials in London, Novaya Zemlya was chosen for the protest because of fears it would again become a major test site after the closing down of the Soviet Union's main test range in the Kazakhstan republic in central Asia. The site is about 370 miles from Norway. Unconfirmed reports that nuclear tests would be resumed there prompted protests from Nordic governments.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans' Oldest Abortion Clinic Shuts Down After Feds Seize Equipment
DOC.TEXT: The city's best-known abortion clinic has closed after authorities seized its equipment for failing to pay federal fines. The penalties were ordered because clinic doctors illegally prescribed drugs. The clinic's lawyer contends the seizure was more than a matter of $337,000 in fines, but a stroke against abortion. ``I've talked to people all over the country, and this is the only time this has ever happened,'' said Charles Cotton, an attorney for Delta Women's Clinic, after its equipment and furniture were seized Friday. The U.S. Marshals Service said it will auction the confiscated items to collect on fines set in March by U.S. District Judge Adrian Duplantier. The judge agreed with federal prosecutors that three doctors illegally prescribed sedatives and painkillers at the clinic. The physicians were licensed to prescribe the drugs, but had not registered to do so at the clinic. Clinical Leasing Services Inc., which owns the clinic, filed for protection from its creditors in May. But Thursday federal Bankruptcy Judge Thomas Kingsmill dismissed the petition, saying it was filed in bad faith. Cotton said he hadn't been told of the ruling when the clinic's assets were seized. ``The speed, rapidity and zeal in which this was handled leads us to believe it was more than a simple execution of a judgment,'' Cotton said. ``This is an attempt to circumvent Roe vs. Wade and an attempt to abrogate women's right to choose'' an abortion, Cotton said. The clinic opened in 1973 after the U.S. Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion. First Assistant U.S. Attorney Al Winters Jr. said the government simply went after a debt it was owed. ``We are collecting the civil judgment as required by law,'' Winters said. U.S. Attorney John Volz has denied repeatedly that his office sued Delta in July 1989 to shut it down. Cotton said the clinic may stay closed until the courts can hear an appeal. Clinical Leasing Services said in the spring that it wanted to appeal the court ruling but could not afford the fine or an appeal bond. The bond would have kept the case in court and prevented the seizure of assets. In April the government seized about $40,000 from clinic accounts, Cotton said. Volz has said that federal authorities began looking into the clinic's operations in August 1988, and had warned officials that physicians had to be registered to dispense drugs at the clinic. Duplantier ordered fines of $300,000 against the clinic for 100 instances in which doctors prescribed sedatives and painkillers. The judge also fined the clinic $37,000 for 37 instances of alleged failure to list addresses of patients who had received drugs. Duplantier also fined the doctors a total of $278,000. They are appealing the fines.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Hears Church Service On Red Square
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: A Russian Orthodox service reverberated across Red Square from the brightly colored, onion-shaped domes of St. Basil's Cathedral on Saturday night for the first time since the 1917 Revolution. In one of the most stirring demonstrations of the revival of religion in the Soviet Union, the plaintive chanting of the faithful echoed off the Kremlin's red brick walls, floated over Lenin's marble tomb and through much of central Moscow on a cold, clear night. St. Basil's, whose bright yellow, green, blue and white domes and spires are among Russia's most famous symbols, sits on the southern edge of the cobblestone square. The plaza is bordered on the east by the immense GUM department store and on the west by the Kremlin, seat of the Soviet government. Like many important churches across the country, St. Basil's was confiscated by the Soviet government after the Bolshevik Revolution, converted into a museum and closed to religious observances. Saturday's service - commemorating a ninth century miracle in which the Mother of God is said to have appeared to soldiers defending the city of Byzantium - was the first allowed in the cathedral since 1917. Official tolerance for religion has increased greatly since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. During the last two years, in particular, many churches have been reconsecrated, and Soviet citizens have flocked to services in record numbers. Last month, a full service was held in the Kremlin's Uspensky Cathedral, the country's holiest church, for the first time since the revolution. The Soviet legislature also passed a law on freedom of conscience, formally ending decades of repression. Shortly before nightfall Saturday, hundreds of people packed St. Basil's, built in 1555-1561 by Ivan the Terrible to celebrate his military victory over the kingdom of Kazan on Russia's eastern border. As many as 1,000 other worshippers gathered behind police barricades outside the church, enduring 35-degree temperatures throughout the three-hour service, which was projected by two sound trucks on the square. The worshippers stood silently, gazing up at the domes illuminated by floodlights and periodically making the four-point sign of the cross across their chests with three fingers, in the eastern church tradition. Inside, the scent of incense filled the cathedral and the choir's chanting seemed at times to come from within the walls of its eight chapels, which represent Ivan's eight major battles against Kazan. Among the worshippers Saturday was a former KGB general, Oleg Kalugin, who was stripped of his rank, honors and pension last summer after he accused the security police of continuing to spy on ordinary citizens, including clergymen. The service was conducted by Archimandrite Pavel of Pskov, one of the leaders of the Russian Orthodox Church, which has an estimated 30 million active followers among the Soviet Union's 285 million people. ``I am a believer, and for us, this is a great event in our life,'' said Vitaly Kolesnik, 55, a magazine editor. ``I wanted to be here, on Red Square, when it happened.'' ``It was very sad when this was a museum. Now, there is joy and the walls are alive again with prayer,'' said Maya Besarabskaya, 60, a Moscow sculptor who held a thin candle in her strong hands.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacist Does Court Battle with Civil Rights Attorney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 18-19, `A man...' to CORRECT to Mazzella sted Mazella, identify him as a former vice president of Aryan Youth Movement.
DOC.TEXT: Racists and civil rights advocates are sitting side by side in a courtroom to watch white supremacist Tom Metzger battle a crusading Alabama attorney out to bankrupt him and his cause. Metzger, 52, a television repairman from Fallbrook, Calif., is a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon and founder of the White Aryan Resistance. The Aryan Youth Movement, a WAR spinoff, is headed by his son John, 22. The groups believe in racial separatism. The extent of their ambitions is at the heart of the trial that on Monday enters its second week at the Multnomah County Courthouse. The Metzgers are accused of inciting the beating death of a black man by sending agents to Portland to preach hate and violence. Mulugeta Seraw, 27, an Ethiopian national planning to attend college in this country, was returning home from a party in November 1988 when he was beaten to death with a bat. Three ``skinheads'' have pleaded guilty to killing Seraw. Now Seraw's family wants $10 million in damages for his death. The lead attorney in the civil suit is Morris Dees, a civil rights lawyer from the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala. Three years ago, Dees won a $7 million jury verdict that put the United Klans of America out of business. Two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a black man. As compensation, the victim's mother received title to the Klan's national headquarters. The Metzgers are representing themselves in the trial before Judge Ancer Haggerty. ``I am a white separatist,'' the elder Metzger told jurors, by way of introduction. ``I'm a small-business man from Fallbrook, Calif. I'm going to talk to you like I would one of my customers over a cup of coffee or a beer.'' He told jurors the lawsuit was a government attempt to persecute him. Dees spent the week trying to link the Metzgers to Seraw's murder, in part through the testimony of Kenneth Mieske. Mieske, who goes by the nicknames Ken Death and Bat Man, is serving a life sentence for killing Seraw. Under Dees' questioning he was contentious, often smirking and winking at his girlfriend across the courtroom. When he pleaded guilty to killing Seraw, Mieske had said his motive was racial. But on the stand last week Mieske said the government forced him to say that. The alternative, he said, would have been charges bringing more prison time than the 20-year minimum sentence he ultimately received. Mieske, 25, said he really killed Seraw to defend fellow skinhead Kyle Brewster. Seraw hit Brewster with a ``sucker punch,'' he said, and Seraw was choking him. A man allegedly sent to train Mieske in violence, Dave Mazzella, 21, is Dees' star witness and he put him on the stand Friday. Mazella, a former vice president of the Aryan Youth Movement, told jurors the Metzgers sent him to Portland to organize neo-Nazi skinheads and incite them to do violence against minorities. At the Metzgers' direction, Mazella said, he headed for Kenneth Mieske's home after arriving in Portland. Metzger has filed a countersuit against Mazella and two other men he allegedly sent to Portland, charging they were ``agent provocateurs'' working for the Portland police. The countersuit also claims two of Seraw's friends provoked the fight with the skinheads and that they and the ``provocateurs'' should be liable for any damages Metzger might be ordered to pay Seraw's estate. Among the spectators are skinheads professing racism and members of Skinheads Against Racial Prejudice. The American Civil Liberties Union and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith are monitoring the trial as well. The courthouse is under heavy security. Police taped paper over the courtroom windows and spectators were required to pass through a labyrinth of metal detectors. Officers routinely lined skinheads along the wall outside the courtroom and searched them. Three skinheads were arrested for carrying weapons, and two on outstanding warrants. One warrant alleged a neo-Nazi skinhead had tried to carve a swastika into the skull of a member of Skinheads Against Racial Prejudice. Police revealed some anxiety early in the week when they spotted a suspicious-looking lunchbox outside a federal courthouse several blocks from where the trial is being held. The bomb squad was called and the box was gingerly pulled by a rope into the street. It contained a lunch.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 13 Killed In Hot Spring Explosion
PRECEDES San Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with details, quotes from scene, higher death toll. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A geyser-like blast of boiling water and hot rocks leveled homes and killed at least 13 people in a western Salvadoran village Saturday. The 3 a.m. eruption left a huge crater and shot water, mud and stones up to 350 feet around this small farm community 60 miles west of San Salvador, the capital. At least seven homes were destroyed and 20 others hospitalized. ``First it felt like an earthquake, followed by a strong wind,'' said Miguel Antonio Melgar, 56. ``I ran outside. There was a lot of smoke and rocks.'' ``Rocks and boiling water were falling all over the place,'' said Army Maj. Jose Rodriguez, from the nearby military base at Ahuachapan. El Salvador sits on a geological fault and is frequently shaken by earthquakes and volcanic activity. The Massachusetts-sized nation with a population of 5 million is dotted with thermal wells, some harnessed to generate electricity. Rodriguez said the site that exploded was not being used for power, but often attracted tourists to El Barro, Spanish for ``the mud.'' Sometimes the murky well pffed steam. The village has hardly been touched by the guerrilla war concentrated in the eastern half of the country during the past decade. The war has left more than 73,000 people dead. ``Here we are far from the war, but suddenly we are suffering,'' Antonio Melgar said as he dug with a spade through the rubble of his brother's home, crushed by falling rocks. His brother, sister-in-law and the couple's four children were killed. Candida Hernandez, 53, who lives 90 feet from the geothermal well, said she will likely remain in the village. ``We have long heard that it could be dangerous, but what should we do? We're poor people and we have nowhere else to live. We're going to stay here,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: `Displaced President' Takes Over
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Since his election 11 months ago, Elias Hrawi has been known as the displaced president because rebel Gen. Michel Aoun held the presidential palace and refused to recognize him. After Aoun was pushed out by Syrian and Lebanese government forces Saturday, Hrawi, an affable 65-year-old former agricultural engineer, can at last claim it for his own. Not that there's much left to claim. The hilltop palace in Baabda east of Beirut is a ruin, hit by hundreds of shells fired by the Syrians and their allies last year in their war against Aoun. The shell-shattered mansion symbolizes the awesome task that Hrawi, a wealthy Christian landowner, faces in implementing a 1989 peace accord to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Then he must rebuild the shattered country. Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic like Aoun, is a native of the town of Zahle in the fertile Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon, where his family has an agricultural business. He was elected president Nov. 24 by Parliament, which convened at a honeymoon hotel in the Syrian-policed Bekaa because Aoun had banned elections in the 300-square-mile Christian enclave north of Beirut. Hrawi's main task was to implement the peace agreement reached in Taif, Saudi Arabia, in October 1989. Unable to occupy what was left of the palace in the Christian enclave, Hrawi had to make his headquarters in a spartan Lebanese army barracks in the Bekaa. He later moved to an apartment in west Beirut near the Syrian army command. Security around him has been tight. He rarely moves outside his heavily guarded building and his travel plans are kept secret.

DOC.HEAD: Threats From Lili Diminish, But Rain Continues
DOC.TEXT: The threat from Tropical Storm Lili diminished Saturday, but rain continued over much of the nation. Lili was downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm early Saturday and maximum sustained winds of 60 mph were forecast to diminish by Sunday. Lili was moving north over the Atlantic northeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., Saturday evening. There was flooding in the South and along the Atlantic Coast, with many roads closed and widespread damage. The National Weather Service said a major flood worked its way down the Ogeechee River in east-central Georgia Saturday. Flood stage at Midville is six feet, and the river there was at 12 feet Saturday morning, the weather service said. There also was rain in Pennsylvania, northern Vermont and portions of New York state, New Jersey and much of New England. Snow fell in the mountains of Wyoming Saturday morning, with a mixture of rain and snow falling over the north-central portion of the state in the afternoon. Rain was scattered over western Montana and the Idaho panhandle as well as across northwest Nebraska. High winds were reported in Wyoming, Idaho and in the mountains of Colorado. Winds gusted to 57 mph near Pocatello, Idaho, and to 58 mph at Laramie, Wyo. Cape Hatteras reached 84 degrees Saturday, breaking its high temperature record for the date. The high temperature record has been tied or broken there every day for the past week. Miami warmed to 91 degrees, also a record for the date. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 41 degrees at Mullan, Idaho, to 91 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif. Low temperature for the Lower 48 Saturday morning was 16 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Draws Devoted Surfers
With AM-Storms Rdp
DOC.TEXT: As a hurricane watch sent caravans of prudent campers scurrying inland, another type of human headed in the opposite direction: the windsurfer. Ted Mustric and Mike Sweazen of Beaver Falls, Pa., jumped in their car and drove through the night to North Carolina as soon as they heard Wednesday about Hurricane Lili, and the prospect of speeding winds. ``We heard about the hurricane and all the turbulence,'' Mustric said. ``I knew it would be windy, so I said `Let's go!''' ``Actually we like gale-force winds,'' Mustric said, sounding a bit disappointed that Lili had been downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm early Saturday. Though tropical storm watches and warnings were canceled along the mid-Atlantic coast, strong winds combined with glass-smooth waters produced ideal conditions for windsurfers who flocked to Pamlico Sound, which lies between North Carolina's Outer Banks and the mainland. On Friday afternoon, campgrounds on Hatteras Island were deserted and radio announcers were imploring residents to board up their windows. But at one of the most popular wind-surfing spots on the East Coast, it was business as usual: sun, stiff wind and no waves. ``It's an absolutely fabulous day,'' said Gill Barlow of Charlotte, Vt. Behind him, across a parking lot packed with scores of vans, station wagons and pickup trucks all from points north, raged an Atlantic churned by the approaching storm. ``We're not disrespectful of the possibility of a hurricane,'' Barlow said. ``We have time to get out. The house is buttoned down and we're packed.'' But he, and others like him who had come south from as far away as Montreal, were not going anywhere until they were forced out. ``I would only leave if they told us to leave,'' said Gus Linssen, a Bostonian who brings windsurfing students to this parking lot on a sliver of private land wedged inside the Cape Hatteras National Seashore near Avon. Every other vehicle at Canadian Hole had at least one neon surfboard on top or in back. One bumper sticker read ``Pray For Wind.'' The lot was busy with windsurfers either coming out of the water or getting ready to go in. ``It's a great spot because it's shallow,'' said Steve Pomeroy of Boston, one of Linssen's charges. ``You can walk out as far as you want and the water will only come up to your waist.''

DOC.HEAD: Auctioneer: Exxon Surplus Sells for More Than Projected $10 Million
DOC.TEXT: A four-day auction of Exxon's surplus oil-spill cleanup gear grossed well over the expected $10 million, auction company officials said. The Vancouver, British Columbia-based Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers International wouldn't say Saturday exactly how much it took in. The sale, which drew thousands of bidders to several lots around Anchorage, concluded Friday. Everything sold, from a float plane to mobile homes to Zodiac boats to fishing nets to household appliances, officials said. Ritchie Bros. bought the merchandise last month from Exxon Corp. for an undisclosed price. The gear was left over from Exxon's 1989 and 1990 summer cleanup efforts on Alaska shorelines tainted by the Exxon Valdez's spill in March 1989 of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil. It was the nation's biggest oil spill.

DOC.HEAD: Educators Surprised with $25,000 Awards
DOC.TEXT: Six West Virginia teachers lured to a state school board meeting on the pretext of setting up an educational task force were instead named winners of $25,000 awards for excellence. Susan Burt, a social studies teacher at Marlinton Middle School, said she didn't want to attend the board meeting Friday until she was told she was needed for a task force, which turned out be fictitious. ``I'm certainly pleased I changed my mind,'' she said. The money was provided by the Los Angeles-based Milken Family Foundation in recognition of the educators' exemplary leadership skills, professional achievements and ability to motivate students. West Virginia is one of 13 states chosen by the three-year-old foundation to participate in a program designed to get public recognition and financial awards for outstanding teachers and principals, State Schools Superintendent Hank Marockie said. He said top school officials chose the six from more than 200 candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Week at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here at a glance are the developments in the Persian Gulf crisis for the of October 7 to October 14:
DOC.HEAD: SUNDAY
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Kuwaitis crossed into Saudi Arabia after Iraq suddenly relaxed restrictions on Kuwaitis leaving the occupied emirate. Some refugees said it was the latest move in an Iraqi campaign to depopulate Kuwait, isolate the resistance movement and prepare for war.
DOC.HEAD: MONDAY
DOC.TEXT: Two American pilots serving with the multinational force facing Iraq were killed in a jet crash in Saudi Arabia. U.S. military officials said a RF4C reconnaissance jet crashed in the southern Saudi Arabian peninsula. The jet belonged to a unit of the Alabama Air National Guard assigned to Operation Desert Shield. Two U.S. Marine helicopters with eight men aboard were reported missing in the Gulf of Oman. Naval officers ruled out hostile action.
DOC.HEAD: TUESDAY
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said Iraq has developed a new missile with a range of several hundred miles, enough to strike deep in Saudi Arabia where tens of thousands of U.S. troops are deployed. The missile is called the al-Hijara, or Stone, Saddam said in a statement read over state-run Radio Baghdad.
DOC.HEAD: WEDNESDAY
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force jet crashed in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members. F-111 fighter crashed while on a training mission.
DOC.HEAD: THURSDAY
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force grounded all training flights in the Persian Gulf region for 24 hours to discuss air safety with pilots. The order followed separate accidents this week in which 12 U.S. servicemen have died.
DOC.HEAD: FRIDAY
DOC.TEXT: At the United Nations, U.S. officials joined the rest of the Security Council in condemning Israel's security forces for killing 19 Palestinians in rioting in Jerusalem earlier this week. Diplomats said the United States had not exercised its veto power over the resolution for fear of alienating Arab nations whose support it needs against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis.
DOC.HEAD: SATURDAY
DOC.TEXT: A conference of Kuwaiti exiles convened in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, with the country's royal leaders promising to install a more democratic system if Iraqi invaders are driven out. Conference members were expected to reject any Iraqi attempt to include a national referendum on Kuwait's future as part of a political solution to the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Minister Leads Reporters on Tour of Prison
DOC.TEXT: The justice minister led reporters on a tour of the Central Prison on Saturday, where captives taken since a rebel invasion last month complained of harsh conditions and lack of medical care.
