Among them were two young Ugandan boys, who showed gruesome marks on their backs they said came from being jabbed with bayonets. ``The wounds are three or four days old and haven't been looked after yet,'' said the guide who escorted the delegation of reporters and Western diplomats through the prison. Rwandan Justice Minister Pheomesee Mutgamama said at least 2,500 people have been arrested for allegedly collaborating with the rebels who invaded from Uganda. About 1,000 of them have been released, he said. Some of the detainees complained of squalid conditions and brutality. ```If they keep me here much longer my baby will die,'' said a Ugandan woman who was nursing her infant. ``My baby is still breast feeding but because of the bad food in this prison I'm scared I cannot give milk anymore to my baby.'' A man with a swollen mouth said he was beaten with the butt of a gun. ``We were put in a truck,'' he said. ``A young boy tried to escape and he was killed, shot on the spot.'' The government gave permission Saturday for the International Red Cross to visit the prison. Foreign governments, including the United States, have been stressing to Rwanda's government that it should respect human rights and work to avoid the outbreak of an all-out tribal war in Rwanda. Maj.-Gen. Juneval Habyarimana, a member of the majority Hutu tribe who has ruled Rwanda for 17 years, has been seeking western military aid for his government. He claims its troops are outnumbered by the invasion force. In the early 1960s, the Hutu crushed a Tutsi uprising, killing more than 10,000 members of the tribe, whose members make up about 15 percent of Rwanda's population of 8 million. The rebel force that invaded from Uganda includes Tutsi refugees from among the hundreds of thousands who were forced to flee in the 1960s.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Prince Promises Greater Democracy
DOC.TEXT: The crown prince of Kuwait Saturday promised greater democracy for the oil-rich emirate if it is freed from Iraqi occupation. In Jordan, Iraq's foreign minister hinted at a possible ``reconsideration'' of Baghdad's hard-line position on Kuwait. But reports that Iran and Iraq plan to upgrade diplomatic relations could help Iraq's quest to circumvent the U.N.-sanctioned boycott. ``Liberation is our top priority, and after liberation we have much to achieve,'' Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah told a gathering of about 1,000 Kuwaiti exiles in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, for a three-day conference. After liberation, he said, ``Kuwait will reinforce democracy and consolidate popular participation. The political leadership will respond to the aspirations of the people regarding the reorganization of the Kuwaiti house.'' Sheik Saad is also the nation's prime minister. Outside the hall, hundreds of youths raised banners of support for the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who opened the conference. The meeting was being attended by some who, before the Aug. 2 invasion, demanded a return to the Western-style democracy prescribed in the 1962 constitution. In the Jordanian capital of Amman, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said Saturday the gulf crisis has entered a new phase of ``reconsideration.'' ``The present phase is one of reconsideration and reassessment of all plans and trends,'' said Aziz, holding talks with King Hussein and other Jordanian officials. ``But we must have no illusions regarding the agggressive intentions of the United States, the Zionist entity, and other Western powers.'' ``We in Iraq are still looking for a comprehensive and just peace that safeguards the rights (of Arabs) and eliminates the core of the Middle East crises,'' said Aziz, alluding to the Palestinian uprising against Israel. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has previously linked a gulf settlement to Israeli withdrawal from lands claimed by the Palestinians. The Tehran Times reported that Iran and Iraq were to open embassies in each other's capitals Sunday following more than a decade of hostility. Saddam is seeking Iranian help to puncture the U.N.-sponsored embargo, possibly using Iranian pipelines to ship Iraqi oil. Quoting an unidentified source, the English-language newspaper said the two nations agreed to establish missions during a visit to Tehran by Iraqi Deputy Foreign Minister Wisam al-Zahawi. In Baghdad, children burned British and American flags and delivered letters to both embassies saying the U.N.-sanctioned economic sanctions are ``subjecting Iraqi children to hunger and endangering their health and lives.'' The protests occurred on Iraq's National Children's Day, which commemorates an Oct. 13, 1987 Iranian missile attack on a Baghdad primary school that killed 39 children. In other developments: -Fifteen Spaniards and four Britons were expected to leave Sunday on regular Iraqi Airlines flights to the Jordanian capital of Amman, according to Spanish Parliament member Cristina Almeida and Youssef Islam, the name the former pop singer Cat Stevens adopted after converting to the Moslem faith. The two said they arranged the releases in talks with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. -A Sudanese cargo ship sunk after colliding with an Iraqi vessel near Port Sudan. Three of its crew were reported missing, the official Sudan News Agency said Saturday. It said the collision between Sheeba and the Iraq cargo vessel Altaawin Alarabi took place Thursday, three nautical miles northeast of Port Sudan. The Iraqi ship had refrigeration on board. There was no explanation for the presence of the ship off Sudan, which insists it is honoring the conomic boycott on Iraq. -Turkish President Turgut Ozal on Saturday began a visit to five Middle Eastern and Gulf countries, with Saudi Arabia as his first stop. Turkey made a major contribution to the U.N. embargo by shutting off twin pipelines carrying Iraqi crude through Turkey. -Were a one-megaton nuclear bomb dropped on Baghdad, it would immediately kill 2.3 million people and injure nearly 1.3 million others, according to the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, Inc. The group, which won the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize, was meeting in Prato, Italy, to discuss the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Forbids Destruction of Monuments to Lenin
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued a decree Saturday forbidding the removal or destruction of Lenin monuments, war memorials and other state symbols under attack by anti-Communist protesters. Crowds in several cities have toppled statues of Vladimir I. Lenin, the leader of the Bolshevik Revolution, and desecrated other symbols of Communist power. Gorbachev's decree says such actions ``are incompatible with popular traditions, respect for the history of the Motherland and generally recognized moral standards.'' In the most recent incident, unidentified protesters attempted Oct. 4 to blow up a monument to Soviet soldiers who died fighting the Nazis in 1944 near the Lithuanian town of Krizhkalnis. Lithuanian leaders contend that their republic was illegally occupied and annexed by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II, and there is widespread resentment against the Red army among Lithuanian citizens. The republic's government, in a statement Saturday, deplored the bombing, which it called a ``provocative act ... perpetrated by forces aiming to destabilize the situation in Lithuania'' prior to negotiations on independence. Under Gorbachev's reforms, plaques and monuments to disgraced Soviet leaders such as Josef Stalin and Leonid Brezhnev have been removed. But Lenin, who led the revolution until his illness and death in 1924, is another matter. Some criticism of Lenin has appeared in the state-run press. But moves to brand him as a criminal and to stop venerating the Soviet victory in ``the Great Patriotic War'' of 1939-1945 appear to have met stiff public resistance, particularly in Russia, the largest Soviet republic. Outraged citizens have written letters to newspapers and been interviewed on television. When the city council in the Ukrainian city of Ternopol voted in July to dismantle statues of Lenin and Karl Marx, the local Communist Party committee branded it an act of ``vandalism and barbarism.'' According to the newspaper Soviet Culture, statues of Lenin have been destroyed in more than two dozen Georgian towns, and attempts have been made to topple them in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku and the Armenian capital of Yerevan. A giant monument to Lenin in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi was guarded round-the-clock for months until authorities gave into public demands and allowed it to be dismantled in September. Some prominent politicians, including the radical mayor of Moscow, Gavriil Popov, have advocated pulling down memorials to Lenin and changing the names of cities, streets and institutions dedicated to him. The city council of Leninakan, an Armenian community that was virtually destroyed by an earthquake two years ago and has since been rebuilt with international aid, voted this week to retake its ancient name of Kumairi. There has also been popular pressure in Leningrad to change back to the pre-revolutionary name of St. Petersburg. Gorbachev's decree apparently does not prevent name changes. But it suspends all decisions by local authorities ``about the pulling down, moving or changing of memorial structures,'' according to the official Soviet news agency Tass.

DOC.HEAD: Economy, Persian Gulf Send Bush's Approval Rating Downward
DOC.TEXT: Public approval of President Bush's handling of the economy and his handling of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait dropped in recent weeks, according to a CBS News-New York Times poll released Saturday. Bush's 60 percent overall approval rating in the poll is the worst of his presidency, but still higher than that recorded for Presidents Reagan and Carter at the same point in their administrations. The poll found a majority of Americans still approves of Bush's actions in the Persian Gulf, but the 57 percent approval rating is down from 75 percent soon after the invasion. The poll found 34 percent disapproved of Bush's handling of Iraq. Asked to rate Bush's handling of the economy, 52 percent said they disapproved and 36 percent said they approved. In August, 45 percent approved of Bush's handling of the economy, and 44 percent disapproved. Amid heightened concern over Bush's handling of the economy and the budget deficit, 30 percent said they disapproved of his overall performance - the highest level of his presidency in the CBS-New York Times poll. The poll was conducted among a random sample of 960 adults around the United States interviewed by telephone Monday through Wednesday. Results of such a poll should generally be accurate to within 3 percentage points in either direction.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Unveil Manifesto With Some of Bhutto's Promises
DOC.TEXT: The loose-knit coalition opposed to ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto on Saturday opened their campaign by announcing a platform that includes some of Ms. Bhutto's populist ideas. The Islamic Democratic Alliance released a 17-page manifesto as its leaders fanned out across the country to hold rallies and tell the voters that their differences had been swept aside. The alliance is comprised of nine parties spanning the ideological spectrum and bound together largely by their contempt for the 37-year-old former prime minister. Ms. Bhutto has capitalized on their highly publicized bickering and labeled them the ``remnants of Zia,'' referring to Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who took power in a coup in 1977 and ruled until his death in a 1988 plane crash. Many Pakistanis have voiced fears that a government headed by the alliance would resurrect many of Zia's policies, curtailin individual rights especially for women and non-Moslems. Kamal Azfar, special assistant to caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, sought to dispel the notion. He told a news conference that the coalition's manifesto ``has some of the populist promises'' that have been the hallmark of Ms. Bhutto's left-leaning Pakistan People's Party. Among them were increased education and medical care, free housing for the poor, programs to reduce the country's alarming birthrate, deregulation of the economy, denationalization of major industry and financial reforms. Ms. Bhutto has yet to announce her party's manifesto. She currently faces charges of corruption in a special court. Her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, was arrested Wednesday on a kidnapping and extortion charge. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissesd Ms. Bhutto's government Aug. 6 on charges of corruption and mismanagement and set parliamentary elections for Oct. 24. ``The 20 months of PPP rule was a period of anarchy, loot and plunder of national resources, gross incompetence and breakdown of law and order,'' the alliance's manifesto said, referring to Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. ``It was the government of one family, for one family and by one family,'' the manifesto said. The alliance promised ``severe measures to put an end to all un-Islamic means of ill-gotten wealth, including gambling, narcotics, blackmarketing, hoarding, smuggling and corruption.''

DOC.HEAD: Dealer Buys Rare Painting at Bargain Price
DOC.TEXT: A New York art dealer offered the sole bid Saturday on a long-lost painting and, in his opinion, walked away with a steal from an auction at an amusement park. The 6-foot by 10-foot painting by American landscape artist Albert Bierstadt of Lake Lucerne and the Swiss Alps was expected to fetch $1 million. Richard York bought it for half that. ``When one examines it as a work of art it has all the elements that make Bierstadt great,'' York said. ``It's also one of his first large-scale paintings.'' York, who owns the Richard York Gallery in New York City, said he thought the decision to hold the auction at the Rocky Point Amusement Park may have affected the purchase price. ``Maybe it's not the right climate for the picture here,'' he said, glancing at the faded wine-colored velvet curtains and glitzy gold drapes that decorate the hall. Another large Swiss landscape by Bierstadt went for $990,000 at Sotheby's New York auction house on May 24. The 1858 Lake Lucerne painting was offered about halfway into the auction of art from the estate of the late Pearl J. Rose. Mrs. Rose was secretive about her collection. In fact, she and her family kept the Bierstadt from the public for more than 100 years since it was last sold in Boston in 1882. Bidding had been erratic. A painting by Mauritz Frederik Hendrick De Haas, expected to bring $13,000, was sold for $50,000. One by Charles Storer, valued at $4,000, was unsold after there was no opening bid of $300. John Lynch, the estate attorney, said he had inquiries about the Bierstadt from France, Tokyo, London and around the United States. The auctioneer started bidding at $500,000. When none of the 150 registered bidders would offer $600,000, he dropped to $550,000. Again no takers. He then stopped the auction to confer with organizers. A stunned audience watched as he asked one last time for a higher bid. York raised his hand. Afterward, York said he had been prepared to pay more. He would not say if he bought the painting for himself or a client, or whether it would be staying in the United States. Bierstadt, part of the Hudson River group of painters, built his reputation on panoramic landscapes of the American West. Lewis E. Peck, a distant cousin of Mrs. Rose who inherited her collection when she died in August 1989 at the age of 86, said he had no regrets about holding the auction at the amusement park. ``It's in Rhode Island. That's where it should have stayed,'' he said. Bierstadt was born in Germany but raised in New Bedford, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Precedes Camp Blanding, Fla.
Animal-Rights Activists Cited in Florida, Ignored in Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with deer hunt protest in Texas.
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: A dozen animal-rights activists were cited for leaving a designated area in a demonstration Saturday against Florida's annual Youth Deer Hunt. In Texas, protesters who want to test the legality of hunter-harassment laws in effect in 37 states walked noisily behind bow-and-arrow hunters to prevent them sneaking up on their prey, but failed in their primary mission: to get arrested. About 80 demonstrators carrying signs and noisemakers marched for four hours outside the Camp Blanding Wildlife Management Area in northeast Florida, while 39 young hunters were inside. The state-sponsored deer hunt is staged to help parents and guardians teach children 8 to 15 to hunt safely. The protesters had a permit to demonstrate across the street from the park, about a half-mile from the nearest hunting area. But 12 attempted to go inside and were stopped, said Capt. Bill Glover of the Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission. They were cited for failure to obey lawful order, a misdemeanor. One also was charged with resisting arrest, Glover said. They were released pending a court appearance later this month. Protesters had planned to make noise and disrupt the hunt, but Glover said there appeared to be no violations of a new state law that prohibits interfering with legal hunting, trapping or fishing. ``All in all, both the hunt and the protest went pretty smoothly,'' he said. ``We just had a few who felt like they had to push their cause and come into an area they couldn't go into.'' Barry Silver, a Boca Raton lawyer and board member of Florida Action for Animals, argued that public funds should not be used to pay for the hunt. ``We are against the use of taxpayer money in order to indoctrinate our youth to become trained killers,'' he said. ``Training children in acts of violence will only encourage them to become violent later on.'' In Texas, four teams of 12-15 protesters stationed themselves in Sam Houston National Park, 55 miles north of Houston, during a bow-and-arrow hunt, and rustled leaves as they walked behind the hunters, said Dana Forbes of Fund for Animals. Even though the demonstrators were technically violating the state's hunter-harassment law, game wardens declined to arrest them, giving them no vehicle with which to challenge the law in court. ``If they have a right to harm these animals, we have a right to protect them,'' Ms. Forbes said. Tommy Johnson, the state game warden for Walker County, said no one was arrested because none of the hunters seemed to be harassed. The protesters ``wanted to have their little say and have their little day and the hunters were real courteous about it,'' Johnson said. ``They took a whole lot more abuse than most people should have to put up with.'' Ms. Forbes said some hunters ``were obviously very angry, but we didn't allow anything to get physically violent.'' Wayne Pacelle, national director of the Fund for Animals, said Friday that if protesters were arrested, the 23-year-old organization would take the state to court and possibly use the arrests to test hunter-harassment laws around the country. The group contends that bow-and-arrow hunting is far more cruel than gun hunting because the animals die slowly or are wounded and remain crippled. State officials said 80,000 hunters in Texas this year applied for bow licenses, and 1.1 million applied for gun-hunting licenses.

DOC.HEAD: National Memorial Dedicated To Fallen Firefighters
LaserPhoto FDK1
DOC.TEXT: A national monument etched with the names of 1,238 firefighters who have died in the line of duty since 1981 was dedicated Saturday at a ceremony that recounted the tales of fallen heroes. President Bush signed legislation in August designating the 9-year-old monument at the National Fire Academy in Emmitsburg the official national memorial to career and volunteer firefighters who died on the job. ``While many local communities and states honor their fallen heroes, this memorial stands as a lasting national tribute to those who have answered their last alarm,'' said Olin L. Greene, administrator of the U.S. Fire Administration. About 200 people, including state, local and national officials and firefighters from across the country, attended the outdoor ceremony held at the 7-foot-tall, pyramid-shaped limestone monument. Honor guard units from Baltimore County and St. Louis marched to the strains of bagpipes traditionally played at firefighters' funerals. ``In recent years, many people have bemoaned our country's lack of national heroes,'' said Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., who shepherded legislation through Congress to get the memorial dedicated. ``What they fail to realize is that we do have heroes in every fire hall across this land.'' ``No job demands more sacrifice of time and dedication. Sadly, that sacrifice too often results in death,'' said Wallace E. Stickney, director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which operates the academy. ``We honor that sacrifice now, as we dedicate this fallen firefighters memorial. This is much more than a memorial. It is national recognition by President Bush and Congress that these men and women, who have given their lives, deserve the respect and honor of all Americans.'' Alan Lee Mickelson, one of 113 firefighters from 35 states who died in 1989, fought his last blaze in Gillette, Wyo., on Jan. 31. ``He fell 40 feet through a roof in a burning church. The whole sanctuary roof fell at once. There was no warning at all,'' said his 34-year-old widow, Marietta Mickelson, who traveled from her home in northeast Wyoming. ``I just think it was something good for my kids to see - a part of the healing,'' she said. ``It was something we needed to do.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Obit-Le Duc Tho, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0518,0783
DOC.HEAD: Le Duc Tho, Vietnamese Negotiator During War
DOC.TEXT: Le Duc Tho, the co-founder of the Vietnamese Communist Party who in 1973 negotiated the U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam, died in Hanoi Saturday. Official accounts said he was 79. Tho shared the Nobel Peace Prize with former U.S. Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, with whom he negotiated the Paris Peace Accords of 1973. But Tho turned it down, saying peace had not yet been achieved. A Foreign Ministry official in the Vietnamese capital confirmed Tho's death but gave no details. Japan's Kyodo's news agency, reporting from Hanoi, said Tho died of throat cancer. He had been hospitalized at an army hospital since returning in April from treatment in Paris, the report said. Kissinger wrote in a 1982 book, ``Years of Upheaval,'' that Tho's ``subtlety, his acumen, his iron self-discipline'' were admirable, and ``in all the years of negotiation with me he never lost his poise; he never made a mistake.'' ``As a professional Leninist he despised the bourgeois values of compromise I put forward,'' Kissinger said, ``and the effrontery of his deceptions inside and outside the conference room could be enraging.'' In April 1975, forces from Communist North Vietnam defeated the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government and reunified the country. Tho, known as a hard-line party organizer and theoretician, was believed to have had a key role in Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia in late 1978. But in 1986, at the Sixth National Party Congress, he and other veterans were replaced on the Politburo by pragmatists seeking economic reform. He became an adviser to the party Central Committee, and Western diplomats said he continued to exercise considerable influence in the party's conservative wing. His younger brother Mai Chi Tho - who is said to share his hard-line views -is the powerful interior minister in charge of internal security, and is on the Politburo. Last month, Tho was awarded the state's Gold Star Order for his more than 60 years of political activity. ``I pledge to dedicate my utmost efforts, as I have done since I joined the revolution, to the common cause of the party and the country,'' he said at the ceremony. Much of Tho's life was shrouded in secrecy, like many of the revolutionaries of his generation. There are several accounts of his birth. Some say he was born to poor parents in a village about 60 miles south of Hanoi. But other Western biographical sources say his father was a civil service official of middle rank in the French colonial administration. As a teenager, Tho became involved in left-wing labor and political movements and helped organize strikes and riots in the Hanoi area. He helped found the Indochinese Communist Party in 1930. During his imprisonment by the French, his fellow inmates nicknamed him ``Tho the Phonograph'' for his ceaseless recitations of Marxist doctrine. His activities during World War II are a matter of speculation among Western historians. Some sources say Tho escaped to China and helped Vietnam's ``revolutionary father'' Ho Chi Minh found the Viet Minh guerrillas and lead them against the Japanese. Others say Tho spent the war years in a French prison in Vietnam. He joined the Politburo in the 1950s and launched attacks against ``revisionists, defeatists, traitors, pessimists and individualists.'' But he often called for moderation in healing party rifts. In 1968, with the Vietnam War apparently at a stalemate, the United States and North Vietnam opened talks toward a cease-fire. Tho was the North's chief representative at the meetings in Paris. The negotiations - some public, others secret - dragged on for years, with the two sides trying to overcome what Kissinger called ``mountains and ravines'' of complexities. Finally, the accord was signed Jan. 27, 1973. It resulted in the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Vietnam, the exchange of prisoners and the splintering of South Vietnam into Communist and Saigon-controlled zones. But the pact had no machinery for effectively enforcing the provisions. Fighting continued, and when the North Vietnamese began their final assault south, Tho was in the south as a direct link with the Politburo. Recalling the talks and the fall of Saigon in 1975, Tho said in 1985 on U.S. television that the Communist side had ``wrested total victory.'' Word of Tho's survivors was not immediately released.

DOC.HEAD: Surgeons Operate on German Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th and 6th grafs, bgng `Prosecutor Werner ...' to CORRECT spellings to Kaufmann sted Kaufman
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons removed a bullet Saturday from the spinal cord of Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, shot at a restaurant campaign rally the day before by a mentally disturbed man with drug problems. Schaeuble, 48, one of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's top aides and an architect of the recent German unification, was in ``satisfactory and stable'' condition after five hours of surgery to remove the bullet, hospital officials said. German television said he was out of danger, and Lothar Spaeth, governor of Baden-Wuerttemberg state, said after a visit to the hospital that Schaeuble stood a chance of full recovery. The gunmen fired three times at Schaeuble as he was signing autographs at the restaurant during a campaign appearance in Oppenau, in his home district late Friday. The second bullet hit the right side of Schaueble's face. A third shot struck a bodyguard, who was in satisfactory condition Saturday. Prosecutor Werner Botz identified the gunman as Dieter Kaufmann, 37. Kaufmann told investigators he had acted out of revenge for the ``terror of the state'' and had decided six months ago to shoot Schaeuble, according to Botz. The gunman had been undergoing treatment for schizophrenia, according to the Interior Ministry. Kaufmann was released from prison in 1986 after serving three years in jail for a drug offense. He was unemployed and lived with his parents in a nearby village. The gun he used was a .38-caliber Smith and Wesson revolver he stole from his father, Botz said. On April 26, a mentally disturbed woman attacked Oskar Lafontaine, the opposition Social Democratic candidate for chancellor in the Dec. 2 elections. Lafontaine was stabbed in the neck at a campaign rally, but has since recovered. Hans Neusel, the No. 2 official in Schaeuble's ministry, escaped with superficial injuries when a bomb planted by the Red Army Faction terrorist gang blew up his car near Bonn in July. Schaeuble was taken from Oppenau to a hospital in nearby Offenburg, and later flown by helicopter to the university hospital in Freiburg, his home town in southwest Germany. Kohl and other politicians visited the Freiburg hospital Saturday. Schaeuble's wife Ingeborg and their four children were also at his side. Witnesses told German television the gunman sat in the next-to-last row in the restaurant hall during the rally and fired as Schaeuble approached. One of the minister's guards, Klaus-Dieter Michalski, jumped in front of Schaeuble to shield him and was shot in the stomach. Botz said Michalski was ``relatively lightly injured'' and would be released soon. Schaeuble has sometimes been mentioned as a possible successor to Kohl when the Christian Democratic leader decides to retire. Schaeuble guided the difficult talks that led to the historic German unification on Oct. 3. He was named interior minister by Kohl in April 1989, and previously had been the chancellor's chief of staff.

DOC.HEAD: Lafontant Acclaimed At Duvalierist Convention
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The former head of the dreaded paramilitary police appeared at a political convention Saturday, defying warrants for his arrest. Former Minister of the Interior Roger Lanfontant is wanted for plotting against national security, but the arrest warrants have not been served by the army, where he has followers and inspires fear. Lanfontant was head of the Tonton Macoutes, which used terror to keep the Duvalier family in power for 29 years, until Jean Claude Duvalier fled in 1986. The two-day National Reconciliation Convention on Sunday was to select a neo-Duvalierist unity candidate for upcoming general elections. Lafontant has been openly campaigning for the presidency, although the 1987 constitution bars criminal supporters of dictatorship from running for office until 1997. Lafontant's return in July from exile in the Dominican Republic made many Haitians fear an attempt to disrupt the elections, now set for Dec. 16. In 1987, the last attempt at free elections collapsed when thugs with the support of the army murdered at least 34 voters at the polls. Hundreds more were killed and wounded in pre-election violence. ``We have come out of hiding,'' said Radio Liberte director Serge Beaulieu at the convention, addressing a cheering crowd of around 1,500. ``We are the power. We will organize elections ourselves; we don't need the United Nations,'' said Beaulieu, criticizing soon-to-arrive U.N. election monitors and security experts as an infringement of national sovereignty. The mission of the observers includes trying to assure that paramilitary and police forces do not intimidate voters. On a five-hour visit to Haiti Friday, former President Carter said the army had not yet arrested Lafontant because he was in hiding. But in recent weeks Lafontant has been seen in the provincial towns of Cap-Haitien and Hinche, as well as in the capital suburb Petionville. Other Duvalierist leaders on the podium besides Beaulieu were Duvalierist militants Alphonse Lahens and Jean Theagene and former Duvalier-dynasty ministers Herve Boyer, Alix Cineas, and Dr. Volvick Remy Joseph. ``We have not yet chosen our candidate. They are still divided among themselves,'' said convention moderator Marjorie Robins. Dr. Francois Duvalier ruled Haiti from 1957 to 1971. His son Jean-Claude succeeded him and was ousted on Feb. 7, 1986. He is living in France. ``The doctrine of Dr. Francois Duvalier is very, very fine, but it must not be applied as it was applied but as he conceived it,'' said Robins. On March 13, after four brief military-controlled regimes, civilian provisional President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot took over and promised to hold elections. The president-elect is to take office on Feb. 7, 1991, on the fifth anniversary of the ouster of Jean-Claude Duvalier. There are about 20 presidential hopefuls.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Begins Rollout to Launch Pad
DOC.TEXT: Columbia, the shuttle plagued with mechanical problems since April, was pulled from its hangar again Saturday night for a trip to the launch pad. The nation's oldest flight-qualified orbiter began the six-hour, 4.2 mile ride from to launch pad 39B at 9:03 p.m. EDT. Its counterpart Atlantis was taken to pad 39A Friday night. In late October, Columbia will undergo the first of what may be several fueling tests. If Columbia passes, its mission to deploy the $150 million Astro observatory may get under way in December. The move was Columbia's sixth since April 22, when it was first rolled out for a May 30 mission. Hydrogen leaks scrubbed that launch, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration didn't get a shuttle in orbit until Discovery took off with the Ulysses solar probe on Oct. 6. On June 6, Columbia failed a leak test on the pad and was taken back to the assembly building for fuel line repairs. On Aug. 9, Columbia, equipped with a fuel line borrowed from the still-unfinished shuttle Endeavour, was rolled back to pad 39A. An electronic problem with an Astro telescope prompted NASA to delay a Sept. 1 launch. Then on Sept. 5, hydrogen flooded Columbia's aft compartment during fueling. Columbia's next launch attempt was set for Sept. 18 but once again, a hydrogen buildup was detected in the engine compartment and the liftoff was scrubbed. At that point, NASA decided Columbia would have to vacate pad 39A to permit Atlantis to be readied for a secret military mission, which had been on hold since mid-July because of leaking hydrogen. After Discovery's launch, Columbia was shifted to pad 39B for an all-out search for the sources of its hydrogen leaks. The very next day, the approach of a hurricane forced shuttle managers to bring Columbia back to its cavernous shelter.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Hold ``Africa's First Gay Pride March''
DOC.TEXT: Homosexuals and lesbians waving placards marched through the city Saturday to demand equal rights in what organizers said was Africa's first gay protest march. About 200 men and women chanting ``Gay rights now'' marched for more than an hour in pouring rain as startled Saturday shoppers watched. Most of the marchers were white men, but women and blacks also took part. A few marchers wore paper bags over their heads to conceal their identities. Organizers said the struggle for gay rights had to be linked to the fight for racial equality in South Africa. ``With this march, South Africa's gays and lesbians will actively join the struggle for human rights in South Africa. They will also finally take their place in a venerable tradition of worldwide defiance and celebration - the gay liberation movement,'' they said in a statement. Dozens of police officers followed the march, which ended without incident with a picnic in a Johannesburg park. Homosexuality is illegal in South Africa. Some onlookers jeered or heckled the marchers. Two men with bibles and a loudspeaker yelled that homosexuality was sinful.

DOC.HEAD: Former Silicon Valley Executive Wins $31 Million in Plane Crash Case
DOC.TEXT: A former Silicon Valley executive, who was maimed when a light plane plummeted onto the busy San Diego Freeway in 1987, has been awarded a record $31 million, his lawyer said Saturday. Terry O'Reilly, an attorney for Dennis Paboojian, said he believes the settlement is the largest ever negotiated by a single person suing for personal injuries. The previous record of $28.5 million was awarded a Salinas woman and her child who were paralyzed in a 1985 traffic accident, he said. Paboojian, 47, lost his left forearm and fingers on his right hand, was partially paralyzed and suffered burns over 65 percent of his body when the six-seater Piper Malibu PA-46 he was flying crashed near Long Beach on Nov. 29, 1987. The single-engine plane began having engine trouble over Southern California, and Paboojian turned the controls over to flying instructor John Spiesman, who died in the crash. The plane, en route from Palomar Airport in San Diego County to San Jose Airport, came down a half-mile short of Long Beach Municipal Airport. ``The courage involved in his survival is just incredible,'' O'Reilly said. Paboojian, of Cupertino, headed Rolm Corp. from January 1986 until April 1987, and then he served as a consultant to the company. The settlement, which will be paid immediately, was ratified Friday in Santa Clara County Superior Court, O'Reilly said. Attorneys for Paboojian and Alabama-based Teledyne Continental Motors, which built the Piper's engine, had been expected to go to trial next week. O'Reilly said the engine maker agreed to pay $20 million. An additional $11 million will be paid by the airplane maker, Piper Aircraft, the flight instructor's company, S&G Flight Services of San Jose, and companies responsible for maintaining and leasing the plane, among others, O'Reilly said. Efforts to reach Teledyne and the other companies for comment were unsuccessful. None of the defendants acknowledged liability for the accident under terms of the settlement, O'Reilly said. Paboojian's lawsuit accused Teledyne of ignoring evidence that its engines were poorly designed. After the accident, Piper canceled its contract with Teledyne and began using a different engine in its planes.

DOC.HEAD: Question of Priests and Marriage Not on Synod Agenda
DOC.TEXT: The issue of whether to allow marriage by Roman Catholic priests is not on the agenda for the second half a worldwide gathering of bishops, a spokesman said Saturday. Brazilian Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves said discussion groups scheduled to begin Monday will address a number of topics, including celibacy and priests' relations with women. Bishops from Brazil, Lebanon and the Bahamas had called for debate on allowing priests to marry. Several said during the synod that such a change would help resolve the shortage of priests in certain countries. After two weeks of presenting speeches in daily meetings, the bishops plan to break into groups to help compile a final document on the synod, called by Pope John Paul II. Moreira Neves, the moderator of the conference, said the issues scheduled to be discussed include: the defense of celibacy; priests' rapport with women; the role of future priests in the church and community; the commitment for justice and peace; the problems of attracting and training priests, and the necessity to attract new believers. The discussion on priests' relations with women would focus on how young priests can to work with women while avoiding ``both excessive familiarity and distrustfulness,'' the spokesman said. More than 200 bishops are attending the synod.

DOC.HEAD: Gettysburg College Establishes Eisenhower Prize
DOC.TEXT: Gettysburg College set up an annual award for encouraging leadership in memory of Dwight D. Eisenhower, who was born 100 years ago Sunday. Another former president, Gerald Ford, announced the $25,000 Eisenhower Leadership Prize at a news conference Saturday attended by college officials and Eisenhower's grandson, David, who serves on the college's board of trustees. The prize will be given not only to political or military leaders, but also to emergent leaders in science, medicine, education and social work, Ford said. Recipients will serve as guest lecturers at the college. ``The prize is unique in that it is aimed at stimulating the kinds of leadership in a broad, broad sense, that would reflect what Ike thought was in the best interest of our country,'' Ford said. Eisenhower bought a farm in Gettysburg in 1951 that he used as a retreat during his presidency and retired there after his second term ended in 1961. He also had an office at Gettysburg College. Eisenhower, who was born in Denison, Texas, died in March 1969 at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Bethesda, Md. The first recipient of the award will be named Oct. 14, 1991, by a 12-member board including David Eisenhower, Dallas industrialist H. Ross Perot and Drew Lewis, chief executive officer of Union Pacific Corp.

DOC.HEAD: South Savors The Sunshine But Floods Still Menace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for grafs 7-8, `Lili was ...' to UPDATE with 10:30 p.m. advisory and winds dropping to 50 mph. Picks up 10th graf, `Head-high waves ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NAGX1
DOC.TEXT: Southerners exalted in sunshine Saturday and began bailing out from the drenching floodwaters left by two tropical storms, grateful that the threat of a third storm, Lili, was fading. But the storms left at least 12 people dead in Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina. And although the heavy rains were forecast to end, residents of low-lying areas were not out of danger. ``Even if it stops raining, the dams could develop problems two or three days from now,'' said George Ballenger, chief of dams and reservoir safety in Columbia, S.C. ``There's a lag time between the time the water falls and works its way down to the dam,'' Ballenger said. Still, the clear skies offered a welcome respite. ``The sun's shining brightly,'' said Gwen White, a spokeswoman for the Dare County emergency operations in North Carolina, on Saturday. ``I don't even know if we're going to get any rain out of it.'' Lili was downgraded from a hurricane to a tropical storm shortly before 6 a.m. Saturday, and all tropical storm watches and warnings were canceled along the mid-Atlantic coast. At 10:30 p.m. EDT Saturday, Lili's center was located near latitude 37.1 north, longitude 70.9 west, or about 280 miles south of Nantucket Island, Mass. Lili was expected to increase in forward speed and turn toward the northeast. Its maximum sustained winds were near 50 mph, down from 60 mph at 6 p.m. EDT, and some decrease in strength was forecast. Head-high waves Friday afternoon claimed a 10-foot section of dune fence near the base of the Cape Hatteras lighthouse. The century-old safety beacon, the oldest on the East Coast, was in no imminent danger, authorities said. ``The rains have stopped in the western part of the state and, of course, in the eastern part of the state, Hurricane Lili has gone way offshore,'' said Graham Wilson, spokesman for the State Emergency Response Team in North Carolina. ``The problem in the western part of the state is still some water on the roads.'' More than 2,000 South Carolinians were told Friday night to evacuate their homes as rivers and creeks swelled around the state and threatened to flood more low-lying areas. Earlier, residents boarded up their windows along North Carolina's Outer Banks, shelters were readied and some tourists fled, but the state was spared Lili's full brunt, forecasters said. At least 12 people died in the onslaught of tropical storms Marco and Klaus. A 2-year-old boy died Friday in South Carolina after he wandered away from home. Four others drowned Wednesday when a dam broke, including a 10-year-old boy whose body was not found until Saturday. Rising waters in Georgia killed four people, including an 80-year-old man as he and his wife struggled to leave a flooded railroad track. One person drowned and two died in storm-related traffic accidents in North Carolina. In Florida, cleanup was under way along the central Gulf Coast, where Marco caused $1.5 million in damage. ``When it hit here, it slammed us,'' said Joe Miller, Manatee County parks director. ``I'm still amazed. I'd hate to see a hurricane.''

DOC.HEAD: Gas Explosion at Tortilla Kitchen Kills Manager, 3 Boys
DOC.TEXT: A gas line from a propane truck to a tank at a tortilla factory broke and exploded Saturday, killing the manager of the establishment and three boys, the fire department said. The four victims were burned to death and at least seven other people suffered severe burns, said Fire Chief Jaime Espinoza. The kitchen and seven nearby houses were in flames when firemen arrived, he said. Crews had difficult reaching the Simon Bolivar neighborhood where the explosion occurred because of poor roads to the hastily constructed shantytown. Its cardboard and plank cabins perch on the edge of the hotel district of this Pacific Coast resort. Four months ago a similar gas explosion killed several people in Acapulco, Espinoza said.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Forces Capture, Destroy Rebel Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Afghan troops fighting near Kabul captured a large cache of weapons and ammunition from Moslem guerrillas, who recently increased their attacks on the capital, Afghanistan's official radio said. ``The Kabul garrison contingent launched a successful cleanup operation south of the city and gained new ground,'' Kabul Radio said in a broadcast monitored in Islamabad. ``The soldiers are fighting in high spirits.'' The radio said several heavy machine guns, hundreds of missiles, rocket-propelled grenades, anti-personnel mines and 100 pounds of explosives were seized or destroyed. The report could not be independently confirmed. Earlier this month, fundamentalist guerrillas stepped up their rocket attacks on the capital in preparation for a major assault against the Soviet-backed government of Kabul, diplomatic sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Gather For Conference Amid Wave of Protests
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party members opened a regional conference Saturday amid mounting protests provoked by a party leader critical of some reforms, the state CTK news agency reported. A rally by about 4,000 anti-Communist demonstrators, organized by the governing Civic Forum and other gruops, was held outside the Communist congress for Bohemia and Moravia, which opened in Olomouc, about 140 miles southeast of Prague. On Thursday, the Czechoslovak government proposed seizing all Communist Party property without compensation. The Communists were driven from power by a pro-democracy meeting last year. ``We are witnessing an open drive of right-wing forces,'' CTK quoted Jiri Machalik, chairman of the regional Communist Party of the Czech lands, as saying in his opening speech to the congress. ``Basically, we do not reject privatization ... but the privatization should not be the goal, it should be the means to increase the efficiency of the national economy,'' he said. Anti-Communist sentiment swelled quickly after comments earlier this week by party chairman Vasil Mohorita, who criticized Czechoslovakia's economic reform as a de facto return to capitalism and called for a ``hard and uncompromising struggle.'' Over 50,000 people jammed Prague's Old Town Square Thursday to protest his remarks. Civic Forum, the country's leading political force, also convened a two-day meeting Saturday to discuss strategy for communal elections in November, CTK reported. Although Civic Forum began as a loose coalition of democratic forces, delegates at the meeting urged forming a more solid organization. ``We should transform the ad lib structure of the movement into something similar to a political party,'' said Pavel Rychetsky, Czechoslovak vice premier and a Civic Forum leader. The 11-month-old movement elected Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus as its first chairman Saturday, CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT file number
DOC.TEXT: Making common cause with its new Arab allies, the United States has joined the rest of the Security Council in denouncing Israeli authorities for killing 19 Palestinians during rioting in Jerusalem. In its unanimous vote late Friday, the council asked for a U.N. investigation of the deaths. But Israel said it would not allow such a mission on its territory. The U.S. vote for the resolution represented a rare departure from the usual American practice of defending Israel, its longtime ally, from censure in the council. The last U.S. vote against Israel in the United Nations was in 1988 over the Israeli practice of expelling suspected leaders of the Arab uprising, known as the intefadeh. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate Finance Committee approved a middle-of-the-road budget-cutting plan early today that raises some taxes on the wealthy and boosts the levy on gasoline. The panel adopted the plan on a bipartisan 15-5 vote, leaving the Senate in sharp contrast with the more fractious House. In that chamber, Democrats have endorsed a liberal package containing sharper tax increases for the wealthy. Republicans are torn between a more conservative proposal bearing President Bush's plan to cut the capital gains tax, or perhaps offering nothing at all. ``I believe it is a fair compromise,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, just before the post-midnight Finance panel vote. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Lawmakers are voicing concern that the level of military spending approved by Congress in its budget resolution is too high for a nation facing an economic crisis. ``This isn't about a war with the Russians. This isn't about a war in the Middle East. This is about the economic survival of this country,'' said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., prior to House approval Friday of a $268 billion defense bill. By a vote of 322-97, the House adopted a military spending bill that cuts off production of the B-2 bomber at 15 planes and slashes President Bush's budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative. The House bill meets the level of defense spending worked out by the House and Senate last week in a budget resolution seeking to cut $500 billion from the federal deficit over the next five years. ---= BERLIN (AP) - A lone assailant has shot and seriously wounded Germany's top law enforcement official, but officials say the attacker had a history of mental problems and that terrorists were not involved. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, considered a possible future candidate for chancellor, was shot late Friday at a campaign meeting at a restaurant in Oppenau, about 120 miles south of Frankfurt. Television reports said a security guard was also seriously wounded when he threw himself in front of Schaeuble. After Friday's attack, Schaeuble was hospitalized in Freiburg. Interior Ministry spokesman Roland Bachmeier said Schaeuble was ``seriously wounded'' but that his life was not in danger. ---= BUCHAREST, Romania (AP) - The government has suddenly switched to painful and politically risky capitalist reform, raising fears of winters as cold and dark as those imposed by executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It cut energy subsidies and credits to the country's chronically inefficient government-owned industries and said the same treatment was in store for private consumers. On Friday it said the country's second-largest automaker will be allowed to go bankrupt if it can't pay its debts. Officials also have put Romanians on notice that state-controlled prices will go up, and that the country can afford no more across-the-board wage increases. Economics Minister Eugen Dijmarescu warned that could cause civil unrest.
